headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q4 2014 Louisiana-Pacific Corp. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Joyce and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purpos
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q4 2014 Louisiana-Pacific Corp. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Joyce and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes.
I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Sallie Bailey, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Ms. Bailey would then the call over to Curt Stevens, Chief Executive Officer. Please proceed.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Well, thank you very much, Joyce, and good morning, and good afternoon for those of you on the East Coast. We thank you for joining our conference call today to discuss LP's financial results for the fourth quarter of 2014 and the year ended Decemb
componenttext:
Great. Well, thank you very much, Joyce, and good morning, and good afternoon for those of you on the East Coast. We thank you for joining our conference call today to discuss LP's financial results for the fourth quarter of 2014 and the year ended December 31, 2014.
I am Sallie Bailey, LP Chief Financial Officer. And with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's Chief Executive Officer; as well as Mike Kinney and Becky Barckley, our primary Investor Relations contact.
I'll begin the discuss with a review of the financial results for the fourth quarter of 2014 and the full year. It will be followed by some comments on the performance on the individual segments and balance sheet.
When I finished my comments, Curt will discuss the general market environment in which LP has been operating and provide his perspective on our operating results and give some thoughts on the outlook.
As we have done in the past, we have open this call to the public and we're doing a webcast. That webcast can be accessed at www.lpcorp.com. Additionally, to help with the discussion, we have provided a presentation with supplemental information that should be reviewed in conjunction with the earnings release. I will be referencing these slides in my comments this morning. We filed an 8-K this morning with some supplemental information and expect to file our Form 10-K before the end of the month.
I want to remind all the participants about the forward-looking statements comment on Slide 2 of the presentation. Please also be aware of the discussion of our use of non-GAAP financial information included on Slide 3 of the presentation.
The appendix attached to the presentation have some of the necessary reconciliations that's been supplemented by the Form 8-K filing we made this morning. Rather than reading these 2 statements, I incorporate them with this one.
2014 was a challenging year for LP. Housing starts grew to just over 1 million starts or 9% higher than 2013. Single-family housing starts to grew 5% year-over-year. At L.P., we remain focused on activities which are in our control and continue to invest in our future, so we are prepared when U.S. housing starts return to its historical levels.
Moving to Slide 4 of the presentation for a discussion of the fourth quarter 2014 and the full year 2014 result. We reported net sales of $454 million for the fourth quarter of 2014, a 5% decline from the net sales of $480 million reported for the fourth quarter of 2013.
In the fourth quarter of 2014, we recorded net loss of $43 million or $0.30 per diluted share. The fourth quarter of 2013, we reported net loss of $20[ph] million or $0.15 per diluted share. The adjusted loss from continuing operations for the quarter is $32 million or $0.23 per share based upon a normalized tax rate of  35%. This compares to a loss of $9 million or $0.06 per share in the fourth quarter of 2013.
Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was negative $17 million in the quarter compared to the [indiscernible] EBITDA of $24 million in the fourth quarter of 2013.
On a year-to-date basis, we recorded $1 billion of net sales, a loss of $75 million and a loss per share of $0.53 as compared to net sales of $2.1 million[ph], net income of $177 million and earnings per share of $1.23 for the full year of 2013.
On a non-GAAP basis, we recorded an adjusted loss from continuing operations of $60 million, a loss per share of $0.42 and adjusted EBITDA of $44 million for the full year of 2014.
In 2013, we recorded $121 million of adjusted income from continuing operations, earnings per share of $0.90[ph] and adjusted EBITDA of $330 million. The significant headwind experienced by LP in 2014 was a 26% decrease in LSL pricing. The lower LSL impacted operating income and adjusted EBITDA by $298 million, which is more than the year-over-year decrease in adjusted EBITDA.
I will now move to Slide 5 and our view of our segment results, beginning with OSB. LP's OSB segment recorded an operating loss of $29 million and $203 million of sales in the quarter compared to operating and profit of $7 million and $230 million of sales in the fourth quarter of 2013. For the quarter, we're reporting negative adjusted EBITDA of $50[ph] million compared to positive EBITDA of $27 million in the fourth quarter of 2013. We had a 1% decrease in volume and pricing for OSB was up 12% over the fourth quarter of 2013.
We took 136 done days during the quarter, which equates to approximately 200 million square feet. Most of the down days were market related. The positive utilization of our operating mills for the end of the quarter were approximately 77%.
For the full year, OSB had an operating loss of $53 million compared to income of $230 million in 2013. Adjusted EBITDA in 2014 was $4 million compared to $285 million in 2013. The impact of lower OSB pricing between the years was $298 million.
Slide 6 reports the results of the Siding business. This segment includes our SmartSide and CanExel siding product. The Siding segment reported sale of $141 million in the fourth quarter of 2014, an increase of 2% from $138 million reported in the fourth quarter of 2013. The Siding segment reported operating income of $14 million compared to $16 million in the fourth quarter of 2013, and adjusted EBITDA of $19 million as compared to $20 million in the same quarter of 2013.
During the quarter, the Siding segment did not produce any OSB compared to the fourth quarter of 2013 when the Siding segment produced 45 million square feet of OSB.
For the quarter, SmartSide average sales price were 4% and volume increased 4%. Volume is increasing in our SmartSide line due to continued penetration in several key focus market, including retail, repair/remodel and such. However, the Siding segment was negatively impacted by shortages in the space. We estimate that the Siding business lost 45 days of downtime or 27 million square feet of production in the fourth quarter. We estimate that the gross margin on the lost sales along with a higher mill cost decreased adjusted EBITDA by $5 million for the quarter.
CanExel prices were down slightly in U.S. dollars or up 6% in Canadian dollars. Canada is CanExel's primary market. Volumes were up 11% in the quarter due to higher Canadian and international demand. And on a year-to-date basis, the Siding segment recorded $617 million in sale, $80[ph] million in profit and $98 million in adjusted EBITDA.
For 2013, the Siding segment reported sales of $474[ph] million, profit of $86 million and adjusted EBITDA of $103 million.
In 2014, volumes of SmartSide increased 13% and prices increased 3%. The Siding segment produced 45 million square feet of OSB in 2014 as compared to 168 million square feet of OSB in 2013.
For the full year, the Siding segment was negatively impacted by log shortages. We estimate of the business loss 88 days or 53.8 million square feet of production due to those logs shortages. We estimate the impact of these log shortages in operating income and adjusted EBITDA with just over $10 million for the year.
Please turn to Slide 3 of the presentation, which shows the results for our Engineered Wood Products segment. This segment includes I-Joist, Laminated lumber, laminated veneer lumber and other related products. This segment also includes the sale of I-Joist and LVL products produced by the Abitibi joint venture or under a sales arrangement with Murphy Plywood.
In past quarters, we've included log sales from our licenses in this segment. But beginning this quarter and going forward, these sales and operating income and adjusted EBITDA are being recorded as part of the Other Building Products category. The Other Building Products category includes log sales from other nonoperating mills. All prior periods have been adjusted.
The impact in EWP's results on an annual basis has been between $1 million and $1.5 million of adjusted EBITDA in each of the last 3 years. The Engineered Wood Products segment reported net sales of $66 million in the fourth quarter of 2014, down slightly from the fourth quarter of 2013. The segment's operating loss in the fourth quarter of 2014 was $6 million as compared to a loss of $4 million in the fourth quarter of 2013. For the fourth quarter of 2014, adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations declined to a negative $4 million as compared to breakeven in the fourth quarter of 2013.
Volumes of I-Joist were down 9%, while volumes of LVL and LSL were down 3% compared to the same quarter last year. Pricing was up 3% in I-Joist and 5% in LVL/LSL reflecting price increases in all products.
For 2014, Engineered Wood Products reported net sales of $281 million as compared to $250 million in 2013, 12% increase. Sales volumes were up 6% in I-Joist and 9% and LVL and LSL. For 2014, Engineered Wood Products -- in 2014 Engineered Wood Products recorded an operating loss of $14 million and reported breakeven adjusted EBITDA as compared to a loss of $15[ph] million and negative EBITDA of $2 million for 2013.
Moving to Slide 8 of the presentation. For the quarter, our South American segment recorded sales of $36 million as compared to $41 million in the fourth quarter of 2013. Operating income is $3 million in the fourth quarter of 2014 compared to $2 million in the fourth quarter 2013. South America's adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $5 million for the fourth quarter of 2013, which is comparable to the fourth quarter of 2013.
Volumes in Chile were up 16% and lower by 27% in Brazil compared to the same quarter last year. Sales volume increased in Chile primarily by increased demand, offset by lower exports.
In Brazil, the lower volume was primarily due to reduced exports to the far east market. Pricing was down 16% in Chile and down 6% in Brazil. In local currency Chile's pricing is 5% lower compared to the same quarter in 2013 due to continued pricing pressure from North American imports. And Brazil recorded a 1% improvement in pricing in local currency.
For the full year of 2014, South America recorded net sales of $150 million, profit of $11 million and adjusted EBITDA of $20 million. For 2013, South America recorded net sales of $172 million, profit of $20 million and adjusted EBITDA of $31 million.
Total selling, general and administrative costs were $41 million in the fourth quarter of 2014 compared to $47 million in the same quarter in 2013. For the full year of 2014, selling, general and administrative costs were about flat between the periods at about $150 million. For the quarter, the reduction in SG&A cost is primarily related to lower incentive compensation.
Now please turn to Slide 9 of the presentation where we announced that as of December 31, 2014, we have cash, cash equivalents, investments and restricted cash of $548 million. Working capital of $778 million, net cash of $177 million. In addition to the cash on our balance sheet, we have $200 million of availability on our credit facility. Capital expenditures for the year were $80 million.
 Capital expenditures for 2015 are expected to be approximately $130 million of which around $80 million relates to our growth project, such as the siding mill conversion and the mill. And we did not repurchase any shares of LP stock during this quarter.
Now I'll turn the call over to Curt for his comments.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sallie, for the review of the fourth quarter and the full year. My comments today will focus on our accomplishments and challenges during the last year, talk about the current state of the housing market and provide you with my views on what is
componenttext:
Thank you, Sallie, for the review of the fourth quarter and the full year. My comments today will focus on our accomplishments and challenges during the last year, talk about the current state of the housing market and provide you with my views on what is ahead for us in 2015. I will conclude by discussing the executive leadership changes that we announced this morning.
From a safety perspective, LP had a total incident rate of 0.35 for 2014, the lowest level in LP's history. This is the ninth year in a row that our total incident rate has been below 1.0. In addition, we completed all of our capital work in 2014 without single recordable injury to any of the many, many contractors that we used on site, truly remarkable performance.
For the year, housing starts were just over 1 million, led by a strong fourth quarter performance. However, this is only about a 9% increase compared to the beginning of the year forecast of a 20% plus increase. This shortfall put pressure on OSB pricing all year that resulted in north-central 716's pricing between $71 per 1,000 square feet lower than 2013, quite a disappointment for us.
In our Siding business, we had record shipments of SmartSide for the third year in a row. This success led us to convert all production at Hayward to Siding and to make the decision to accelerate the conversion of our Swan Valley, Manitoba OSB mill siding production. We expect this to be operational early in the fourth quarter of this year.
In Engineered Wood, we again had record shipments of Laminated Strand Lumber, products and higher volumes of both I-Joist and LVL than in 2013.
South America, weaker economies in both Chile and Brazil, plus the stronger U.S. dollar, reduced results, but we were still profitable in both these operations.
That leaves me a few comments on housing market. U.S. housing starts in December were at 1.089 million units with single-family starts at their highest level in 6.5 years. In addition, housing starts on both October and November were revised upward.
Housing permits were slightly below starts in December at 1.028 million. The average 30-year mortgage rate for the week ending January 23 was at 3.66, the lowest level since the spike in rates in May of 2013.
Last month, I attended the International Builders Show in Las Vegas. The attendance was very strong with an estimate of 125,000 attendees. From the supplier perspective, I'd say there was a universal caution as we were all caught off guard by the slow pace of the housing recovery in 2014. Most are using around 1.1 million housing start as a base assumption. Among the builders, I'd say there was more optimism around housing activity, but the express concerns the number of various: Cost and ability of prime lots, availability of construction labor and upward pressure on labor cost, the cost of building products and margin pressure as the ability to raise prices aggressively has dissipated.
Just last night, I returned from the Policy Advisory Board meeting of the hardware joint center -- housing study that was held in Washington, D.C. over the past 2 days. This is a group from all facets of the housing industry, builders, developers, producers, distributors, realtors, government agencies that support housing, banks and other financial institutions. I'm pleased to say that the general tenor of the meeting was the most positive in 5 years. The optimism was broad based, but the most discussed item was the expected return of the first-time home buyer due to a variety of factors. Sallie nointed household formations have been at extremely low level for much of the great recession. These number shot up in the fourth quarter to 3x what they've been averaging over the last 3 years.
Job growth and wage increases from an improving economy gave much of the credit for this.
On the financing side, the lowering of premiums on mortgage insurance, the reemergence of the 3% down payment loans and more favorable credit standards are making financing more available for first-time home buyer.
At the meeting, there's also a discussions are trying to assess the impact of falling oil prices on housing and it appears to be a mixed bag. In the oil-producing areas, it doesn't appear that housing activity has slowed, but there are certainly a lot of talk about the timing of beginning new housing projects.
Lower fuel prices are adding to consumer confidence, which should accelerate household formation, a precursor to the first-time home sale or apartment rental.
As and aside, we do expect to have lower raw materials cost out of our operations due to lower oil pricing, primarily resins and energy. Last December when we put our 2015 budget together, we estimated that the savings due to lower oil prices in the range of $25 million to $30 million. Today, with oil prices hovering just north of $50 a barrel, our estimated savings are in the $40 million to $50 million range.
In other markets, the National Association of Homebuilding Remodeling index had a record level in the fourth quarter of 2014. The Hardware Joint Center for Housing Studies just released their emerging trends in the remodeling market where they concluded that this market will continue to strengthen.
For the strong U.S. dollar, we don't see exports returning anytime soon to North America.
For 2015 and 2016, we agree with the forecasters that housing is going to continue to get better. The consensus forecast for housing starts in 2015 now stands at 1.19 million and 1.426 million in 2016, a 10% increase this year, followed by a 20% increase next year. I'll take that. As I mentioned in our last call, we're using 1.1 million as our 2015 base forecast.
OSB pricing is critically important to us and our financial performance demonstrated last year. Clearly, pricing was short of expectations in 2014 as new production that came online in anticipation of higher housing activity led to an imbalance between supply and demand.
While we don't provide guidance on earnings or OSB prices, we do use force economic advisers as a primary forecasting source. For 2015, they see an increase of about 8% in OSB prices and a further 14% increase in 2016.
We do see the Canadian dollar below the $0.90 level for 2015. To put this in perspective, the change in the exchange rate in 2014 compared to 2013 improved our results by about $14 million.
In the near term, we have several important projects on the growth agenda. We've been on allocation on our Siding business for several months due to low shortages and cost production shortfalls. We've been working diligently to put log into these mills so we can operate it without interruption. If nature cooperates a bit, I think this will happen.
In addition, we kicked off an accelerated project to convert our Sun Valley, Manitoba OSB mill production early in the fourth quarter. We have further capital projects under development to add capacity or capabilities as our other Siding mills to meet customer demand, having available siding capacity ahead of demand is a very high priority.
South America, we have submitted our environmental permits and have an initial comments back for our third mill in Chile, and we have started the detailed engineering to be ready to begin construction when the permits are approved. We believe that this will be sometime around the end of the summer.
While we always like housing to recover more quickly, we are pleased with our positioning in the market and we stand ready to serve the increased housing market activity.
Before I turn over to Sallie for questions and answer, I do want to take a few minutes to discuss the management changes that we announced this morning. The good news is these announcements is that we have a broad and deep bench within LP to assume important roles. The bad news is that we will be losing 2 very talented executives and good friends to retirement. Here's the summary of the changes: Rick Olszewski, EVP of sales and marketing at South America, will be retiring at the end of March of this year. As Rick demonstrates, Rick is both the Senior Sales and Marketing executive for LP and executive in charge of our South American operations.
For the first responsibility, Rick will be replaced by Mike Sims, our current VP of OSB Sales for the new title of Senior VP, Sales and Marketing. Mike has over 30 years of experience in the selling and marketing of building products and has held a senior role with LP since we acquired ABTco. in 1999. Because of the increased role that South American LP's growth plans, I will be taking over Rick's role in South America's Frederick Price, President of LP's South America will be reporting directly to me.
Jason Ringbloom has held a variety of sales roles with increasing responsibility over the years. He will take Mike Sims spot as VP of OSB sales.
Jeff Wagner, our long-term EVP and GM of OSB, and I have been talking about his retirement plans for some time and decided that Jeff will leave his full-time employment with LP around the middle of this year. In the meantime, Jeff will report to me and assume responsibility for an important internal LP project to get better growth and innovation. As we know, we can't rely solely on housing recovery.
Brad Southern, a long-time LP officer and currently the Senior Vice President and General Manager of our Siding business, will assume Jeff's responsibility as EVP and General Manager of OSB.  [indiscernible] creates more cascading.
Brian Luoma, another longtime LP employee and currently, Senior Vice President, GM of Engineered Wood business, will replace Brad and become EVP and GM of siding.
Neil Sherman, currently our VP of Procurement and Logistics, will take Brian's position become Senior Vice President and GM of EWP.
Finally, Mike Blosser, LP's VP of EH Forestry will once again have Neil's responsibilities to his portfolio.
While it seems like a lot of change at once, we were able to make all these moves internally as a result of the talent pool within LP and our robust succession planning process. I'm fully confident that each of these changes will bring a new perspective to position and will allow our executive management to acquire new skills that will allow for increased responsibility in the future.
I want to publicly thank Jeff for the many contributions he made to LP over his 35-year plus career with the company and Rick for bringing sales and marketing to the forefront of what's historically a manufacturing company in his 8.5 years with LP.
Now, I'll turn it back to Sallie for questions

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you very much, Curt. Joyce, we'd like to go to the queue for questions, please.
componenttext: All right. Thank you very much, Curt. Joyce, we'd like to go to the queue for questions, please.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from the line of Mark Connelly with CLSA.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from the line of Mark Connelly with CLSA.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two things, your comment about Jeff, in particular, peaks my interest. We've talked over the years, recently we've talked about CanExel and Siding. But in the past, we've talked about radiant barriers and other value add, is this a new initiative on your
componenttext: Two things, your comment about Jeff, in particular, peaks my interest. We've talked over the years, recently we've talked about CanExel and Siding. But in the past, we've talked about radiant barriers and other value add, is this a new initiative on your part? Or is there just more coming through the pipe that needs to be managed?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: It actually is a new initiative. As you know, we tried to grow through acquisition last year and it became clear that, that wasn't going to come to the forefront. We did engage in outside group to help us with our growth and innovation capabilities. We've
componenttext: It actually is a new initiative. As you know, we tried to grow through acquisition last year and it became clear that, that wasn't going to come to the forefront. We did engage in outside group to help us with our growth and innovation capabilities. We've done a lot of it over the years, but this just gives us a much more disciplined approach. And so what we've done is Rick and Neil Sherman actually headed up that project for about the end of last summer until today. Jeff will be taking over the responsibility probably until the middle of the year. And what it does do for us, Mark, is it just gives us much more information on the market sizing or what the geographic opportunities might be, so that should accelerate the growth of some new products, plus increase our penetration and geographies where we should be more successful than where we have been.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: That sounds outstanding. Just 1 more question, given the time you've spent with builders and other folks lately, I'm just curious if you see anything that suggests that we're going to see a shift in the rate of adoption or the rate of penetration of Engin
componenttext: That sounds outstanding. Just 1 more question, given the time you've spent with builders and other folks lately, I'm just curious if you see anything that suggests that we're going to see a shift in the rate of adoption or the rate of penetration of Engineered Wood Products over this housing recovery? We've seen shifts in size, we've seen the shift to multifamily, I'm just wondering if you seeing anything that makes you think we're going to see some acceleration.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's going to fall housing growth, I don't think you're going to see increase penetration. A number of things have happened there. I think, in the past, we've talked about the lumber going from British Columbia into China. That's slowing a little
componenttext: I think it's going to fall housing growth, I don't think you're going to see increase penetration. A number of things have happened there. I think, in the past, we've talked about the lumber going from British Columbia into China. That's slowing a little bit which means there's more lumber coming out of British Columbia and into the U.S. to help support this market. So we think that the market share really haven't changed all that much even during the recession, between the Engineered Wood and Solid Wood. It's going to be about the same.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Gail Glazerman with UBS.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Gail Glazerman with UBS.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could give a little bit more color on what went on in Engineered Wood in the quarter? Volumes were pretty good, I guess, there was some references kind of destocking. How much of the effects of seasonal versus something else? And an
componenttext: I was wondering if you could give a little bit more color on what went on in Engineered Wood in the quarter? Volumes were pretty good, I guess, there was some references kind of destocking. How much of the effects of seasonal versus something else? And any signs of that reversing in the first quarter?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Gail. Fundamentally, we do believe that there was a fair amount of destocking that occurred in the fourth quarter and that really highlighted itself in the capacity utilization for that business, which was down in the fourth quarter. And we are begi
componenttext: Sure, Gail. Fundamentally, we do believe that there was a fair amount of destocking that occurred in the fourth quarter and that really highlighted itself in the capacity utilization for that business, which was down in the fourth quarter. And we are beginning to see some improvement in the first quarter in orders in EWP. And we're having some wins in certain markets in EWP as well.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And in terms of the inflation comments on oil. I just wondering, are there any offsets, I guess, specifically, are you currently seeing any relief on the log cost in the last any issues with freight and logistics? Or is that also -- is that a benefi
componenttext: Okay. And in terms of the inflation comments on oil. I just wondering, are there any offsets, I guess, specifically, are you currently seeing any relief on the log cost in the last any issues with freight and logistics? Or is that also -- is that a benefit incorporated in the oil guidance?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. On the transportation side, we actually see, this is an opportunity for both railroads and truckers who raised their rates. So we're actually not seeing much reduction in our freight cost. In fact, we could see a little bit higher pricing, particular
componenttext: Yes. On the transportation side, we actually see, this is an opportunity for both railroads and truckers who raised their rates. So we're actually not seeing much reduction in our freight cost. In fact, we could see a little bit higher pricing, particularly coming out of the Canadian railroads because of price increases they put in place, plus some of the changes they've made to their AMB routing, which is, of course, passed to increase our distribution channel with more railroads and other methods to support our customer. So we're not seeing that on the transportation side. On the log side, we have not seen any relief in the latest pricing. We see a little bit more availability but not on the pricing. In the south, we do expect log pricing to come off[ph] a little bit, but not significantly.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And in light of the decline in the Canadian dollar, I'm just wondering, are you rethinking or have you made any adjustments to your operating footprint, maybe increasing production out of the West Coast and flowing down in the U.S. out of Canada flo
componenttext: Okay. And in light of the decline in the Canadian dollar, I'm just wondering, are you rethinking or have you made any adjustments to your operating footprint, maybe increasing production out of the West Coast and flowing down in the U.S. out of Canada flowing in the U.S.?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: We keep looking and one of the and I mentioned in my earlier comments that the export market has dried up. We actually shipped a fair amount of wood both the Far East and to Russia out of our Canadian operations and that really has come to a standstill wi
componenttext: We keep looking and one of the and I mentioned in my earlier comments that the export market has dried up. We actually shipped a fair amount of wood both the Far East and to Russia out of our Canadian operations and that really has come to a standstill with a strong U.S. dollar plus the havoc happening going on in Russia. So we need to replace that volume somewhere else. And as a result, we have taken some downtime this quarter because of whether a weaker demand. But we continue to look at the Canadian operations as a good source of products in the future. The only asset that we have that is not running is our mill in Québec. And we do not have any plans this year to start that mill backup.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And with pricing where it is, would you -- could you envision seeing any kind of incremental actual multiples versus downtime?
componenttext: Okay. And with pricing where it is, would you -- could you envision seeing any kind of incremental actual multiples versus downtime?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't envision that because I do believe that with the market, even the 9% increase, which is our base forecast versus the 18% or 19% that's in the forecast, would say there's a demand for that wood. But we would do what we have done in the past a
componenttext: Well, I don't envision that because I do believe that with the market, even the 9% increase, which is our base forecast versus the 18% or 19% that's in the forecast, would say there's a demand for that wood. But we would do what we have done in the past as we will take market curtailments as we see weaker demand. Sallie mentioned in the fourth quarter, we took 136 days of downtime and we're currently taking downtime on our mills right now.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon with Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon with Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question is on the -- your CapEx, and I might have missed the number, if you gave us a guide. But could you remind us what that number looks like for '15? And just gives us some direction nuance for '16? And I know you mentioned the product -- the p
componenttext: First question is on the -- your CapEx, and I might have missed the number, if you gave us a guide. But could you remind us what that number looks like for '15? And just gives us some direction nuance for '16? And I know you mentioned the product -- the project in Chile, but are there other definable projects that you're still working -- that you would be working on in '15 and '16?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Chip. Our guidance on CapEx for 2015 is $130 million. $50 million of that represents what we typically talk about in terms of maintenance. The remaining $80 million relates to projects like turning to our Manitoba OSB mill converting that into a Sid
componenttext: Sure, Chip. Our guidance on CapEx for 2015 is $130 million. $50 million of that represents what we typically talk about in terms of maintenance. The remaining $80 million relates to projects like turning to our Manitoba OSB mill converting that into a Siding mill, as well as plans for the third Chilean mill. So if we -- the expectation right now is that Salon would be fully converted in 2015, the Chilean mill will look to see what's going on in the economy and think about the timing on that, but we expect some expenditures in 2015 and that will move into 2016 and then we'll continue to think about opportunities for growth in our Siding business at that business continues to grow.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chip, the only color I would give on that is as we look into our 2015 or 2016, there are a series of additional projects to match the capabilities of our Siding mills with market demand. And so we will be rolling those out through '16, but that's totally
componenttext: Chip, the only color I would give on that is as we look into our 2015 or 2016, there are a series of additional projects to match the capabilities of our Siding mills with market demand. And so we will be rolling those out through '16, but that's totally based on the demand for the product and those are well thought out and great return projects. The only other 1 is we have been focused on our product, particularly for multifamily. And the contractor that we use were currently out of capacity. They are also determining what we do and that may be a modest investment that we will make internally for fire retard OSB and fire retard I-Joist.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. Just a bit of a sort of a little bit of feel for things, if you kind of go back a few years, I know that we haven't had very many good years in the last 5, let's say. But I do recall that in, for example, in 2000 and I think it was '12, we're act
componenttext: Got you. Just a bit of a sort of a little bit of feel for things, if you kind of go back a few years, I know that we haven't had very many good years in the last 5, let's say. But I do recall that in, for example, in 2000 and I think it was '12, we're actually -- sorry, 2013 was a pretty decent year for OSB. And I know that year you made $86 million in Siding, then you have some OSB inside of that segment. Last year, you almost -- I mean, you only made $6 million less. You went from 86 to 80, when OSB completely fell down. So if we kind of strip out the OSB profits in '13, I mean, how -- what's -- I mean, it appears on the surface to have a big swing upward in '14 in Siding or at least an up year, even though it was down for OSB, is that fair?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: That is very, Chip. In fact, there's probably about a $9 million difference between Siding profits in 2013, we reported in the -- our OSB profits in the Siding segment. So it was a $9 million swing. So if you took 2013 down, you would see a pretty good gr
componenttext: That is very, Chip. In fact, there's probably about a $9 million difference between Siding profits in 2013, we reported in the -- our OSB profits in the Siding segment. So it was a $9 million swing. So if you took 2013 down, you would see a pretty good growth in the Siding business. And as I've said, we did have record volumes in 2014.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Bill Hoffman of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Bill Hoffman of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Curt, can you just talk a little bit more sort of how you're planning for what's the downside case here where warehousing doesn't improve like you're thinking and talking even with some of these positive signs from an operating standpoint, just really eit
componenttext: Curt, can you just talk a little bit more sort of how you're planning for what's the downside case here where warehousing doesn't improve like you're thinking and talking even with some of these positive signs from an operating standpoint, just really either take out of the system or to better balance the market so you get somewhat of a better pricing environment?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, what we're doing today, Bill, is what we did last year. As we saw demand fall, let me just back up a minute, so just to remind everyone, when we figure out our OSB business at the beginning of the year, we do contract with our customers for
componenttext: Well, I think, what we're doing today, Bill, is what we did last year. As we saw demand fall, let me just back up a minute, so just to remind everyone, when we figure out our OSB business at the beginning of the year, we do contract with our customers for volume. It doesn't affect the pricing in general, but we contract volume. So with the home centers, we contract a certain amount of volume with some of the big dealers and some of the others. So our contracted volume last year was around 80% and that's about the same this year. So when we take downtime, what really what we're playing with is that 20% that's open market wood because we have commitments for the other 80%. Does that make sense?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the downtime that we're taking is that we don't see a demand for the open market wood then we adjust our production schedule to satisfy the demand that we do have from our customers.
componenttext: So the downtime that we're taking is that we don't see a demand for the open market wood then we adjust our production schedule to satisfy the demand that we do have from our customers.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. I guess, what I'm asking is, does it make sense to even do a temporary facility for a year to help bring this market back and the balance 120%[ph]?
componenttext: Right. I guess, what I'm asking is, does it make sense to even do a temporary facility for a year to help bring this market back and the balance 120%[ph]?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, so far, we believe the best from an economic perspective is to run it the way that we're running it because when you take a mill down, that means you fire all the people, you get rid of the customers that you have contracted that mill with and then
componenttext: Well, so far, we believe the best from an economic perspective is to run it the way that we're running it because when you take a mill down, that means you fire all the people, you get rid of the customers that you have contracted that mill with and then you have the start-up costs that go way that.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just the other question, on the log outages that you experienced in the fourth quarter, is that situation pretty much rectified itself at this point?
componenttext: Okay. And then just the other question, on the log outages that you experienced in the fourth quarter, is that situation pretty much rectified itself at this point?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say, it's better, but it's still touch and go. And this is really in the region where they've had some weather issues, they've had some infrastructure issues, where there has been competing demand from the pulp mills in that area. So we're actuall
componenttext: I would say, it's better, but it's still touch and go. And this is really in the region where they've had some weather issues, they've had some infrastructure issues, where there has been competing demand from the pulp mills in that area. So we're actually bringing wood in from farther away or paying more for it.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question come from the line of Mark Wilde with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question come from the line of Mark Wilde with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wonder if we could talk, first, about just OSB and really bridging the difference between year-over-year decline in EBITDA in that sector. You've pointed, I think, to price being about $27 million of that decline and it was a total of about $38 million.
componenttext: I wonder if we could talk, first, about just OSB and really bridging the difference between year-over-year decline in EBITDA in that sector. You've pointed, I think, to price being about $27 million of that decline and it was a total of about $38 million. So the other $11 million, cat, is that downtime? Or what else might be in that number?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's downtime. That's the impact of the higher downtime some cost.
componenttext: Yes, that's downtime. That's the impact of the higher downtime some cost.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes cost, yes, yes, yes. And I'm just curious, you were actually down year-over-year on volumes in OSB in the fourth quarter. But most of the housing indicators, as Curt mentioned, are up in the fourth quarter. So how do we get our heads around that delta
componenttext: Yes cost, yes, yes, yes. And I'm just curious, you were actually down year-over-year on volumes in OSB in the fourth quarter. But most of the housing indicators, as Curt mentioned, are up in the fourth quarter. So how do we get our heads around that delta?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Mark, as you will recall, we actually produced more in the third quarter. So we sold it to other inventory.
componenttext: Well, Mark, as you will recall, we actually produced more in the third quarter. So we sold it to other inventory.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. That's fine. Just turning to the Latin American business, I was just curious about how you see the impacts of the big decline in both the Chilean peso and the Brazilian real playing out over the next year in that business?
componenttext: Okay, all right. That's fine. Just turning to the Latin American business, I was just curious about how you see the impacts of the big decline in both the Chilean peso and the Brazilian real playing out over the next year in that business?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the most impact is on our results because we translated back into u.S. dollars. We sell those products sold in Chile in the Chilean pesos. So our costs and expenses are the same. In Brazil, we have a little bit of an export market -- a little bit mo
componenttext: Well, the most impact is on our results because we translated back into u.S. dollars. We sell those products sold in Chile in the Chilean pesos. So our costs and expenses are the same. In Brazil, we have a little bit of an export market -- a little bit more of an export market and that is typically in U.S. dollar. So they should benefit a little bit from that as we go forward.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: And if possible, going back to Chile, on the consequence of the higher U.S. dollar, a few of our competitors exporting down into Chile, which would help our Chilean operations from a demand point of view and pricing point of view.
componenttext: And if possible, going back to Chile, on the consequence of the higher U.S. dollar, a few of our competitors exporting down into Chile, which would help our Chilean operations from a demand point of view and pricing point of view.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Because I guess, when I listened to your comments on the fourth quarter, it seemed like things moved in an opposite direction from what I would've expected. You talked about more imports coming into the Chilean market and you talked about less export
componenttext: Yes. Because I guess, when I listened to your comments on the fourth quarter, it seemed like things moved in an opposite direction from what I would've expected. You talked about more imports coming into the Chilean market and you talked about less exports out of Brazil. And I would have thought, given the weakness in both of those currencies, that we would have seen less imports into Chile and more exports out of Brazil.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we're continuing to see export from the U.S. into the Chilean market, even with the U.S. dollar where it is and we're seeing that pricing pressure.
componenttext: So we're continuing to see export from the U.S. into the Chilean market, even with the U.S. dollar where it is and we're seeing that pricing pressure.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's not logical, Mark.
componenttext: It's not logical, Mark.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I almost used that D word if I didn't know better. I guess, the last question I had, Curt, was just on the EWP business and I just -- I wonder whether your strategy or your market position in EWP is due for a rethink at all?
componenttext: I almost used that D word if I didn't know better. I guess, the last question I had, Curt, was just on the EWP business and I just -- I wonder whether your strategy or your market position in EWP is due for a rethink at all?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as we do with all of our businesses, we look at our portfolio to figure out what makes the most sense. I think some of Sallie's comments may not picked up on it, but we did have a pretty significant series of design wins or wins with major customers
componenttext: Well, as we do with all of our businesses, we look at our portfolio to figure out what makes the most sense. I think some of Sallie's comments may not picked up on it, but we did have a pretty significant series of design wins or wins with major customers in the fourth quarter. So I do see that business picking up. And so we are seeing more activity in wood.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Is being in that business that, is there any connection between that businesses and the Siding business? Do you have any of the sales and support people that overlap? Or is that completely separate?
componenttext: Is being in that business that, is there any connection between that businesses and the Siding business? Do you have any of the sales and support people that overlap? Or is that completely separate?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The salespeople were up quite a bit. We do have specialists that support EWP because as you know, you need engineering expertise there. So those are specifically identified with EWP. But the general sales, sales are especially OSB, our Siding products and
componenttext: The salespeople were up quite a bit. We do have specialists that support EWP because as you know, you need engineering expertise there. So those are specifically identified with EWP. But the general sales, sales are especially OSB, our Siding products and engineered wood. So they are calling on the same customers, dealers, builders.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Last thing I would ask, Curt, we had some news about another OSB mill in East Texas. It's amazing to me given the difficulties that the market has gone through over the last 7, 8 years, including this last year that the people are talking about buil
componenttext: Okay. Last thing I would ask, Curt, we had some news about another OSB mill in East Texas. It's amazing to me given the difficulties that the market has gone through over the last 7, 8 years, including this last year that the people are talking about building more capacity. Any thoughts?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first, this is a privately-held enterprise and has made the announcement. And also if you think about it, with today's capacity given bringing back the 2 or 3 mills that are curtailed, we can support about 1.4 million to 1.5 million housing starts.
componenttext: Well, first, this is a privately-held enterprise and has made the announcement. And also if you think about it, with today's capacity given bringing back the 2 or 3 mills that are curtailed, we can support about 1.4 million to 1.5 million housing starts. So we get north of that, it only needs to be solution for additional capacity. Not that I'm thinking about it, but I'm just telling you what is thinking might be. And as I understand the announcement is that there were some economic development grants discussed, I don't think they were approved, but they were discussed. So I think he's getting ahead of it because if you think about it, he's got to get the site, which as far as I know, he doesn't, he's just got the economic development grant. On my [indiscernible], you got to get environmental permitting, you've got to order the equipment and you're going to do build it. So you're 3 to 4 years out. So if you think about it in that context, it's not totally wacky, plus it probably helps so you don't have to talk to shareholders.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Presumably, he still likes to get a return on his money.
componenttext: Presumably, he still likes to get a return on his money.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Weintraub of Buckingham Research Group.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Weintraub of Buckingham Research Group.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Curious, you mentioned that you got about 80% of your OSB volumes contracted last year and this year, is that relatively standard practice for the larger producers? Or are you an outlier in that regard, would you say?
componenttext: Curious, you mentioned that you got about 80% of your OSB volumes contracted last year and this year, is that relatively standard practice for the larger producers? Or are you an outlier in that regard, would you say?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know specifically what they do. But if you think about the home center business, we know what percentage we have. And for the rest of the home center businesses is supplied by our competitors. And Home Depot or Lowe's don't do anything by contract
componenttext: I don't know specifically what they do. But if you think about the home center business, we know what percentage we have. And for the rest of the home center businesses is supplied by our competitors. And Home Depot or Lowe's don't do anything by contracting. So I assume on the retail side that there's contracts in place. And I also assume the same thing on the big dealers. But I can't tell you specifically.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you have a very outsized position in Home Depot and Lowe's, would you say, relative to the competition?
componenttext: Do you have a very outsized position in Home Depot and Lowe's, would you say, relative to the competition?

componenttextpreview: I think our position is probably consistent with our market share.
componenttext: I think our position is probably consistent with our market share.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then switching to Siding for a minute, if you think about the impact of the log shortages, et cetera, do think that you were -- the opportunity cost on the market share is something that's lost? Do you think that inventory was pulled out of the
componenttext: Okay. And then switching to Siding for a minute, if you think about the impact of the log shortages, et cetera, do think that you were -- the opportunity cost on the market share is something that's lost? Do you think that inventory was pulled out of the channel to -- somewhere along the channel to make sure that demand was and so there's kind of capability for you to refill that channel? Or how should we think about the dynamics of how log shortages are impacting the Siding business?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think with the allocation that we went on, we made in our customer or customer loyalty. But effortful we had production, we lost that on another technology, inventories were adjusted. So that's why we have always ahead of siding from a capacity st
componenttext: Well, I think with the allocation that we went on, we made in our customer or customer loyalty. But effortful we had production, we lost that on another technology, inventories were adjusted. So that's why we have always ahead of siding from a capacity standpoint. And we feel bad about that, but we're doing everything we can to recapture that volume.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just lastly, one quick one, just trying to understand a little bit, you talked about the third mill in Chile as being part of the $130 million. It sounded though that you were still considering the exact timing of how you want to proceed there.
componenttext: Okay. And just lastly, one quick one, just trying to understand a little bit, you talked about the third mill in Chile as being part of the $130 million. It sounded though that you were still considering the exact timing of how you want to proceed there. Can you may be flush that out a little bit more for us?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we've had a third mill on the drawing board for a while in Chile, and then we have the very efficient in Brazil, we had the fall in copper pricing. So we are being very cognizant of what's going on in those economies. Now the other piece of this is
componenttext: Well, we've had a third mill on the drawing board for a while in Chile, and then we have the very efficient in Brazil, we had the fall in copper pricing. So we are being very cognizant of what's going on in those economies. Now the other piece of this is we are intending to supply other South American countries with this capacity. And as you probably know, Colombia's doing very well now, Peru is coming back. Argentina is a mess, but assuming they would change the government soon and that could come back. So on a timing perspective, it's going to be a year construction period. I think Sallie was the one hesitating a little bit. We expect to get the permitting by the end of the summer. But to higher thinking and I would agree with that, is if the Chilean economy remains in the doldrums, we might delay that a little bit.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: And presumably, if that happens and part of the $130 million get shifted to a later time period, is that the right way?
componenttext: And presumably, if that happens and part of the $130 million get shifted to a later time period, is that the right way?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's correct, that's correct.
componenttext: That's correct, that's correct.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015

componenttext: And we people talked $20 million or $30 million, or what type of order of magnitude?

componenttextpreview: It's probably in that range. I think the numbers are given before, as we talked this was a $50 million to $60 million project. And again it's a construction period of a year.
componenttext: It's probably in that range. I think the numbers are given before, as we talked this was a $50 million to $60 million project. And again it's a construction period of a year.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015

componenttext: So many of the questions have already been asked. But with respect to OSB, since it's now $20 per 1,000 square feet below 2014. Are we on track possibly for a worse year? Or do you think the higher volume and the lower raw materials will offset pricing?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: In answering your question, when I was at the Builder show or is it the [indiscernible], I talked to some of our distributors and said, what are your inventories like? I said, they're pretty lean because I get whatever I want right now, at a pretty low pr
componenttext: In answering your question, when I was at the Builder show or is it the [indiscernible], I talked to some of our distributors and said, what are your inventories like? I said, they're pretty lean because I get whatever I want right now, at a pretty low price. So what's going to happen in March and April if this does take off? And they all said, well, we're also worried about that. So we didn't see a little bit of affirming last Friday. I think for us, in certain regions, it did hit our floor pricing, so sub-lower floor pricing. And again, I think, ticked up a little bit last week. So we'll see.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015

componenttext: I guess, it's incumbent on all of us to look at the pricing beyond just north where we're so focused on. But you believe that the industry has in place sufficient capacity to satisfy 1.2 million starts in 2015? I mean, it seems like that's part of the problem as we've been excessively optimistic for a couple of years now on OSB demand.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think with what's running today, [indiscernible] 1.2 million, yes, I do believe that.
componenttext: Yes. I think with what's running today, [indiscernible] 1.2 million, yes, I do believe that.

componenttextpreview: Yes, that seems part of the problem? I mean, Clarke County is presumably up to full capacity at this stage?
componenttext: Yes, that seems part of the problem? I mean, Clarke County is presumably up to full capacity at this stage?

componenttext: We're meeting customer demand, Steve.

componenttext: Okay. And one final on, on log availability, I mean, I guess, you're getting a lot of snow in the Northeast this year but it's not a polar vortex, thank goodness. Are you laying in sufficient inventories in lake states that we won't have the repeat of the shortages last year?

componenttext: Well, I can't tell you there's a usually year. But typically, we see kind of the early March to mid-March is when you see an inflection point because that's when the dealers are putting their inventories for the building season.

componenttext: Okay. And just on Canadian dollar, I think, you mentioned $14 million benefit in 2014 versus 2013. If Canadian dollars stays at sort of where it is right now, just below 80, what are some benefits you expect in '15?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just last question on Siding, I haven't seen some updated stats for sort of Engineered Wood in the siding market and how that's growing in terms of market share. Do you have you any that you can update us with? And are you still taking share fro
componenttext: Okay. And just last question on Siding, I haven't seen some updated stats for sort of Engineered Wood in the siding market and how that's growing in terms of market share. Do you have you any that you can update us with? And are you still taking share from we vinyl and fiber cement, I guess, and some wood too?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that most recent study was a percipient study. Mike would have more details than I do. But we did take market share against other technologies. In fact, if you just took Siding business, it looks that were pretty much on track with Hardy in the se
componenttext: I think that most recent study was a percipient study. Mike would have more details than I do. But we did take market share against other technologies. In fact, if you just took Siding business, it looks that were pretty much on track with Hardy in the second half of the year. Hardy puts in their order for tile which really is a siding product. But if you took that out, Precipia actually gave us a stronger market share than we had thought. So good, it's a good place to be.

componenttext: Okay, got that. And then on the inflation side, what's your normal labor inflation run in the business on an annual basis? And at this point in the cycle, are you thinking about you offset that through volume and then price? Or are there productivity initiatives in place to be able to just offset the normal labor inflation in the business?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, typically, we hold to what is local market determination, where our plants are. That has been running in the last couple of years at about 3% o the wage side. And then on the benefit side, we actually have pretty good experience on our healthcare la
componenttext: Well, typically, we hold to what is local market determination, where our plants are. That has been running in the last couple of years at about 3% o the wage side. And then on the benefit side, we actually have pretty good experience on our healthcare last couple of years. So we haven't seen as much of an impact on the healthcare. So I think, a 3% to 4% number is probably about where it's been. On the productivity, as you know, we're a Lean Six Sigma company. And last year, we've got a 5.8:1 return on our investment in Lean Six Sigma. So we really use that as our continuous improvement approach to the mill. So most of that actually have a wage increase could offset with productivity or the Lean Six Sigma.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015

componenttext: Okay, got it, Curt. On the EWP side, there's 2 public competitors out there. I'm just looking at their numbers, 1 explicitly reports the numbers. The other, you can essentially back into the numbers. Just the profitability, both the absolute level and the year-on-year improvement was just material head where you guys are showing the numbers. I mean, fundamentally, is there a difference in the businesses?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: There is one. I talked to it last time. So let me tell you again what it is. In our business, we have owned facilities and then we have partnership facilities and we have a sales arrangement. So for instance, in LVL, probably 1/3 of our volume, we buy fro
componenttext: There is one. I talked to it last time. So let me tell you again what it is. In our business, we have owned facilities and then we have partnership facilities and we have a sales arrangement. So for instance, in LVL, probably 1/3 of our volume, we buy from Murphy Plywood. And what we get there is we get a sales margin, we don't get a manufacturing margin. But we also have no investment in the planning equipment. In our I-Joist business, probably 70% of our I-Joists has come out the 2 joint venture mills that we have with Abitibi. And there, again we get the sales margin and we get half of the manufacturing margin, but not all of it. So if you were to look at on our return on assets, we look really. Really good. But if you look at that just on the margin, we don't capture the full margin either on those I-Joist out of JV, only half of it. And in the Murphy, we just get a sales margin. So there's the difference in the operating model and we don't own and operate all of our own facilities. But we adjust for that, if you look at the sales pricing between the 2 other public entities, our sales pricing is right on top of maybe even a little bit ahead and our manufacturing costs are right on top of them. But it's the manufacturing margin that we don't enjoy on the Murphy Plywood and only half of it on the I-Joist.
