headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q4 2014 Louisiana-Pacific Corporation Earnings Conference Call. My name is Joyce, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q4 2014 Louisiana-Pacific Corporation Earnings Conference Call. My name is Joyce, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes.
I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Sallie Bailey, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Ms. Bailey would then the call over to Curt Stevens, Chief Executive Officer. Please proceed.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Well, thank you very much, Joyce, and good morning, and good afternoon for those of you on the East Coast. We thank you for joining our conference call today to discuss LP's financial results for the fourth quarter of 2014 and the year ended Decemb
componenttext:
Great. Well, thank you very much, Joyce, and good morning, and good afternoon for those of you on the East Coast. We thank you for joining our conference call today to discuss LP's financial results for the fourth quarter of 2014 and the year ended December 31, 2014.
I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer. And with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's Chief Executive Officer; as well as Mike Kinney and Becky Barckley, our primary Investor Relations contact.
I'll begin the discussion with a review of the financial results for the fourth quarter of 2014 and the full year. It will be followed by some comments on the performance of the individual segments and selected balance sheet items.
After I finished my comments, Curt will discuss the general market environment in which LP has been operating and provide his perspective on our operating results and give some thoughts on the outlook.
As we have done in the past, we have opened up this call to the public and we are doing a webcast. That webcast can be accessed at www.lpcorp.com. Additionally, to help with the discussion, we have provided a presentation with supplemental information that should be reviewed in conjunction with the earnings release. I will be referencing these slides in my comments this morning. We filed an 8-K this morning with some supplemental information and expect to file our Form 10-K before the end of the month.
I want to remind all the participants about the forward-looking statements comment on Slide 2 of the presentation. Please also be aware of the discussion of our use of non-GAAP financial information included on Slide 3 of the presentation. The appendix attached to the presentation has some of the necessary reconciliation that has been supplemented by the Form 8-K filing we made this morning. Rather than reading these 2 statements, I incorporate them with this reference.
2014 was a challenging year for LP. Housing starts grew to just over 1 million starts or 9% higher than 2013. Single-family housing starts grew 5% year-over-year. At LP, we remain focused on activities which are in our control and continue to invest in our future, so we are prepared when U.S. housing starts return to its historical levels.
Moving to Slide 4 of the presentation for a discussion of the fourth quarter 2014 and the full year 2014 result. We reported net sales of $454 million for the fourth quarter of 2014, a 5% decline from the net sales of $480 million reported for the fourth quarter of 2013.
In the fourth quarter of 2014, we recorded net loss of $43 million or $0.30 per diluted share. In the fourth quarter of 2013, we reported a net loss of $20 million or $0.15 per diluted share. The adjusted loss from continuing operations for the quarter is $32 million or $0.23 per share based upon the normalized tax rate of 35%. This compares to a loss of $9 million or $0.06 per share in the fourth quarter of 2013.
Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was negative $17 million in the quarter compared to positive EBITDA of $24 million in the fourth quarter of 2013.
On a year-to-date basis, we recorded $1 billion of net sales, a loss of $75 million and a loss per share of $0.53 as compared to net sales of $2.1 billion, net income of $177 million and earnings per share of $1.23 for the full year of 2013.
On a non-GAAP basis, we recorded an adjusted loss from continuing operations of $60 million, a loss per share of $0.42 and adjusted EBITDA of $44 million for the full year of 2014. In 2013, we recorded $121 million (sic) [ $129 million ] of adjusted income from continuing operations, earnings per share of $0.90, and adjusted EBITDA of $330 million. The most significant headwind experienced by LP in 2014 was a 26% decrease in OSB pricing. The lower OSB price impacted operating income and adjusted EBITDA by $298 million, which is more than the year-over-year decrease in adjusted EBITDA.
I will now move to Slide 5 and our view of our segment results, beginning with OSB. LP's OSB segment recorded an operating loss of $29 million and $203 million of sales in the quarter compared to operating profit of $7 million and $230 million of sales in the fourth quarter of 2013. For the quarter, we're reporting negative adjusted EBITDA of $15 million compared to positive EBITDA of $27 million (sic) [ $23 million ] in the fourth quarter of 2013. We had a 1% decrease in volume, and pricing for OSB was up 12% over the fourth quarter of 2013.
We took 136 down days during the quarter, which equates to approximately 200 million square feet. Most of the down days were market related. Capacity utilization of our operating mills for the quarter was approximately 77%.
For the full year, OSB had an operating loss of $53 million compared to income of $230 million in 2013. Adjusted EBITDA in 2014 was $4 million compared to $285 million in 2013. The impact of lower OSB pricing between the years was $298 million.
Slide 6 reports the results of the Siding business. This segment includes our SmartSide and CanExel siding product. The Siding segment reported sales of $141 million in the fourth quarter of 2014, an increase of 2% from $138 million reported in the fourth quarter of 2013. The Siding segment reported operating income of $14 million compared to $16 million in the fourth quarter of 2013, and adjusted EBITDA of $19 million as compared to $20 million in the same quarter of 2013.
During the quarter, the Siding segment did not produce any OSB compared to the fourth quarter of 2013 when the Siding segment produced 45 million square feet of OSB.
For the quarter, SmartSide average sales price were up 4% and volumes also increased 4%. Volume increased in our SmartSide siding line due to continued penetration in several key focused markets, including retail, repair/remodel and shed. However, the Siding segment was negatively impacted by log shortages in the Lake States. We estimate that the Siding business lost 45 days of downtime or 27 million square feet of production in the fourth quarter. We estimate that the gross margin on the lost sales along with a higher unabsorbed mill costs decreased adjusted EBITDA by $5 million for the quarter.
CanExel prices were down slightly in U.S. dollars or up 6% in Canadian dollars. Canada is CanExel's primary market. Volumes were up 11% in the quarter due to higher Canadian and international demand. And on a year-to-date basis, the Siding segment recorded $617 million in sale, $80 million in profit and $98 million in adjusted EBITDA. For 2013, the Siding segment reported sales of $574 million, profit of $86 million and adjusted EBITDA of $103 million.
In 2014, volumes of SmartSide increased 13% and prices increased 3%. The Siding segment produced 45 million square feet of OSB in 2014 as compared to 168 million square feet of OSB in 2013.
For the full year, the Siding segment was negatively impacted by log shortages. We estimate that the business lost 88 days or 53.8 million square feet of production due to the log shortage. We estimate the impact of these log shortages in operating income and adjusted EBITDA with just over $10 million for the year.
Please turn to Slide 3 (sic) [ Slide 3 ] of the presentation, which shows the results for our Engineered Wood Products segment. This segment includes I-Joist, Laminated Strand Lumber, Laminated Veneer Lumber, plus other related products. This segment also includes the sale of I-Joist and LVL products produced by the Abitibi joint venture or under a sales arrangement with Murphy Plywood.
In past quarters, we've included log sales from our Malakwa forest licenses in this segment. But beginning this quarter and going forward, these sales and the associated operating income and adjusted EBITDA are being recorded as part of the Other Building Products category. The Other Building Products category includes log sales from other nonoperating mills. All prior periods have been adjusted.
The impact on EWP's results on an annual basis has been between $1 million and $1.5 million of adjusted EBITDA in each of the last 3 years. The Engineered Wood Products segment reported sales of $66 million in the fourth quarter of 2014, down slightly from the fourth quarter of 2013. The segment's operating loss in the fourth quarter of 2014 was $6 million as compared to a loss of $4 million in the fourth quarter of 2013. For the fourth quarter of 2014, adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations declined to a negative $4 million as compared to breakeven in the fourth quarter of 2013.
Volumes of I-Joist were down 9%, while volumes of LVL and LSL were down 3% compared to the same quarter last year. Pricing was up 3% in I-Joist and 5% in LVL and LSL reflecting price increases in all products.
For 2014, Engineered Wood Products reported net sales of $281 million as compared to $250 million in 2013, a 12% increase. Sales volumes were up 6% in I-Joist, and 9% in LVL and LSL. For 2014, Engineered Wood Products -- in 2014, Engineered Wood Products recorded an operating loss of $14 million and reported breakeven adjusted EBITDA as compared to a loss of $15 million and negative EBITDA of $2 million for 2013.
Moving to Slide 8 of the presentation. For the quarter, our South American segment recorded sales of $36 million as compared to $41 million in the fourth quarter of 2013. Operating income is $3 million in the fourth quarter of 2014 compared to $2 million in the fourth quarter of 2013. South America's adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $5 million for the fourth quarter of 2013 (sic) [ 2014 ], which is comparable to the fourth quarter of 2013.
Volumes in Chile were up 16% and lower by 27% in Brazil compared to the same quarter last year. Sales volume increase in Chile primarily increased demand, offset by lower exports. In Brazil, the lower volume was primarily due to reduced exports to the far east market. 
Pricing was down 16% in Chile and down 6% in Brazil. In local currency, Chile's pricing is 5% lower compared to the same quarter in 2013 due to continued pricing pressure from North American imports. And Brazil recorded a 1% improvement in pricing in local currency.
For the full year of 2014, South America recorded net sales of $150 million, profit of $11 million and adjusted EBITDA of $20 million. For 2013, South America recorded net sales of $172 million, profit of $20 million and adjusted EBITDA of $31 million.
Total selling, general and administrative costs were $41 million in the fourth quarter of 2014 compared to $47 million in the same quarter in 2013. For the full year of 2014, selling, general and administrative costs were about flat between the periods at $150 million. For the quarter, the reduction in SG&A costs is primarily related to lower incentive compensation.
Now please turn to Slide 9 of the presentation where we note that as of December 31, 2014, we had cash, cash equivalents, investments and restricted cash of $548 million. Working capital of $778 million. Net cash of $177 million. In addition to the cash on our balance sheet, we have $200 million of availability on our credit facility. Capital expenditures for the year were $80 million.
Capital expenditures for 2015 are expected to be approximately $130 million of which around $80 million relates to our growth project, such as the Swan siding mill conversion and the third Chilean mill. And we did not repurchase any shares of LP stock during this quarter.
Now I'll turn the call over to Curt for his comments.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sallie, for the review of the fourth quarter and the full year. My comments today will focus on our accomplishments and challenges during the last year, talk about the current state of the housing market, and provide you with my views on what i
componenttext:
Thank you, Sallie, for the review of the fourth quarter and the full year. My comments today will focus on our accomplishments and challenges during the last year, talk about the current state of the housing market, and provide you with my views on what is ahead for us in 2015. I will conclude by discussing the executive leadership changes that we announced this morning.
From a safety perspective, LP had a total incident rate of 0.35 for 2014, the lowest level in LP's history. This is the ninth year in a row that our total incident rate has been below 1.0. In addition, we completed all of our capital work in 2014 without a single recordable injury to any of the many, many contractors that we used on site, a truly remarkable performance.
For the year, housing starts were at just over 1 million, led by a strong fourth quarter performance. However, this is only about a 9% increase compared to the beginning of the year forecast of a 20% plus increase. This shortfall put pressure on OSB pricing all year that resulted in North Central 7/16's pricing between $71 per 1,000 square feet lower than 2013, quite a disappointment for us.
In our Siding business, we had record shipments of SmartSide for the third year in a row. This success led us to convert all production at Hayward to Siding and to make the decision to accelerate the conversion of our Swan Valley, Manitoba OSB mill to siding production. We expect this to be operational early in the fourth quarter of this year.
In Engineered Wood, we again had record shipments of Laminated Strand Lumber products and higher volumes of both I-Joist and LVL than in 2013.
South America, weaker economies in both Chile and Brazil, plus the stronger U.S. dollar reduced results, but we were still profitable in both these operations. That leaves me to a few comments on the housing market. U.S. housing starts in December were at 1.089 million units with single-family starts at their highest level in 6.5 years. In addition, housing starts for both October and November were revised upward.
Housing permits were slightly below starts in December at 1.028 million. The average 30-year mortgage rate for the week ending January 23 was at 3.66, the lowest level since the spike in rates in May of 2013.
Last month, I attended the International Builders' Show in Las Vegas. The attendance was very strong with an estimate of 125,000 attendees. From the supplier perspective, I'd say there was a universal caution as we were all caught off guard by the slow pace of the housing recovery in 2014. Most are using around 1.1 million housing starts as a base assumption. Among the builders, I'd say there was more optimism around housing activity, but they expressed concerns in a number of areas: Cost and ability of prime lots, availability of construction labor and upward pressure on labor cost, the cost of building products. And margin pressure as the ability to raise prices aggressively has dissipated.
Just last night, I returned from the Policy Advisory Board meeting of the Harvard Joint Center for Housing Studies that was held in Washington, D.C. over the past 2 days. This is a group from all facets of the housing industry, builders, developers, producers, distributors, realtors, government agencies who support housing, banks and other financial institutions. I'm pleased to say that the general tenor of the meeting was the most positive in 5 years. The optimism was broad based, but the most discussed item was the expected return of the first-time homebuyer due to a variety of factors. Sallie mentioned household formations have been at an extremely low level for much of the great recession. These numbers shot up in the fourth quarter to 3x what they've been averaging over the last 3 years. Job growth and wage increases from an improving economy gave much of the credit for this.
On the financing side, the lowering of premiums on mortgage insurance, the reemergence of the 3% down payment loans and more favorable credit standards are making financing more available for the first-time homebuyer.
At the meeting, there's also a discussions to try to assess the impact of falling oil prices on housing, and it appears to be a mixed bag. In the oil-producing areas, it doesn't appear that housing activity has slowed, but there's certainly a lot of talk about the timing of beginning new housing projects.
Lower fuel prices are adding to consumer confidence, which should accelerate household formation, a precursor to the first-time home sale or apartment rental.
As and aside, we do expect to have lower raw materials cost at our operations due to lower oil pricing, primarily resins and energy. Last December when we put our 2015 budget together, we estimated that the savings due to lower oil prices in the range of $25 million to $30 million. Today, with oil prices hovering just north of $50 a barrel, our estimated savings are in the $40 million to $50 million range.
In other markets, the National Association of Home Builder Remodeling index hit a record level in the fourth quarter of 2014. The Harvard Joint Center for Housing Studies just released their emerging trends in the remodeling market where they concluded that this market will continue to strengthen.
For the strong U.S. dollar, we don't see exports returning any time soon to North America. For 2015 and 2016, we agree with the forecasters that housing is going to continue to get better. The consensus forecast for housing starts in 2015 now stands at 1.19 million and 1.426 million in 2016, a 10% increase this year, followed by a 20% increase next year. I'll take that. As I mentioned in our last call, we're using 1.1 million as our 2015 base forecast.
OSB pricing is critically important to us and our financial performance as demonstrated last year. Clearly, pricing was short of expectations in 2014 as new production that came online in anticipation of higher housing activity led to an imbalance between supply and demand.
While we don't provide guidance on earnings or OSB prices, we do use Forest Economic Advisors as a primary forecasting source. For 2015, they see an increase of about 8% in OSB prices and a further 14% increase in 2016.
We do see the Canadian dollar below the $0.90 level for 2015. To put this in perspective, the change in the exchange rate in 2014 compared to 2013 improved our results by about $14 million.
For the near term, we have several important projects on our growth agenda. We've been on allocation on our Siding business for several months due to log shortages in Lake States that cost production shortfalls. We've been working diligently to put logs into these mills so we can operate without interruption. If nature cooperates a bit, I think this will happen.
In addition, we kicked off an accelerated project to convert our Swan Valley, Manitoba OSB mill to siding production early in the fourth quarter. We have further capital projects under development to add capacity or capabilities at our other siding mills to meet customer demand. Having available siding capacity ahead of demand is a very high priority.
South America, we have submitted our environmental permits and have initial comments back for our third mill in Chile, and we have started the detailed engineering to be ready to begin construction when the permits are approved. We believe this will be sometime around the end of the summer.
While we would always like housing to recover more quickly, we are pleased with our positioning in the market, and we stand ready to serve the increased housing market activity.
Before I turn it over to Sallie for questions and answer, I do want to take a few minutes to discuss the management changes that we announced this morning. The good news is these announcements is that we have a broad and deep bench within LP to assume important roles. The bad news is that we will be losing 2 very talented executives and good friends to retirement. Here's the summary of the changes. Rick Olszewski, EVP of sales and marketing at South America, will be retiring at the end of March of this year. As Rick's title demonstrates, Rick is both the senior sales and marketing executive for LP and the executive in charge of our South American operations.
For the first responsibility, Rick will be replaced by Mike Sims, our current VP of OSB Sales, for the new title of Senior VP, Sales and Marketing. Mike has over 30 years of experience in the selling and marketing of building products, and has held a senior role with LP since we acquired ABTco. in 1999. Because of the increased role of South American LP's growth plans, I will be taking over Rick's role in South America. And Frederick Price, President of LP's South America, will be reporting directly to me.
Jason Ringbloom, who's held a variety of sales roles with increasing responsibility over the years, will take Mike Sims spot as VP of OSB sales.
Jeff Wagner, our longtime EVP and GM of OSB, and I had been talking about his retirement plans for some time and decided that Jeff will leave his full-time employment with LP around the middle of this year. In the meantime, Jeff will report to me and assume responsibility for an important internal LP project to get better at growth and innovation. As we know, we can't rely solely on the housing recovery.
Brad Southern, a longtime LP officer and currently the Senior Vice President and General Manager of our Siding business, will assume Jeff's responsibility as EVP and General Manager of OSB. So you can tell, this creates more cascading.
Brian Luoma, another longtime LP employee and currently, Senior Vice President and GM of Engineered Wood business, will replace Brad and become EVP and GM of Siding.
Neil Sherman, currently our VP of Procurement and Logistics, will take Brian's position and become Senior Vice President and GM of EWP.
Finally, Mike Blosser, LP's VP of EHS and Forestry will once again add Neil's prior responsibilities to his portfolio.
While it seems like a lot of change at once, we were able to make all these moves internally as a result of the talent pool within LP and our robust succession planning process. I'm fully confident that each of these changes will bring a new perspective to position and will allow our executive management to acquire new skills that will allow for increased responsibility in the future.
I want to publicly thank Jeff for the many contributions he made to LP over his 35-year plus career with the company and Rick for bringing sales and marketing to the forefront of what's historically a manufacturing company in his 8.5 years with LP.
Now I'll turn it back over to Sallie for questions.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from the line of Mark Connelly with CLSA.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from the line of Mark Connelly with CLSA.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two things. Your comment about Jeff, in particular, peaks my interest. We've talked over the years, recently we've talked about CanExel and Siding. But in the past, we talked about radiant barriers and other value add. Is this a new initiative on your par
componenttext: Two things. Your comment about Jeff, in particular, peaks my interest. We've talked over the years, recently we've talked about CanExel and Siding. But in the past, we talked about radiant barriers and other value add. Is this a new initiative on your part? Or is there just more coming through the pipe that needs to be managed?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: It actually is a new initiative. As you know, we tried to grow through acquisition last year. And when it became clear that, that wasn't going to come to the forefront, we did engage an outside group to help us with our growth and innovation capabilities.
componenttext: It actually is a new initiative. As you know, we tried to grow through acquisition last year. And when it became clear that, that wasn't going to come to the forefront, we did engage an outside group to help us with our growth and innovation capabilities. We've done a lot of it over the years, but this just gives us a much more disciplined approach. And so what we've done is Rick Olszewski and Neil Sherman actually headed up that project for about the end of last summer until today. And Jeff will be taking over that responsibility probably until the middle of the year. And what it does do for us, Mark, is it just gives us much more information on the market sizing or the geographic opportunities might be. So it should accelerate the growth of some new products, plus increase our penetration and geographies where we should be more successful than we have been.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: That sounds outstanding. Just one more question. Given the time you've spent with builders and other folks lately, I'm just curious if you see anything that suggests that we're going to see a shift in the rate of adoption or the rate of penetration of Eng
componenttext: That sounds outstanding. Just one more question. Given the time you've spent with builders and other folks lately, I'm just curious if you see anything that suggests that we're going to see a shift in the rate of adoption or the rate of penetration of Engineered Wood Products over this housing recovery? We've seen shifts in size, we've seen it shift to multi-family. I'm just wondering if you're seeing anything that makes you think we're going to see some acceleration.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's going to fall housing growth, I don't think that you're going to see increased penetration. A number of things have happened there. I think, in the past, we talked about the lumber going from British Columbia into China. That's slowing a litt
componenttext: I think it's going to fall housing growth, I don't think that you're going to see increased penetration. A number of things have happened there. I think, in the past, we talked about the lumber going from British Columbia into China. That's slowing a little bit, which means there's going to be more lumber coming out of British Columbia into the U.S. to help support this market. So we think that the market shares really haven't changed all that much even during the recession between the Engineered Wood and Solid Wood. so I think, it's going to be about the same.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Gail Glazerman with UBS.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Gail Glazerman with UBS.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could give a little bit more color on what went on in Engineered Wood in the quarter? Volumes were pretty weak. I guess, there was some reference of kind of destocking. How much of that do you think was seasonal versus something els
componenttext: I was wondering if you could give a little bit more color on what went on in Engineered Wood in the quarter? Volumes were pretty weak. I guess, there was some reference of kind of destocking. How much of that do you think was seasonal versus something else? And any signs of that reversing in the first quarter?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Gail. Fundamentally, we do believe that there was a fair amount of destocking that occurred in the fourth quarter and that really highlighted itself in the capacity utilization for that business, which was down in the fourth quarter. And we are begi
componenttext: Sure, Gail. Fundamentally, we do believe that there was a fair amount of destocking that occurred in the fourth quarter and that really highlighted itself in the capacity utilization for that business, which was down in the fourth quarter. And we are beginning to see some improvement in the first quarter in orders in EWP. And we're having some wins in certain markets in EWP as well.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And in terms of the inflation comments on oil. I'm just wondering, are there any offsets? I guess, specifically, are you currently seeing any relief on the log costs in the West? Any issues with freight and logistics? Or is that also -- is that a be
componenttext: Okay. And in terms of the inflation comments on oil. I'm just wondering, are there any offsets? I guess, specifically, are you currently seeing any relief on the log costs in the West? Any issues with freight and logistics? Or is that also -- is that a benefit incorporated in the oil guidance?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. On the transportation side, we actually see -- this is an opportunity for both railroads and truckers to raise their rates. So we're actually not seeing much reduction in our freight cost. In fact, we could see a little bit higher pricing, particular
componenttext: Yes. On the transportation side, we actually see -- this is an opportunity for both railroads and truckers to raise their rates. So we're actually not seeing much reduction in our freight cost. In fact, we could see a little bit higher pricing, particularly, coming out of the Canadian railroads because of price increases they put in place, plus some of the changes they have made to their AMB [ph] routing, which has forced us to increase our distribution channel with more reloads and other methods to support our customers. So we're not seeing on the transportation side. On the log side, we have not seen any relief in the Lake States on pricing. We've seen a little bit more availability but not on the pricing. In the South, we do expect log pricing to come off a little bit, but not significantly.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And in light of the decline in the Canadian dollar, I'm just wondering, are you rethinking or have you made any adjustments to your operating footprint, maybe increasing production out of the West Coast and flowing down in the U.S -- or out of Canad
componenttext: Okay. And in light of the decline in the Canadian dollar, I'm just wondering, are you rethinking or have you made any adjustments to your operating footprint, maybe increasing production out of the West Coast and flowing down in the U.S -- or out of Canada and flowing in the U.S.?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: We keep looking at that. But one of the -- I mentioned in my earlier comments that the export market has dried up. We actually shipped a fair amount of wood both the to far east and to Russia out of our Canadian operations, and that really has come to a s
componenttext: We keep looking at that. But one of the -- I mentioned in my earlier comments that the export market has dried up. We actually shipped a fair amount of wood both the to far east and to Russia out of our Canadian operations, and that really has come to a standstill with a strong U.S. dollar plus the havoc that's going on in Russia. So we need to replace that volume somewhere else. And as a result, we have taken some downtime this quarter because of weather and weaker demand. But we continue to look at the Canadian operations as a good source of products in the future. The only asset that we have that is not running is our mill in Québec. And we do not have any plans this year to start that mill backup.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And with pricing where it is, would you -- could you envision seeing any kind of incremental actual multiples versus just downtime?
componenttext: Okay. And with pricing where it is, would you -- could you envision seeing any kind of incremental actual multiples versus just downtime?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't envision that because I do believe that with the market, even the 9% increase, which is our base forecast versus the 18% or 19% that's in the forecast, would say there is a demand for that wood. But we will do what we have done in the past a
componenttext: Well, I don't envision that because I do believe that with the market, even the 9% increase, which is our base forecast versus the 18% or 19% that's in the forecast, would say there is a demand for that wood. But we will do what we have done in the past as we will take market curtailments as we see weaker demand. Sallie mentioned in the fourth quarter, we took 136 days of downtime, and we're currently taking downtime at our mills right now.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon with Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon with Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question is on the -- your CapEx, and I might have missed the number, if you gave us a guide. But could you remind us what that number looks like for '15? And just gives us some directional nuance for '16? And I know you mentioned the product -- the
componenttext: First question is on the -- your CapEx, and I might have missed the number, if you gave us a guide. But could you remind us what that number looks like for '15? And just gives us some directional nuance for '16? And I know you mentioned the product -- the project in Chile. But are there other definable projects that you're still working -- that you would be working on in '15 and '16?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Chip. Our guidance on CapEx for 2015 is $130 million. $50 million of that represents what we typically talk about in terms of maintenance. The remaining $80 million relates to projects like turning our Swan Manitoba OSB mill converting that into a s
componenttext: Sure, Chip. Our guidance on CapEx for 2015 is $130 million. $50 million of that represents what we typically talk about in terms of maintenance. The remaining $80 million relates to projects like turning our Swan Manitoba OSB mill converting that into a siding mill, as well as plans for the third Chilean mill. So if we -- the expectation right now is that Swan would be fully converted in 2015. The Chilean mill -- we'll look to see what's going on in that economy and think about the timing on that, but we expect some expenditures in 2015 and that will move into 2016, and then we'll continue to think about opportunities for growth in our Siding business as that business continues to grow.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chip, the only color I would give on that is as we look into 2015 or 2016, there are a series of additional projects to match the capabilities of our siding mills to the market demand. And so we will be rolling those out through '16, but that's totally ba
componenttext: Chip, the only color I would give on that is as we look into 2015 or 2016, there are a series of additional projects to match the capabilities of our siding mills to the market demand. And so we will be rolling those out through '16, but that's totally based on the demand for the products, and those are well thought out and great return projects. The only other one is we have been focused on our FlameBlock product for, particularly, for multi-family. And a contractor that we use were currently out of capacity there, so we're determining what we do and that may be a modest investment that we will make internally for both fire-retardant OSB and fire retardant I-Joist.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. And just to give us a little bit of a feel for things, if you kind of go back a few years, I know that we haven't had very many good years in the last 5, let's say. But I do recall that in, for example, in 2000 and I think it was '12, we're actua
componenttext: Got you. And just to give us a little bit of a feel for things, if you kind of go back a few years, I know that we haven't had very many good years in the last 5, let's say. But I do recall that in, for example, in 2000 and I think it was '12, we're actually -- sorry, 2013 was a pretty decent year for OSB. And I know in that year you made $86 million in Siding. Now I know you have some OSB inside of that segment. Last year, you almost -- I mean, you only made $6 million less. You went from $86 million to $80 million, when OSB completely fell down. So if we kind of strip out the OSB profits in '13, I mean, how much -- I mean, it appears on the surface to have been a big swing upward again in '14 in siding or at least an up year, even though it was down for OSB. Is that fair?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: That is fair, Chip. In fact, there's probably about a $9 million difference between Siding profits in 2013, we reported in the -- our OSB profits in the Siding segment. So it was a $9 million swing. So if you took 2013 down, you would see a pretty good gr
componenttext: That is fair, Chip. In fact, there's probably about a $9 million difference between Siding profits in 2013, we reported in the -- our OSB profits in the Siding segment. So it was a $9 million swing. So if you took 2013 down, you would see a pretty good growth in the Siding business. And as I said, we did have record volumes in 2014.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Bill Hoffmann with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Bill Hoffmann with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Curt, could you just talk a little bit more sort of how you're planning for what if there's a downside case here where housing -- it doesn't improve like you're thinking and talking even with some of these positive signs, from an operating standpoint, jus
componenttext: Curt, could you just talk a little bit more sort of how you're planning for what if there's a downside case here where housing -- it doesn't improve like you're thinking and talking even with some of these positive signs, from an operating standpoint, just really either take costs out of the system or to better balance the market, so you get somewhat of a better pricing environment?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, what we're doing today, Bill, is what we did last year. As we saw demand fall -- let me just back up a minute. So just to remind everyone, when we figure out our OSB business at the beginning of the year, we do contract with our customers f
componenttext: Well, I think, what we're doing today, Bill, is what we did last year. As we saw demand fall -- let me just back up a minute. So just to remind everyone, when we figure out our OSB business at the beginning of the year, we do contract with our customers for volume. It doesn't affect the pricing in general, but we contract volume. So with the home centers, we contract a certain amount of volume with some of the big prodealers and some of the others. So our contracted volume last year was around 80%, and it's about the same this year. So when we take downtime, what really what we're playing with is that 20% that's open market wood because we have commitments for the other 80%. Does that make sense?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the downtime that we're taking is that we don't see a demand for the open market wood, then we adjust our production schedules to satisfy the demand that we do have from our customers.
componenttext: So the downtime that we're taking is that we don't see a demand for the open market wood, then we adjust our production schedules to satisfy the demand that we do have from our customers.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. I guess, what I'm asking is, does it make sense to even temporarily idle a facility for a year to help bring this market back into balance on that 120%?
componenttext: Right. I guess, what I'm asking is, does it make sense to even temporarily idle a facility for a year to help bring this market back into balance on that 120%?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, so far, we believe the best from an economic perspective is to run it the way that we're running it because when do you take a mill down, that means you fire all the people, you get rid of the customers that you had contracted that mill with, and th
componenttext: Well, so far, we believe the best from an economic perspective is to run it the way that we're running it because when do you take a mill down, that means you fire all the people, you get rid of the customers that you had contracted that mill with, and then you have the start-up costs that go with that.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just the other question, on the log outages that you experienced in the fourth quarter, is that situation pretty much rectified itself at this point?
componenttext: Okay. And then just the other question, on the log outages that you experienced in the fourth quarter, is that situation pretty much rectified itself at this point?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say, it's better, but it's still touch and go. And this is really in the Lake States region where they've had some weather issues, they've had infrastructure issues, there's been competing demand from the pulp mills in that area. So we're actually
componenttext: I would say, it's better, but it's still touch and go. And this is really in the Lake States region where they've had some weather issues, they've had infrastructure issues, there's been competing demand from the pulp mills in that area. So we're actually bringing wood in from farther away or paying more for it.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question come from the line of Mark Wilde with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question come from the line of Mark Wilde with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wonder if we could talk, first, about just OSB and really bridging the difference between the year-over-year decline in EBITDA in that sector. You've pointed, I think, to price being about $27 million of that decline and it was a total of about $38 mill
componenttext: I wonder if we could talk, first, about just OSB and really bridging the difference between the year-over-year decline in EBITDA in that sector. You've pointed, I think, to price being about $27 million of that decline and it was a total of about $38 million. So the other $11 million, Curt, is that downtime? Or what else might be in that number?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's downtime. That's the impact of the higher downtime of the unabsorbed costs.
componenttext: Yes, that's downtime. That's the impact of the higher downtime of the unabsorbed costs.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The unabsorbed costs, yes, yes, yes, okay. All right. And I was just curious, you were actually down year-over-year in volumes in OSB in the fourth quarter. But most of the housing indicators, as Curt mentioned, were up in the fourth quarter. So how do we
componenttext: The unabsorbed costs, yes, yes, yes, okay. All right. And I was just curious, you were actually down year-over-year in volumes in OSB in the fourth quarter. But most of the housing indicators, as Curt mentioned, were up in the fourth quarter. So how do we get our heads around that delta?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Mark, as you will recall, we actually produced more in the third quarter. So we sold it for other inventory.
componenttext: Well, Mark, as you will recall, we actually produced more in the third quarter. So we sold it for other inventory.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right, that's fine. Just turning to the Latin American business, I was just curious about how you see the impacts of the big decline in both the Chilean peso and the Brazilian real playing out over the next year to -- in that business?
componenttext: Okay, all right, that's fine. Just turning to the Latin American business, I was just curious about how you see the impacts of the big decline in both the Chilean peso and the Brazilian real playing out over the next year to -- in that business?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, most of the impact is on our reported results because we translated back into u.S. dollars. We sell -- most of the product in Chile is sold in the Chilean pesos. So our costs and our expenses are in the same. In Brazil, we have a little bit of an ex
componenttext: Well, most of the impact is on our reported results because we translated back into u.S. dollars. We sell -- most of the product in Chile is sold in the Chilean pesos. So our costs and our expenses are in the same. In Brazil, we have a little bit of an export market -- a little bit more of an export market and that is typically in U.S. dollar. So they should benefit a little bit from that as we go forward.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: And it's possible going back to Chile's unintended consequence of the higher U.S. dollar  would be few of our competitors exporting down into Chile, which would help our Chilean operations from a demand point of view and pricing point of view.
componenttext: And it's possible going back to Chile's unintended consequence of the higher U.S. dollar  would be few of our competitors exporting down into Chile, which would help our Chilean operations from a demand point of view and pricing point of view.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Because I guess, when I listened to your comments on the fourth quarter, it seemed like things moved in an opposite direction from what I would have expected. You talked about more imports coming into the Chilean market and you talked about less expo
componenttext: Yes. Because I guess, when I listened to your comments on the fourth quarter, it seemed like things moved in an opposite direction from what I would have expected. You talked about more imports coming into the Chilean market and you talked about less exports out of Brazil. And I would have thought, given the weakness in both of those currencies, that we would have seen less imports into Chile and more exports out of Brazil.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're continuing to see export from the U.S. into the Chilean market, even with the U.S. dollar where it is, and we're seeing that pricing pressure. And then...
componenttext: Yes, we're continuing to see export from the U.S. into the Chilean market, even with the U.S. dollar where it is, and we're seeing that pricing pressure. And then...

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's not logical, Mark.
componenttext: It's not logical, Mark.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. We just -- right.
componenttext: Right. We just -- right.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Geez, I'd almost use that D word if I didn't know better. I guess, the last question I had, Curt, was just on the EWP business and I just -- I wonder whether your strategy or your market position in EWP is due for a rethink at all?
componenttext: Geez, I'd almost use that D word if I didn't know better. I guess, the last question I had, Curt, was just on the EWP business and I just -- I wonder whether your strategy or your market position in EWP is due for a rethink at all?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as we do with all of our businesses, we look at our portfolio to figure out what makes the most sense. I think some of Sallie's comments may not picked up on it, but we did have a pretty significant series of design wins or wins with major customers
componenttext: Well, as we do with all of our businesses, we look at our portfolio to figure out what makes the most sense. I think some of Sallie's comments may not picked up on it, but we did have a pretty significant series of design wins or wins with major customers in the fourth quarter. So I do see that business picking up, and so we are seeing more activity in Engineered Wood.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Is being in that business, is there any connection between that businesses and the Siding business? Do you have any of the sales and support people that overlap? Or is that completely separate?
componenttext: Is being in that business, is there any connection between that businesses and the Siding business? Do you have any of the sales and support people that overlap? Or is that completely separate?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The salespeople were up quite a bit. We do have specialists that support EWP. As you know, you need engineering expertise there. So those are specifically identified with EWP. But the general sales force, sales are especially OSB, our Siding products and
componenttext: The salespeople were up quite a bit. We do have specialists that support EWP. As you know, you need engineering expertise there. So those are specifically identified with EWP. But the general sales force, sales are especially OSB, our Siding products and our engineered wood. So they are calling on the same customers, dealers, builders.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Last thing I would ask, Curt, we just -- we had some news about another OSB mill in East Texas. It's amazing to me given the difficulties that the market has gone through over the last 7 or 8 years, including this last year that the people are talki
componenttext: Okay. Last thing I would ask, Curt, we just -- we had some news about another OSB mill in East Texas. It's amazing to me given the difficulties that the market has gone through over the last 7 or 8 years, including this last year that the people are talking about building more capacity. Any thoughts?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first, this is a privately-held enterprise that has made the announcement. It's also -- if you think about it, with today's capacity, even bringing back the 2 or 3 mills that are curtailed, we can support about 1.4 million to 1.5 million housing sta
componenttext: Well, first, this is a privately-held enterprise that has made the announcement. It's also -- if you think about it, with today's capacity, even bringing back the 2 or 3 mills that are curtailed, we can support about 1.4 million to 1.5 million housing starts. So if you get north of that, there needs to be a solution for additional capacity. Not that I'm thinking about it, but I'm just telling you what is the thinking might be. And as I understand the announcement is that there were some economic development grants discussed. I don't think they were approved, but they were discussed. So I think he's getting ahead of it because if you think about it, he's got to get the site, which as far as I know, he doesn't own a site, he's just got the economic development grant. You've got to buy the site. You got to get an environmental permitting. Then you got to order the equipment and then you got to build it. So you're 3 to 4 years out. So if you think about it in that context, it's not totally wacky. Plus he is privately held so it doesn't habe talk to shareholders.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, presumably, he still likes to get a return on his money.
componenttext: Well, presumably, he still likes to get a return on his money.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Mark Weintraub with Buckingham Research Group.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Mark Weintraub with Buckingham Research Group.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm curious, you mentioned that you've got about 80% of your OSB volumes contracted last year and this year. Is that relatively standard practice for the larger producers? Or are you an outlier in that regard, would you say?
componenttext: I'm curious, you mentioned that you've got about 80% of your OSB volumes contracted last year and this year. Is that relatively standard practice for the larger producers? Or are you an outlier in that regard, would you say?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know specifically what they do. But if you think about the home center business, we know what percentage we have. And the rest of that home center businesses is supplied by our competitors. And Home Depot and Lowe's don't do anything but contracti
componenttext: I don't know specifically what they do. But if you think about the home center business, we know what percentage we have. And the rest of that home center businesses is supplied by our competitors. And Home Depot and Lowe's don't do anything but contracting. So I assume on the retail side that there's contracts in place, and I also assume the same thing on the big dealers. But I can't tell you specifically.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you have a very outsized position in Home Depot and Lowe's, would you say, relative to the competition?
componenttext: Do you have a very outsized position in Home Depot and Lowe's, would you say, relative to the competition?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think our position is probably consistent with our market share.
componenttext: I think our position is probably consistent with our market share.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then switching to Siding for a minute, if you think about the impact of the log shortages, et cetera, do you think that you were -- that the opportunity cost on the market share is something that's lost? Do you think that inventory was pulled ou
componenttext: Okay. And then switching to Siding for a minute, if you think about the impact of the log shortages, et cetera, do you think that you were -- that the opportunity cost on the market share is something that's lost? Do you think that inventory was pulled out of the channel to -- somewhere along the channel to meet where that demand was? And so there's kind of this capability for you to refill that channel? Or how should we think about the dynamics of how the log shortages are impacting the Siding business?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think with the allocation that we went on, we maintained our customers, our customer loyalty. But the shortfall we had in production, we lost that to another technology. I don't think inventories were adjusted. So that's why we have to always be a
componenttext: Well, I think with the allocation that we went on, we maintained our customers, our customer loyalty. But the shortfall we had in production, we lost that to another technology. I don't think inventories were adjusted. So that's why we have to always be ahead of siding from a capacity standpoint. And we feel bad about that, but we're doing everything we can to recapture that volume.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, just one quick one, just trying to understand a little bit, you talked about the third mill in Chile as being part of the $130 million. It sounded though like you were still considering the exact timing of how you want to proceed th
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, just one quick one, just trying to understand a little bit, you talked about the third mill in Chile as being part of the $130 million. It sounded though like you were still considering the exact timing of how you want to proceed there. Can you may be flush that out a little bit more for us?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we've had a third mill on the drawing board for a while in Chile, and then we had the recession in Brazil, we had the fall in copper pricing. So we are being very cognizant of what's going on in those economies. Now the other piece of this is we are
componenttext: Well, we've had a third mill on the drawing board for a while in Chile, and then we had the recession in Brazil, we had the fall in copper pricing. So we are being very cognizant of what's going on in those economies. Now the other piece of this is we are intending to supply other South American countries with this capacity. And as you probably know, Colombia is doing very well now. Peru is coming back. Argentina is a mess, but assuming they have a change in government soon that, that could come back. So from a timing perspective, it's going to be a year of construction period. I think Sallie was the one that was hesitating a little bit. We expect to get the permitting by the end of the summer. But to here thinking, and I would agree with that, is if the Chilean economy remains in the doldrums, we might delay that a little bit.

componenttext: That's an interesting question because when I was at the Builder' Show, when I was at the Harvard meeting, I talked to some of our distributors and said, "What are your inventories like?" They all said, "They're pretty lean because I get whatever I want right now at a pretty low price." I said, "What's going to happen in March and April if this does take off?" And they all said, "Well, we're all worried about that." So we did see a little bit of affirming last Friday. I think for us, in certain regions, it did hit our floor pricing, so a sub-lower floor pricing. So again, it did get a little tick up last week. So we'll see.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, typically, we hold to what is the local market determination where our plants are. That has been running in the last couple of years at about 3% on the wage side. And then on the benefit side, we actually had pretty good experience on our health car
componenttext: Well, typically, we hold to what is the local market determination where our plants are. That has been running in the last couple of years at about 3% on the wage side. And then on the benefit side, we actually had pretty good experience on our health care last couple of years. So we haven't seen as much of an impact on the health care. So I think, a 3% to 4% number is probably about where it's been. And on the productivity, as you know, we're a Lean Six Sigma company. And last year, we got a 5.8:1 return on our investment in Lean Six Sigma. So we really use that as our continuous improvement approach to the mill. So most of that actually as a wage increase could offset with productivity or the Lean Six Sigma.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015

componenttext: Okay, got it, Curt. On the EWP side, there's 2 public competitors out there. I'm just looking at their numbers, one, explicitly reports the numbers. The other, I think, you can essentially back into the numbers. Just the profitability, both the absolute level and the year-on-year improvement was just materially ahead where you guys are showing the numbers. I mean, fundamentally, is there a difference in the businesses here [indiscernible]?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, there is a fundamental difference. I can -- and I talked to it last time. So let me just tell you again what it is. In our business, we have owned facilities and then we have partnership facilities and we have a sales arrangement. So for instance, in
componenttext: Yes, there is a fundamental difference. I can -- and I talked to it last time. So let me just tell you again what it is. In our business, we have owned facilities and then we have partnership facilities and we have a sales arrangement. So for instance, in LVL, probably 1/3 of our volume, we buy from Murphy Plywood. And what we get there is we get a sales margin, we don't get a manufacturing margin. But we also have no investment in the planning equipment. In our I-Joist business, probably 70% of our I-Joist has come out of the 2 joint venture mills that we have with AbitibiBowater. And there, again, we get the sales margin and we get half of the manufacturing margin, but not all of it. So if you were to look at it on an RO -- return on assets, we look really, really good. But if you look at it just on a margin, we don't capture the full margin either on those I-Joists or the JV because we only get half of it. And then in the Murphy, we just get a sales margin. So there's the difference in the operating models in that we don't own and operate all of our own facilities. But we adjust for that, if you look at the sales pricing between the 2 other public entities, our sales pricing is right on top of -- maybe even a little bit ahead, and our manufacturing costs are right on top of them. But it's the manufacturing margin that we don't enjoy on the Murphy Plywood and only half of it on the I-Joist.
