headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corp. Q1 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would like to introduce a host for today's conference, Ms Sallie Baile
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corp. Q1 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would like to introduce a host for today's conference, Ms Sallie Bailey, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Ma'am, please go ahead.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you very much, Michelle, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the first quarter of 2015. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer, and with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's C
componenttext:
Great. Thank you very much, Michelle, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the first quarter of 2015. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer, and with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's Chief Executive Officer; as well as Mike Kinney; and Becky Barckley, our primary Investor Relations contact.
I will begin the discussion with a review of the financial results for the first quarter of 2015. This will be followed by some comments on the performance of the individual segments and selected balance sheet items. After I finish my remarks, Curt will discuss the general market environment in which LP has been operating, provide his perspective on our operating results and give some thoughts on the outlook. As we have done in the past, we have opened up this call to the public and are doing a webcast. And that webcast can be accessed at www.lpcorp.com. 
Additionally, to help with the discussion, we have provided a presentation with supplemental information that should be reviewed in conjunction with our earnings release. I will be referencing these slides in my comments this morning. We have filed an 8-K this morning with some supplemental information as well as our Form 10-Q. I want to remind all the participants about the forward-looking statements comments on Slide 2 of the presentation. Please also be aware of the discussion of our use of non-GAAP financial information included on Slide 3 of the presentation. The appendix attached to the presentation have some of the necessary reconciliation that has been supplemented by the Form 8-K filing we've made this morning. Rather than reading these 2 statements, I incorporated them with this reference.
The housing market was still in recovery mode for the first quarter during 2015. The results in our OSB segment reflects the lower pricing environment, down 13% from last year and impacted the company's financial results for the quarter. The reduction in OSB pricing accounts for approximately $29 million of the change in our operating loss and adjusted EBITDA relative to the first quarter of 2014. The stronger dollar, lower raw material cost, better plant operating performance and the record-setting quarter on our Siding segment offset the impact of the decline in OSB price. 
With that let me go into the details. Moving to Slide 4 of the presentation for a discussion of the first quarter 2015 consolidated results. We are reporting net sales of $472 million for the first quarter of 2015, a 6% increase from the net sales of $445 million reported in the first quarter of 2014. In the first quarter, we recorded a net loss of $35 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.24 as compared to a net loss for the first 3 months of 2014 of $14 million or loss of $0.10 per diluted share. 
Included in our GAAP results for the quarter is $11.6 million write-off of the timber licenses associated with our indefinitely idle facility. Given our ongoing losses in Canada, this write-off provides no immediate tax benefit to LP due to our valuation reserves. The Ministry of Forestry terminated our license in the first quarter of 2015, and Curt will discuss this a bit more detail in a few minutes. The adjusted loss for quarter was $19 million or loss of $0.13 per diluted share, based upon the normalized tax rate of 35% compared to adjusted loss of $7 million or a loss of $0.05 per diluted share for the first quarter of 2014. 
Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $6 million in the quarter compared to $23 million in the first quarter of 2014. 
I'll move to Slide 5 and review of our segment results. Beginning with our OSB. OSB recorded an operating loss of $28 million on $190 million of sales in the quarter, compared to an operating loss of $2 million on $195 million of sales in the first quarter of 2014. For the quarter, we are reporting negative adjusted EBITDA of $13 million compared to positive EBITDA of $12 million in the first quarter of 2014. We have a 14% increase in sales volume and a 4% increase in the OSB segment production. Pricing for OSB was down 13% over the first quarter of 2014. The decrease in pricing resulted in lower operating results by about $29 million. OSB segment 127 down days or the equivalent of just under 200 million square feet of reduced production during the quarter. 
Despite the significant number of down days, our cost of sale per MSF improved relative to the first quarter of 2014 as well as the fourth quarter of 2014, due to the impacts of the weaker Canadian dollar, lower raw material cost and improved operating performance at our Clarke County facility. 
Slide 6 reports the result of the Siding segment. This segment includes our SmartSide and CanExel siding products. The first quarter of 2015 was a record quarter for the Siding segment for sales, operating income and adjusted EBITDA. The Siding segment reported sales of $174 million in the first quarter of 2015, an increase of 21% from $144 million reported in the first quarter of 2014. The Siding segment reported operating income of $33 million compared to $19 million in the first quarter of 2014, and adjusted EBITDA of $38 million as compared to $24 million in the same quarter of 2014. For the second quarter in a row, the Siding segment did not produce any OSB. 
Consistent with the past several quarters, the Siding segment continue to experience higher wood cost. However, we are able to acquire logs, run our facility as planned and took no downtime in the quarter related to offshore The higher wood comps in the first quarter of 2015 were partially offset by lower resin costs and improved absorption in our manufacturing facility. The results for the quarter were also positively impacted by improved product mix and higher sales volume. 
For the quarter, SmartSide average sale prices were up 8% and volumes increased 19%. Volumes increased on our SmartSide siding line due to continued penetration in several key focus markets, including retail, repair and remodel and markets and sheds. CanExel prices were flat in U.S. dollars, so were the prices were up 12% in Canadian dollars, which is CanExel's primary market. Volumes were down 18% in the quarter, due to decreases in Canadian and international demand. 
Please turn to Slide 7 of the presentation, which shows the results for our Engineered Wood Products segment. The segment includes I-Joist, Laminated Strand Lumber, Laminated Veneer Lumber plus other related products. This segment also includes the sale of our I-Joist and products produced by the Abitibi joint venture under our sales arrangement with Murphy Plywood. 
The EWP segment did produce 10 million square feet of OSB in the first quarter of 2015 under the facility. 
The Engineered Wood Products segment recorded sales of $65 million in the first quarter of 2015, up from $62 million in the first quarter of 2014. The segment's operating loss in the first quarter of 2015 was $4 million as compared to a loss of $3 million in the first quarter of 2014. 
For the first quarter of 2015, adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations declined to a negative $400,000 as compared to a positive adjusted EBITDA of $1.3 million in the first quarter of 2014. Volumes of I-Joist were down 12%, primarily due to lower volumes in Western Canada. While volumes of LVL and LSL were up 16% compared to the same quarter last year, as we focus more on exports and industrial markets. 
Pricing was up 6% in I-Joist and down 3% in LVL and LSL. The increase in I-Joist reflects price increases introduced to offset rising raw material cost during 2014. The decline in LVL and LSL reflects changes in mix through a higher percentage of industrial uses, which are sold at a lower price. 
Turning to Slide 8 of the presentation. For the quarter, our South American segment recorded sales of $36 million as compared to $37 million in the first quarter of 2014. Operating income was $2 million in the first quarter of 2015 compared to $4 million in the first quarter of 2014. South America's adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $5 million for the first quarter of 2014 as compared to $7 million in the first quarter of 2014. 
Volumes in the quarter were up 31% and lower by 18% in Brazil compared to the same quarter last year. The sales volume increase in Chile was primarily due to improved housing demand. In Brazil, the reduction in sales volume was due to the economic recession, which led to loss of demand. Pricing was down 13% in Chile and down 16% in Brazil. And in local currency, chile's pricing is lower by 1% compared with the same quarter in 2014, and Brazil recorded a 3% improvement in pricing. 
Total SG&A costs were $39 million in the first quarter of 2015 compared to $41 million in the same quarter of 2014. For the quarter, the reduction in SG&A cost is primarily related to legal costs incurred in the 2014 associated with the aborted Ainsworth transaction. We recorded $2 million of foreign exchange loss in the quarter compared to $4 million loss in the same quarter last year. And net interest expense was flat between quarters. 
Please refer to Slide 9 of the presentation. As of March 31, 2015, we have cash, cash equivalent of investments and restricted cash of $483 million, working capital of $742 million, net cash of $114 million, and in addition to the $483 million of cash on our balance sheet, we have $200 million availability on our credit facility. March year-to-date capital expenditures were $15 million. We do expect capital expenditures for 2015 to be in the range of $120 million to $130 million, with over half of this amount related to the Swan Valley mill conversion. We did not repurchase any shares of LP stock during the quarter, but we do continue to evaluate opportunities to repurchase shares, along with other uses of the company's capital. I will turn the call over to Curt for his comments.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sallie, for that review. Good morning to all of you and thanks for joining us on the call. Let me start with LP's safety performance. Last week, the APA announced the results of their safety and health awards program for 2014. I'm pleased that LP
componenttext:
Thanks, Sallie, for that review. Good morning to all of you and thanks for joining us on the call. Let me start with LP's safety performance. Last week, the APA announced the results of their safety and health awards program for 2014. I'm pleased that LP was named the Safest Large Company in our industry for the year. This is the fifth time we have been so recognized in the last 7 years. We also had 10 facilities included in the Incident-free Honor Society. I'm very proud of one of our employees recognize the value of being safe and act accordingly. 
In addition to the obvious savings in Worker's Compensation cost, LP believes that our safety culture gives us the competitive edge in the hiring and retention of our employees. 
This morning I'll provide a few comments on the results in the first quarter, talk about the state of the housing market and give you my views for the next several quarters. After that, I'll turn the call back to Sallie for questions. 
With 2 notable exceptions that negatively affected our results, OSB pricing and the write-off of the wood license, LP actually had a pretty good quarter. Let me just start with quick review of the 2 negative items. OSB pricing has fallen below analyst's projections for the last 6 quarters, and Random Lengths was 12% an already low 2014 pricing level. They easy scapegoat in Q1 is always the weather. While I know this did have an impact, the primary driver of lower pricing was more available supply than demand. As a result, we had to take significant downtime in our mills in the quarter. 
In Q2, we continue to evaluate and take market-related downtime as the recovery in residential demand has been short of economists projections. Further, while we are meeting our commitments to our customers, they're also aggressively exploring other applications beyond single-family new construction. These areas include repairing modeling, industrial, transportation and modest exports. 
Let me give you some background to Chambord wood license. We indefinitely curtailed production at the Chambord Québec mill in 2008 as the great recession whacked housing. Over the intervening years, we have been a regular contact with Québec government and we've met all of our mutually agreed upon obligations to obtain the license. Over the last year, there's been increasing pressure to use the wood to create jobs in the area. Unfortunately, the government decided that they would not wait for LP to restart the mill and informed us quarter that they have canceled our wood license. They will be setting up a project office to review alternative proposals for the wood. We'll be a part of this process and believe that the LP mills still the best alternative to use the wood in the area. We do have other options for these assets also been exploring. As to the write-off, the accounting rules dictated that we take on noncash charge for the carrying value of the wood license. 
On the positive side, as Sallie mentioned, our Siding business had a record quarter, SmartSide shipments, revenue and EBITDA. We did enjoy lower resin cost in Q1 and the lower Canadian dollar made our operations north of the border more competitive. Efforts to fully convert our Swan Valley to SmartSide production are underway, with initial production expected in Q4 of this year. 
Next, let me just share some views on the housing market. As you know, there are mountains of data on the featured housing market that are confusing, sometimes conflicting and definitely frustrating. But bottom line housing is improving, but not at the pace forecast by most economists. Here are some numbers expect that housing starts. The consensus forecast for this year is 1.153 million, which would represented a 15% increase over 2014. Consensus forecast for 2016 stands at 1.36 million, which is a further 18% increase on the forecast for this year. At LP, as I mentioned last quarter, we forecast 1.1 million housing starts for 2015 and I believe that still works like a reasonable number. In 2016, we expect a 10% to 15% improvement in starts. 
Other positive housing-related news, household formations accelerated in Q4 to 1.7 million and all that up about 1.5 million in Q1 of this year. This is much better than the anemic 400,000 to 500,000 piece over the last several years. And when the household is formed, it's usually means that the home is occupied, which is good news for our industry. A Deutsche Bank economist just published following tidbit, which might be of interest. The number of people per household returns to the 2000 to 2003 level, this would lead to 4 million new households, a very positive for housing looking forward. 
Mortgage rates remain below 4%, the inventory of new and existing homes for sale is shrinking, and most of the big boulders who have reported first quarter results have mentioned a strong spring selling season. Repair and model expenditures are expected to be strong, and the rental vacancy rate is t the's lowest level in 20 years. 
So what does this all mean for LP in the next several quarters? With spring finally happening in most of the country and positive momentum in the housing sector, we should see increased demand in North America. Obviously, we would like to see improvement in OSB pricing as well. With high channel inventories and ready wood in the market, we didn't see an increase in pricing or demand in April. We have taken steps to adjust our production levels to take this into consideration as we focus on meeting our customer commitments while limiting the sale of unprofitable open market wood. Before I turn back to Sallie, let me make a few comments South America. We continue to see high demand in Chile due to increased spending by government on housing. And with the terrible floods in Northern Chile, 24,000 homes were destroyed and we are helping with emergency shelters. We are supplying this currently from brazil. And as you know, we are working on a project to add a third mill into Chile to eliminate the costly freight coming from Brazil. With that, let me turn it back to Sallie for questions.

Was there some sort of catch up from prior quarters or what you ship in the quarter is sustainable level moving forward?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Gail, I'll take that. We did enjoy a very good quarter in Q1. A couple of things there. One, siding is not solely tied to single-family new construction. We have a big repair remodel portion of that. We also have at least 2 SKUs in every Home Depot, Lowe'
componenttext: Gail, I'll take that. We did enjoy a very good quarter in Q1. A couple of things there. One, siding is not solely tied to single-family new construction. We have a big repair remodel portion of that. We also have at least 2 SKUs in every Home Depot, Lowe's and the Nordstrom North America. So we've been exploring those other markets and satisfying the needs there. In the first quarter, little bit of an anomaly is in the repair and model business. They need to prefinish -- we have a series of prefinishers that our customers that then sell directly into the market. Those pre-finishers don't have the capability of finishing enough product to meet the annual demand unless they do it in first quarter. So there is a little bit of a channel fill with the repair remodel part of that, and we enjoy those volumes that went into that market. As far as the sustainability going forward, for the next 2 quarters -- actually, the next 3 quarters, will be constrained until Swan Valley comes online. As Sallie said, we didn't produce any OSB in our siding mills. We ran them basically at capacity, but we also call down our inventories in the first quarter. And we won't have the opportunity to do that for the next couple of quarters.

componenttextpreview: Well it's all anecdotal because there's no firm data out of there. But I was actually with a big customer yesterday, and what they said is they expect the takeaways to be better than they were in a April because of the return of the cold-weather in the No
componenttext: Well it's all anecdotal because there's no firm data out of there. But I was actually with a big customer yesterday, and what they said is they expect the takeaways to be better than they were in a April because of the return of the cold-weather in the Northwest -- Northeast rather, and the rain in the South. They said the last couple of weeks, however, were the warmer weather they are seeing those inventories come down. So I think it's a 3- to 4-week kind of issue that probably started to dissipate a little bit in the middle of last month.

componenttext: Well of the late stage were a little bit of -- I mean if you look at the wood supply in that area overall, we are a little bit of a dip. We should come out of that the next couple of years where the growth should significantly exceed the drain. It's kind of the age classification of the wood there. What we did is we reach further out principally into Canada. And again, we were aided by the Canadian exchange rate, so that helped us a little bit. So we are going to pull in wood from Canada to support those mills  probably for the next couple of years. But then at that point in time, it also depends on what happens with the pulp mills in the area, we would expect to see wood cost to come down a little bit.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think there's 3 things we're looking at. One is to get our wood license back so we can grab that at full capacity when it's needed in the market. Second is, there is enough nongovernmental wood in the area to run that 50% to 60%. So would look at how we
componenttext: I think there's 3 things we're looking at. One is to get our wood license back so we can grab that at full capacity when it's needed in the market. Second is, there is enough nongovernmental wood in the area to run that 50% to 60%. So would look at how we could monitor -- how we could the facility to run at 50% to 60% in OSB and use the other capacity for some other use, and I don't know what that might be. And the third is, we have shown an ability to relocate physical assets in other parts of the world. We would look on Chambord as another opportunity to do that. So that would be the third option.

And I just didn't know if there's any reason not to assume something roughly similar, not asking for specific forecast, but are there factors that might have made the first quarter either unusually strong or -- and therefore, not in the normal pattern?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

componenttext: Well as we just said ship, we have Tomahawk was down part of the first quarter of last year as we increased the capacity there. So we have significant more available capacity in Tomahawk this first quarter than we did last year. In addition to that, we've manufactured probably 40 million square feet of OSB in Hayward last year and we didn't manufacture any this year. So we utilized the increased capacity at Tomahawk plus the conversion of the OSB we're running to siding. So that allowed us to sell more product. And we are gaining traction in the market, there's no question about that. We are seeing single-family new constructions coming back a little bit, we do have presence in the multifamily with that product. And then repair and model and the nonresidential structures have really been the bulk of the growth over the last year.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

componenttext: I see. So what you're sure suggesting not quite the same bump seasonally. But is there also -- us you think about cost going from first to second quarter, obviously, you're dealing with less winter weather and -- but we do hear about wood cost, especially in the Upper Midwest being still elevated. Any thoughts on what you see profitability in that particular segment doing from first to the second?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

componenttext: Well from first to second, as I said, we're probably going to have less volume actually shipped because we ship that inventory in addition to what we produce. So we're going to be constrained on the volume side until Swan Valley comes up in the fourth quarter. On the wood cost, our guys are sating we're going to be probably about that, that would cause we don't see change in Q2. We've been further breakup so we're in pretty good shape of that perspective. So I would volumes modified a little bit, not a lot. I can assure you, if we can produce it, we'll sell it.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're doing couple of things. We are making very smart investment in a line that probably will operational towards the end of the year. When I say small, less than $5 million because we have been shipping products from our Engineered Wood business up
componenttext: Yes, we're doing couple of things. We are making very smart investment in a line that probably will operational towards the end of the year. When I say small, less than $5 million because we have been shipping products from our Engineered Wood business up here down there. And they do think they've got enough demand to begin to run their own. On the OSB side, we applied for the environmental permits last October. We've got the comments from the government in the first quarter January, February. We have now responded to all of those comments, so we'll be entering into, I think it's the end of this week, would enter into a 30-day wait period for the government to hear back on that environmental permit. So we've been doing base engineering, we have acquired used equipment in the market for a portion of that facility. Actually, probably 75% of it we've acquired to date. So the plan is to get the environmental permitting, we'll complete the engineering and we hope to get Board approval with that, for that project in October. And we'll immediately start construction in summer period in South America.

componenttextpreview: Well what's hurting us in Brazil right now is, when we've acquired that mill, most of the product going into Brazil was going into these industrial markets. so was for hoarding material, the construction side it was packaging, it was being used for concre
componenttext: Well what's hurting us in Brazil right now is, when we've acquired that mill, most of the product going into Brazil was going into these industrial markets. so was for hoarding material, the construction side it was packaging, it was being used for concrete forming. And we went in there with the expectation that we could change building practices like we did in Chile and we are, but we're doing that in a much slower rate. With the decline in the Brazilian economy, that core business that we acquired, that's the business declining. We're actually selling more into new home construction, and we're selling more from expert standpoint but we are selling less for the basic with that and corporate because there's less activity going on. So what's been good for us is we've been able to take that excess capacity we have, manufacture the product and ship it to Chile to meet this demand that we have in Chile until we have the new mill operating. But the product in North America, you give all your profits to the shippers of the shipping in Brazil actually from Chile is not any less expensive than shipping out in southern U.S.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation Q1 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms. Sa
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation Q1 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms. Sallie Bailey, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Ma'am, please go ahead.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you very much, Michelle, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the first quarter of 2015. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer, and with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's C
componenttext:
Great. Thank you very much, Michelle, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the first quarter of 2015. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer, and with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's Chief Executive Officer; as well as Mike Kinney; and Becky Barckley, our primary Investor Relations contact.
I will begin the discussion with a review of the financial results for the first quarter of 2015. This will be followed by some comments on the performance of the individual segments and selected balance sheet items. After I finish my remarks, Curt will discuss the general market environment in which LP has been operating, provide his perspective on our operating results and give some thoughts on the outlook. As we have done in the past, we have opened up this call to the public and are doing a webcast. And that webcast can be accessed at www.lpcorp.com. 
Additionally, to help with the discussion, we have provided a presentation with supplemental information that should be reviewed in conjunction with the earnings release. I will be referencing these slides in my comments this morning. We have filed an 8-K this morning with some supplemental information as well as our Form 10-Q. I want to remind all the participants about the forward-looking statements comments on Slide 2 of the presentation. Please also be aware of the discussion of our use of non-GAAP financial information included on Slide 3 of the presentation. The appendix attached to the presentation have some of the necessary reconciliations that has been supplemented by the Form 8-K filing we made this morning. Rather than reading these 2 statements, I incorporated them with this reference.
The housing market was still in recovery mode for the first quarter during 2015. The results in our OSB segment reflects the lower pricing environment, down 13% from last year and impacted the company's financial results for the quarter. The reduction in OSB pricing accounts for approximately $29 million of the change in our operating loss and adjusted EBITDA relative to the first quarter of 2014. The stronger dollar, lower raw material costs, better plant operating performance and the record-setting quarter on our Siding segment offset the impact of the decline in OSB price. 
With that let me go into the details. Moving to Slide 4 of the presentation for a discussion of the first quarter 2015 consolidated results. We are reporting net sales of $472 million for the first quarter of 2015, a 6% increase from the net sales of $445 million reported in the first quarter of 2014. In the first quarter, we recorded a net loss of $35 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.24 as compared to a net loss for the first 3 months of 2014 of $14 million or loss of $0.10 per diluted share. 
Included in our GAAP results for the quarter is $11.6 million write-off of the timber licenses associated with our indefinitely idle Chambord, Québec facility. Given our ongoing losses in Canada, this write-off provides no immediate tax benefit to LP due to our valuation reserves. The Québec Ministry of Forestry terminated our license in the first quarter of 2015, and Curt will discuss this a bit more in more detail in a few minutes. The adjusted loss for quarter was $19 million or loss of $0.13 per diluted share, based upon the normalized tax rate of 35% compared to adjusted loss of $7 million or a loss of $0.05 per diluted share for the first quarter of 2014. 
Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $6 million in the quarter compared to $23 million in the first quarter of 2014. 
I'll move to Slide 5 and review of our segment results. Beginning with our OSB. OSB recorded an operating loss of $28 million on $190 million of sales in the quarter compared to an operating loss of $2 million on $195 million of sales in the first quarter of 2014. For the quarter, we are reporting negative adjusted EBITDA of $13 million compared to positive EBITDA of $12 million in the first quarter of 2014. We have a 14% increase in sales volume and a 4% increase in the OSB segment's production. Pricing for OSB was down 13% over the first quarter of 2014. The decrease in pricing resulted in lower operating results by about $29 million. OSB segment took 127 down days or the equivalent of just under 200 million square feet of reduced production during the quarter. 
Despite the significant number of down days, our cost of sales per MSF improved relative to the first quarter of 2014, as well as the fourth quarter of 2014, due to the impacts of the weaker Canadian dollar, lower raw material costs and improved operating performance at our Clarke County facility. 
Slide 6 reports the results of the Siding segment. This segment includes our SmartSide and CanExel siding products. The first quarter of 2015 was a record quarter for the Siding segment for sales, operating income and adjusted EBITDA. The Siding segment reported sales of $174 million in the first quarter of 2015, an increase of 21% from $144 million reported in the first quarter of 2014. The Siding segment reported operating income of $33 million compared to $19 million in the first quarter of 2014, and adjusted EBITDA of $38 million as compared to $24 million in the same quarter of 2014. For the second quarter in a row, the Siding segment did not produce any OSB. 
Consistent with the past several quarters, the Siding segment continue to experience higher wood cost. However, we are able to acquire logs, run our facility as planned and took no downtime in the quarter related to log shortages. The higher wood costs in the first quarter of 2015 were partially offset by lower resin costs and improved absorption in our manufacturing facility. The results for the quarter were also positively impacted by improved product mix and higher sales volume. 
For the quarter, SmartSide average sale prices were up 8% and volumes increased 19%. Volumes increased in our SmartSide siding line due to continued penetration in several key focus markets, including retail, repair and remodel and markets and sheds. CanExel prices were flat in U.S. dollars, so were the prices were up 12% in Canadian dollars, which is CanExel's primary market. Volumes were down 18% in the quarter, due to decreases in Canadian and international demand. 
Please turn to Slide 7 of the presentation, which shows the results for our Engineered Wood Products segment. The segment includes I-Joist, Laminated Strand Lumber, Laminated Veneer Lumber plus other related products. This segment also includes the sale of our I-Joist and LVL products produced by the Abitibi joint venture are under our sales arrangement with Murphy Plywood. 
The EWP segment did produce 10 million square feet of OSB in the first quarter of 2015 under the Houlton, Maine facility. 
The Engineered Wood Products segment recorded sales of $65 million in the first quarter of 2015, up from $62 million in the first quarter of 2014. The segment's operating loss in the first quarter of 2015 was $4 million as compared to a loss of $3 million in the first quarter of 2014. 
For the first quarter of 2015, adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations declined to a negative $400,000 as compared to a positive adjusted EBITDA of $1.3 million in the first quarter of 2014. Volumes of I-Joist were down 12%, primarily due to lower volumes in Western Canada. While volumes of LVL and LSL were up 16% compared to the same quarter of last year, as we focus more on exports and industrial markets. 
Pricing was up 6% in the I-Joist and down 3% in LVL and LSL. The increase in I-Joist reflects price increases introduced to offset rising raw material costs during 2014. The decline in LVL and LSL reflects changes in mix through a higher percentage of industrial uses, which are sold at a lower price. 
Turning to Slide 8 of the presentation. For the quarter, our South American segment recorded sales of $36 million as compared to $37 million in the first quarter of 2014. Operating income was $2 million in the first quarter of 2015 compared to $4 million in the first quarter of 2014. South America's adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $5 million for the first quarter of 2014 as compared to $7 million in the first quarter of 2014. 
Volumes in the quarter were up 31% and lower by 18% in Brazil compared to the same quarter of last year. The sales volume increase in Chile was primarily due to improved housing demand. In Brazil, the reduction in sales volume was due to the economic recession, which led to loss of demand. Pricing was down 13% in Chile and down 16% in Brazil. And in local currency, Chile's pricing is lower by 1% compared with the same quarter in 2014, and Brazil recorded a 3% improvement in pricing. 
Total SG&A costs were $39 million in the first quarter of 2015 compared to $41 million in the same quarter of 2014. For the quarter, the reduction in SG&A costs is primarily related to legal costs incurred in 2014 associated with the aborted Ainsworth transaction. We recorded $2 million of foreign exchange loss in the quarter compared to $4 million loss in the same quarter of last year. And net interest expense was flat between quarters. 
Please refer to Slide 9 of the presentation. As of March 31, 2015, we have cash, cash equivalents, investments and restricted cash of $483 million, working capital of $742 million, net cash of $114 million, and in addition to the $483 million of cash on our balance sheet, we have $200 million availability on our credit facility. March year-to-date capital expenditures were $15 million. We do expect capital expenditures for 2015 to be in the range of $120 million to $130 million, with over half of this amount related to the Swan Valley mill conversion. We did not repurchase any shares of LP's stock during the quarter, but we do continue to evaluate opportunities to repurchase shares, along with other uses of the company's capital. Now I will turn the call over to Curt for his comments.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sallie, for that review. Good morning to all of you and thanks for joining us on the call. Let me start with LP's safety performance. Last week, the APA announced the results of their safety and health awards program for 2014. I'm pleased that LP
componenttext:
Thanks, Sallie, for that review. Good morning to all of you and thanks for joining us on the call. Let me start with LP's safety performance. Last week, the APA announced the results of their safety and health awards program for 2014. I'm pleased that LP was named the Safest Large Company in our industry for the year. This is the fifth time we have been so recognized in the last 7 years. We also had 10 facilities included in the Incident Free Honor Society. I'm very proud of all of our employees who recognize the value of being safe and act accordingly. 
In addition to the obvious savings in Worker's Compensation costs, LP believes that our safety culture gives us the competitive edge in the hiring and retention of our employees. 
This morning I'll provide a few comments on the results of the first quarter, talk about the state of the housing market and give you my views for the next several quarters. After that, I'll turn the call back to Sallie for questions. 
With 2 notable exceptions that negatively affected our results, OSB pricing and the write-off of the wood license, LP actually had a pretty good quarter. Let me just start with quick review of the 2 negative items. OSB pricing has fallen below analyst's projections for the last 6 quarters, and Random Lengths, North Central was 12%, an already low 2014 pricing level. The easy scapegoat in Q1 is always the weather. While I know this did have an impact, the primary driver of lower pricing was more available supply than demand. As a result, we had to take significant downtime in our mills in the quarter. 
In Q2, we continue to evaluate and take market-related downtime as the recovery in new residential demand has been short of economists projections. Further, while we are meeting our commitments to our customers, they're also aggressively exploring other applications beyond single-family new construction. These areas include repair and remodeling, industrial, transportation and modest exports. 
Let me give you some background to Chambord wood license. We indefinitely curtailed production at the Chambord, Québec mill in 2008 as the great recession whacked housing. Over the intervening years, we have been a regular contact with Québec government and we've met all of our mutually agreed upon obligations to retain the license. Over the last year, there's been increasing pressure to use the wood to create jobs in the area. Unfortunately, the government decided that they would now wait for LP to restart the mill and informed us quarter that they had canceled our wood license. They will be setting up a project office to review alternative proposals for the wood. We'll be a part of this process and believe that the LP mill is still the best alternative to use the wood in the area. We do have other options for these assets, who are also being exploring. As to the write-off, the accounting rules dictated that we take a noncash charge for the carrying value of the wood license. 
On the positive side, as Sallie mentioned, our Siding business had a record quarter, SmartSide shipments, revenue and EBITDA. We did enjoy lower resin costs in Q1 and the lower Canadian dollar made our operations north of the border more competitive. Efforts to fully convert our Swan Valley to SmartSide production are underway, with initial production expected in Q4 of this year. 
Next, let me just share some views on the housing market. As you know, there are mountains of data on the future of the housing market that are confusing, sometimes conflicting and definitely frustrating. My bottom line housing is improving, but not at the pace forecast by most economists. Here are some numbers on expected housing starts. The consensus forecast for this year is 1.153 million, which would represent a 15% increase over 2014. Consensus forecast for 2016 stands at 1.36 million, which is a further 18% increase on the forecast for this year. At LP, as I mentioned last quarter, we forecast 1.1 million housing starts for 2015 and I believe that still works like a reasonable number. In 2016, we expect a 10% to 15% improvement in starts. 
Other positive housing-related news, household formations accelerated in Q4 to 1.7 million and all that up was about 1.5 million in Q1 of this year. This is much better than the anemic 400,000 to 500,000 pace of the last several years. And when the household is formed, it's usually means that a home is occupied, which is good news for the industry. A Deutsche Bank economist just published following tidbit which might be of interest. The number of people per household returns to the 2000 to 2003 level, this would lead to 4 million new households, a very positive for housing looking forward. 
Mortgage rates remain below 4%, the inventory of new and existing homes for sale is shrinking and most of the big boulders who have reported first quarter results have mentioned a strong spring selling season. Repair/remodel expenditures are expected to be strong and the rental vacancy rate is at the lowest level in 20 years. 
So what does this all mean for LP in the next several quarters? With spring finally happening in most of the country and positive momentum in the housing sector, we should see increased demand in North America. Obviously, we would like to see improvement in OSB pricing as well. With high channel inventories and ready wood in the market, we didn't see an increase in pricing or demand in April. We have taken steps to adjust our production levels to take this into consideration as we focus on meeting our customer commitments while limiting the sale of unprofitable open market wood. Before I turn back to Sallie, let me make a few comments on South America. We continue to see high demand in Chile due to increased spending by the government on housing. And with the terrible floods in Northern Chile, 24,000 homes were destroyed and we are helping with emergency shelters. We are supplying this demand currently from Brazil. And as you know, we are working on a project to add a third mill into Chile to eliminate the costly freight coming from Brazil. With that, let me turn it back over to Sallie for questions.

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Gail Glazerman with UBS.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you give maybe a little bit more color on the strength in Siding, particularly looking at close to 20% volume growth on top of what I think this double-digit growth last year? Is -- was there some sort of catch up from prior quarters or what you ship
componenttext: Can you give maybe a little bit more color on the strength in Siding, particularly looking at close to 20% volume growth on top of what I think this double-digit growth last year? Is -- was there some sort of catch up from prior quarters or what you ship in the quarter is at sustainable level moving forward?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Gail, I'll take that. We did enjoy a very good quarter in Q1. A couple of things there. One, Siding is not solely tied to single-family new construction. We have a big repair/remodel portion of that. And we also have at least 2 SKUs in every Home Depot, L
componenttext: Gail, I'll take that. We did enjoy a very good quarter in Q1. A couple of things there. One, Siding is not solely tied to single-family new construction. We have a big repair/remodel portion of that. And we also have at least 2 SKUs in every Home Depot, Lowe's and the Nordstrom, North America. So we've been exploring those other markets and satisfying the needs there. In the first quarter, a little bit of an anomaly is in the repair/remodel business. They need to pre-finish, we have a series of pre-finishers that are our customers that then sell directly into the market. Those pre-finishers don't have the capability of finishing enough product to meet the annual demand unless they do it in first quarter. So there is a little bit of a channel fill for the repair/remodel part of that, and we enjoyed those volumes that went into that market. As far as the sustainability going forward, for the next 2 quarters -- actually, the next 3 quarters will be constrained until Swan Valley comes online. As Sallie said, we didn't produce any OSB in our siding mills. We ran them basically at capacity, but we also pulled down our inventories in the first quarter. And we won't have the opportunity to do that for the next couple of quarters.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd add one other thing, Gail, just to remind you that we did have a Tomahawk expansion last year, so we increased the capacity in our Siding business last year with that project.
componenttext: I'd add one other thing, Gail, just to remind you that we did have a Tomahawk expansion last year, so we increased the capacity in our Siding business last year with that project.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Curt, can you expand a little bit on the comments about inventory channels being pretty full and ready availability? Is your -- I mean, just how full do you think they are? I think, are they full like ahead of a normal seasonal spring building s
componenttext: Okay. And Curt, can you expand a little bit on the comments about inventory channels being pretty full and ready availability? Is your -- I mean, just how full do you think they are? I think, are they full like ahead of a normal seasonal spring building season or of a little bit chunkier than that?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's all anecdotal because there's no firm data out of there. But I was actually with a big customer yesterday, and what they said is they expect the takeaways to be better than they were in April because of the return of the cold-weather in
componenttext: Well, I think it's all anecdotal because there's no firm data out of there. But I was actually with a big customer yesterday, and what they said is they expect the takeaways to be better than they were in April because of the return of the cold-weather in the Northwest and the rain in the South -- our Northeast weather and the rain in the South. They've said the last couple of weeks, however, were the warmer weather they are seeing those inventories come down. So I think it's a 3- to 4-week kind of issue that probably started to dissipate a little bit in the middle of last month.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And can you talk a little bit about the wood situational late state, I guess, you're able to get wood, this is just a question of what cost? And is there any line of sight for those costs normalizing?
componenttext: Okay. And can you talk a little bit about the wood situational late state, I guess, you're able to get wood, this is just a question of what cost? And is there any line of sight for those costs normalizing?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the late state, we're in a little bit of -- I mean, if you look at the wood supply in that area overall, we're in a little bit of a dip. We should come out of that in the next couple of years, where the growth should significantly exceed the drain.
componenttext: Well, the late state, we're in a little bit of -- I mean, if you look at the wood supply in that area overall, we're in a little bit of a dip. We should come out of that in the next couple of years, where the growth should significantly exceed the drain. It's kind of the age classification of the wood there. What we did is we reached further out principally into Canada. And again, we were aided by the Canadian exchange rate, so that helped us a little bit. So we are going to pull in wood from Canada to support those mills, probably for the next couple of years. But then at that point in time, it also depends on what happens with the pulp mills in the area. We would expect to see wood cost to come down a little bit.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And on Chambord, when you're talking about other option, does that other option do you think your wood for the facility? Should you started or is that just other option facility other than keeping it at something that could revert?
componenttext: Okay. And on Chambord, when you're talking about other option, does that other option do you think your wood for the facility? Should you started or is that just other option facility other than keeping it at something that could revert?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think there's 3 things we're looking at. One is to get our wood license back, so we can run that at full capacity when it's needed in the market. Second is, there is enough nongovernmental wood in the area to run that 50% to 60%. So would look at how we
componenttext: I think there's 3 things we're looking at. One is to get our wood license back, so we can run that at full capacity when it's needed in the market. Second is, there is enough nongovernmental wood in the area to run that 50% to 60%. So would look at how we could monitor -- how we could modify the facility to run at 50% to 60% on OSB and use the other capacity for some other use, and I don't know what that might be. And the third is, we have shown an ability to relocate physical assets in other parts of the world. We would look at Chambord as another opportunity to do that. So that would be the third option.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just quickly on quarter, I think, you had indicated based on oil prices to be, I think, $40 million to $50 million benefit this year. Is that still your view? And if not, can you give an updated estimate?
componenttext: Okay. And then just quickly on quarter, I think, you had indicated based on oil prices to be, I think, $40 million to $50 million benefit this year. Is that still your view? And if not, can you give an updated estimate?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: That is our current view, it's $50 million number.
componenttext: That is our current view, it's $50 million number.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon with Vertical Research partners.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon with Vertical Research partners.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: A question about that is, as we go, if we look at the last 3 years, there does seem to be a seasonal element there. And I know that could've been influenced by the fact, you used to make more commodity OSB in that segment. But at any rate, it looks like t
componenttext: A question about that is, as we go, if we look at the last 3 years, there does seem to be a seasonal element there. And I know that could've been influenced by the fact, you used to make more commodity OSB in that segment. But at any rate, it looks like the seasonal rise in revenue has been roughly $20 million from the first to the second quarter. And I just didn't know if there's any reason not to assume something roughly similar, not asking for specific forecast, but are there factors that might have made the first quarter either unusually strong or -- and therefore, not in the normal pattern?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as we just said Chip, we had Tomahawk was down a part of the first quarter of last year as we increased the capacity there. So we had significantly more available capacity in Tomahawk this first quarter than we did last year. In addition to that, we
componenttext: Well, as we just said Chip, we had Tomahawk was down a part of the first quarter of last year as we increased the capacity there. So we had significantly more available capacity in Tomahawk this first quarter than we did last year. In addition to that, we've manufactured probably 40 million square feet of OSB in Hayward last year and we didn't manufacture any this year. So we utilized the increased capacity at Tomahawk plus the conversion of the OSB we're running to Siding. So that allowed us to sell more product. And we are gaining traction in the market, there's no question about that. We are seeing single-family new construction is coming back a little bit, we do have presence in the multifamily with that product. And then repair/remodel and the nonresidential structures have really been the bulk of the growth over the last year.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I see. So what you're sort of suggesting is not quite the same bump seasonally. But is there also -- as you think about cost going from first to second quarter, obviously, you're dealing with less winter weather and -- but we do hear about wood costs, esp
componenttext: I see. So what you're sort of suggesting is not quite the same bump seasonally. But is there also -- as you think about cost going from first to second quarter, obviously, you're dealing with less winter weather and -- but we do hear about wood costs, especially in the Upper Midwest being still elevated. Any thoughts on what you see profitability in that particular segment doing from first to the second?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, from first to second, as I said, we're probably going to have less volume actually shipped because we ship that inventory in addition to what we produce. So we're going to be constrained on the volume side until Swan Valley comes up in the fourth qu
componenttext: Well, from first to second, as I said, we're probably going to have less volume actually shipped because we ship that inventory in addition to what we produce. So we're going to be constrained on the volume side until Swan Valley comes up in the fourth quarter. On the woods cost, our guys are saying, we're going to be probably above flat of wood costs. We don't see any big change in Q2. We've planned for the breakup, so we're in pretty good shape from that perspective. So I would -- volumes modified a little bit, not a lot. I can assure you, if we can produce it, we'll sell it.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And could you just update us quickly on what you're doing in South America at this point. I know, I believe you're building something down there as well or moving a plant down there as well.
componenttext: And could you just update us quickly on what you're doing in South America at this point. I know, I believe you're building something down there as well or moving a plant down there as well.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're doing couple of things. One, we are making a very small investment in I-Joist line, that probably will operational towards the end of the year. When I say small, less than $5 million because we have been shipping products from our Engineered Wo
componenttext: Yes. We're doing couple of things. One, we are making a very small investment in I-Joist line, that probably will operational towards the end of the year. When I say small, less than $5 million because we have been shipping products from our Engineered Wood business up here, down there. And they do think they've got enough demand to begin to run their own. On the OSB side, we applied for the environmental permits last October. We've got the comments from the government in the first quarter of January, February. We have now responded to all of those comments, so we'll be entering into, I think it's the end of this week, we'll enter into a 30-day wait period for the government to hear back on that environmental permit. So we've been doing base engineering, we have acquired used equipment in the market for a portion of that facility. Actually, probably 75% of it we've acquired to date. So the plan is soon to get the environmental permitting, we'll complete the engineering and we hope to give Board approval with that, for that project in October. And we'll immediately start construction in summer period in South America.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And maybe you want startup like second quarter of next year, would that be a good guess or maybe later?
componenttext: And maybe you want startup like second quarter of next year, would that be a good guess or maybe later?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: It can't be later than that. It's probably a 9- to 12-month construction period, so probably be towards the end of 2016.
componenttext: It can't be later than that. It's probably a 9- to 12-month construction period, so probably be towards the end of 2016.

componenttext: It's -- we did look at it. Chambord doesn't have rail, which makes it a little bit hard from a logistic standpoint. What's nice about Swan is, it does have rail service directly there. The other is that the wood species mix and Swan is better for -- we consider better for our siding product than the mix in Chambord. Chambord needs to be in OSB mill.

componenttext: Got you. That's helpful. And then coming back to Siding, obviously, it was a very good quarter. You talked about how volumes could be down a little bit. But just looking out a little bit on a medium-term basis, do you think margins in the 20% range are achievable, if you go back on the housing starts at 1.4, 1.5?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I certainly think they're achievable, yes.
componenttext: I certainly think they're achievable, yes.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Bill Hoffmann with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Curt, can you just talk a little bit more about what's going on down in Latin America? You would do a weakness in Brazil? You guys able to operate there, you're pushing product out of market, what's the strategy?
componenttext: Curt, can you just talk a little bit more about what's going on down in Latin America? You would do a weakness in Brazil? You guys able to operate there, you're pushing product out of market, what's the strategy?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, what's hurting us in Brazil right now is, when we've acquired that mill, most of the product going into Brazil was going into these industrial markets. So was for hoarding material, the construction side it was on packaging, it was being used for co
componenttext: Well, what's hurting us in Brazil right now is, when we've acquired that mill, most of the product going into Brazil was going into these industrial markets. So was for hoarding material, the construction side it was on packaging, it was being used for concrete forming. And we went in there with the expectation that we could change building practices like we did in Chile and we are, but we're doing that at a much slower rate. With the decline in the Brazilian economy, that core business that we've acquired, that's the business declining. We're actually selling more into new home construction, and we're selling more from an export standpoint, but we are selling less for the basic courting material on concrete form because there's less activity going on. So the -- what's been good for us is, we've been able to take that excess capacity we have, manufacture the product and ship it to Chile to meet this demand that we have in Chile until we have the new mill operating. But similar to providing product from North America, you give all your profits to the shipper, so we're shipping in from Brazil that actually Chile is not any less expensive than shipping that out in Southern U.S.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. That at least it allow you to run those plants, right?
componenttext: Great. That at least it allow you to run those plants, right?

componenttextpreview: So we're running the plant and we're making contribution from our absorption standpoint, but we're not putting the profitability in that we need to.
componenttext: So we're running the plant and we're making contribution from our absorption standpoint, but we're not putting the profitability in that we need to.

componenttext: Got you. Okay. And then just on the OSB side, one of the things we talked about before is it diversifying  your OSB. I mean, obviously, Siding has been a great end market, but could you just talk a little bit more about what other end markets you feel like you've been able to move products into and what percent of sales you are at this point and what the target might be?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I can't give you the sales breakdown because I don't have it in front of me. But we've been successful probably right after the great recession started, we've started focusing on the furniture market and we've been successful in several manufacturers ther
componenttext:
I can't give you the sales breakdown because I don't have it in front of me. But we've been successful probably right after the great recession started, we've started focusing on the furniture market and we've been successful in several manufacturers there. As OSB actually provides a better product for the frame of couches and chairs than plywood does. As we've had some success there, we've had success in the transportation market. That's pretty broad, that's the inside of trailers, inside of trucks, the inside of containers. As we've had some success there, I know those are the principal areas. We are as I said continuing to look at other industrial occupations that may have an opportunity.
You can provide -- you can put a surface on the OSB, that will actually increase its usefulness.

componenttext: Okay. Any sense of how much of your product can go into those other markets or are they going to those other markets? I mean the last quarter of the sales...

componenttext: It's not that big right now. It's probably 10%, 5% to 10% right now. But we do think that there's the opportunity to grow that. The export market hasn't been that attractive to us with the strong dollar. But that sort of export business, so it's down a little bit.

componenttext: Okay. And then just in Engineered Wood Products, the decline I-Joist in Q1, what's your outlook for that is that market balanced here in Q2 or...

componenttextpreview: It was almost all in Western Canada, it was all pricing. Because we produce that in California, and ship it to Canada and 80% rate to dollar. The local producers have a huge advantage and we just didn't want to take a loss.
componenttext: It was almost all in Western Canada, it was all pricing. Because we produce that in California, and ship it to Canada and 80% rate to dollar. The local producers have a huge advantage and we just didn't want to take a loss.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We did the expansion at Two Harbors in 2013, we added about 25% capacity. That was a smaller mill, it was like 127, I think we've added 25 million, 30 million square feet there. And that is -- we're producing all of that. In the Tomahawk, it was about 50%
componenttext: We did the expansion at Two Harbors in 2013, we added about 25% capacity. That was a smaller mill, it was like 127, I think we've added 25 million, 30 million square feet there. And that is -- we're producing all of that. In the Tomahawk, it was about 50% expansion, so we probably went from 130 million to 190 million square feet.

componenttext: We expect to get it back. I think the premier is from the lake Sanguine area, so it's very sensitive to the jobs in the area. Resolute is the other big user in the area and they're our partner in the JV and they think it would be right thing to do to restart Chambord. We provide the web stock by truck for those operations. So it's very convenient from a JV standpoint.
