headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corp Q1 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms. Sallie Ba
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corp Q1 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms. Sallie Bailey, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Ma'am, please go ahead.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you very much, Michelle, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the first quarter of 2015. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer, and with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's C
componenttext:
Great. Thank you very much, Michelle, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the first quarter of 2015. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer, and with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's Chief Executive Officer; as well as Mike Kinney; and Becky Barckley, our primary Investor Relations contact.
I will begin the discussion with a review of the financial results for the first quarter of 2015. This will be followed by some comments on the performance of the individual segments and selected balance sheet items. After I finish my remarks, Curt will discuss the general market environment in which LP has been operating, provide his perspective on our operating results and give some thoughts on the outlook. As we have done in the past, we have opened up this call to the public and are doing a webcast. And that webcast can be accessed at www.lpcorp.com. 
Additionally, to help with the discussion, we have provided a presentation with supplemental information that should be reviewed in conjunction with the earnings release. I will be referencing these slides in my comments this morning. We have filed an 8-K this morning with some supplemental information as well as our Form 10-Q. I want to remind all the participants about the forward-looking statements comments on Slide 2 of the presentation. Please also be aware of the discussion of our use of non-GAAP financial information included on Slide 3 of the presentation. The appendix attached to the presentation have some of the necessary reconciliations that has been supplemented by the Form 8-K filing we made this morning. Rather than reading these 2 statements, I incorporate them with this reference.
The housing market was still in recovery mode for the first quarter during 2015. The results in our OSB segment reflect the lower pricing environment, down 13% from last year and impacted the company's financial results for the quarter. The reduction in OSB pricing accounted for approximately $29 million of the change in our operating loss and adjusted EBITDA relative to the first quarter of 2014. The stronger dollar, lower raw material costs, better plant operating performance and a record-setting quarter on our Siding segment offset the impact of the decline in OSB price. 
With that let me go into the details. Moving to Slide 4 of the presentation for a discussion of the first quarter 2015 consolidated results. We are reporting net sales of $472 million for the first quarter of 2015, a 6% increase from the net sales of $445 million reported in the first quarter of 2014. In the first quarter, we recorded a net loss of $35 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.24 as compared to a net loss for the first 3 months of 2014 of $14 million or a loss of $0.10 per diluted share. 
Included in our GAAP results for the quarter is $11.6 million write-off of the timber licenses associated with our indefinitely idle Chambord, Québec facility. Given our ongoing losses in Canada, this write-off provides no immediate tax benefit to LP due to our valuation reserves. The Québec Ministry of Forestry terminated our license in the first quarter of 2015, and Curt will discuss this a bit more in more detail in a few minutes. The adjusted loss for the quarter was $19 million or a loss of $0.13 per diluted share, based upon the normalized tax rate of 35% compared to adjusted loss of $7 million or a loss of $0.05 per diluted share for the first quarter of 2014. 
Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $6 million in the quarter compared to $23 million in the first quarter of 2014. 
I'll move to Slide 5, a review of our segment results. Beginning with OSB. OSB recorded an operating loss of $28 million on $190 million of sales in the quarter compared to an operating loss of $2 million on $195 million of sales in the first quarter of 2014. For the quarter, we are reporting negative adjusted EBITDA of $13 million compared to positive EBITDA of $12 million in the first quarter of 2014. We have a 14% increase in sales volume and a 4% increase in the OSB segment's production. Pricing for OSB was down 13% over the first quarter of 2014. The decrease in pricing resulted in lower operating results by about $29 million. The OSB segment took 127 down days or the equivalent of just under 200 million square feet of reduced production during the quarter. 
Despite the significant number of down days, our cost of sales per MSF improved relative to the first quarter of 2014, as well as the fourth quarter of 2014, due to the impact of the weaker Canadian dollar, lower raw material costs and improved operating performance at our Clarke County facility. 
Slide 6 reports the results of the Siding segment. This segment includes our SmartSide and CanExel siding products. The first quarter of 2015 was a record quarter for the Siding segment for sales, operating income and adjusted EBITDA. The Siding segment reported sales of $174 million in the first quarter of 2015, an increase of 21% from $144 million reported in the first quarter of 2014. The Siding segment reported operating income of $33 million compared to $19 million in the first quarter of 2014, and adjusted EBITDA of $38 million as compared to $24 million in the same quarter of 2014. For the second quarter in a row, the Siding segment did not produce any OSB. 
Consistent with the past several quarters, the Siding segment continued to experience higher wood costs. However, we were able to acquire logs, run our facility as planned and took no downtime in the quarter related to log shortages. The higher wood costs in the first quarter of 2015 were partially offset by lower resin costs and improved absorption in our manufacturing facility. The results for the quarter were also positively impacted by improved product mix and higher sales volume. 
For the quarter, SmartSide average sale prices were up 8% and volumes increased 19%. Volumes increased in our SmartSide siding line due to continued penetration in several key focus markets, including retail, repair and remodel and markets and sheds. CanExel prices were flat in U.S. dollars, however prices were up 12% in Canadian dollars, which is CanExel's primary market. Volumes were down 18% in the quarter, due to decreases in Canadian and international demand. 
Please turn to Slide 7 of the presentation, which shows the results for our Engineered Wood Products segment. This segment includes I-Joist, Laminated Strand Lumber, Laminated Veneer Lumber plus other related products. This segment also includes the sale of I-Joist and LVL products produced by the Abitibi joint venture are under our sales arrangement with Murphy Plywood. 
The EWP segment did produce 10 million square feet of OSB in the first quarter of 2015 under the Houlton, Maine facility. 
The Engineered Wood Products segment recorded sales of $65 million in the first quarter of 2015, up from $62 million in the first quarter of 2014. The segment's operating loss in the first quarter of 2015 was $4 million as compared to a loss of $3 million in the first quarter of 2014. 
For the first quarter of 2015, adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations declined to a negative $400,000 as compared to a positive adjusted EBITDA of $1.3 million in the first quarter of 2014. Volumes of I-Joist were down 12%, primarily due to lower volumes in Western Canada. While volumes of LVL and LSL were up 16% compared to the same quarter last year, as we focused more on exports and industrial markets. 
Pricing was up 6% in I-Joist and down 3% in LVL and LSL. The increase in I-Joist reflects price increases introduced to offset rising raw material costs during 2014. The decline in LVL and LSL reflects changes in mix through a higher percentage of industrial uses, which are sold at a lower price. 
Turning to Slide 8 of the presentation. For the quarter, our South American segment recorded sales of $36 million as compared to $37 million in the first quarter of 2014. Operating income was $2 million in the first quarter of 2015 compared to $4 million in the first quarter of 2014. South America's adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $5 million for the first quarter of 2014 as compared to $7 million in the first quarter of 2014. 
Volumes in the quarter were up 31% and lower by 18% in Brazil compared to the same quarter last year. The sales volume increase in Chile was primarily due to improved housing demand. In Brazil, the reduction in sales volume was due to the economic recession, which led to loss of demand. Pricing was down 13% in Chile and down 16% in Brazil. And in local currency, Chile's pricing was lower by 1% compared with the same quarter in 2014, and Brazil recorded a 3% improvement in pricing. 
Total SG&A costs were $39 million in the first quarter of 2015 compared to $41 million in the same quarter of 2014. For the quarter, the reduction in SG&A costs is primarily related to legal costs incurred in 2014 associated with the aborted Ainsworth transaction. We recorded $2 million of foreign exchange loss in the quarter compared to $4 million loss in the same quarter of last year. And net interest expense was flat between quarters. 
Please refer to Slide 9 of the presentation. As of March 31, 2015, we have cash, cash equivalents, investments and restricted cash of $483 million, working capital of $742 million, net cash of $114 million, and in addition to the $483 million of cash on our balance sheet, we have $200 million availability on our credit facility. March year-to-date capital expenditures were $15 million. We do expect capital expenditures for 2015 to be in the range of $120 million to $130 million, with over half of this amount related to the Swan Valley mill conversion. We did not repurchase any shares of LP's stock during the quarter, but we do continue to evaluate opportunities to repurchase shares, along with other uses of the company's capital. Now I will turn the call over to Curt for his comments.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sallie, for that review. Good morning to all of you and thanks for joining us on the call. Let me start with LP's safety performance. Last week, the APA announced the results of their safety and health awards program for 2014. I'm pleased that LP
componenttext:
Thanks, Sallie, for that review. Good morning to all of you and thanks for joining us on the call. Let me start with LP's safety performance. Last week, the APA announced the results of their safety and health awards program for 2014. I'm pleased that LP was named the Safest Large Company in our industry for the year. This is the fifth time we have been so recognized in the last 7 years. We also had 10 facilities included in the Incident Free Honor Society. I'm very proud of all of our employees who recognize the value of being safe and act accordingly. 
In addition to the obvious savings in Worker's Compensation costs, LP believes that our safety culture gives us a competitive edge in the hiring and retention of our employees. 
This morning I'll provide a few comments on the results of the first quarter, talk about the state of the housing market and give you my views for the next several quarters. After that, I'll turn the call back to Sallie for questions. 
With 2 notable exceptions that negatively affected our results, OSB pricing and the write-off of the wood license, LP actually had a pretty good quarter. Let me just start with a quick review of the 2 negative items. OSB pricing has fallen below analysts’ projections for the last 6 quarters, and Random Lengths, North Central was 12%, an already low 2014 pricing level. The easy scapegoat in Q1 is always the weather. While I know this did have an impact, the primary driver of lower pricing was more available supply than demand. As a result, we had to take significant downtime in our mills in the quarter. 
In Q2, we continue to evaluate and take market-related downtime as the recovery in new residential demand has been short of economists’ projections. Further, while we are meeting our commitments to our customers, they're also aggressively exploring other applications beyond single-family new construction. These areas include repair and remodeling, industrial, transportation and modest exports. 
Let me give you some background to the Chambord wood license. We indefinitely curtailed production at the Chambord, Québec mill in 2008 as the great recession whacked housing. Over the intervening years, we have been a regular contact with the Québec government and we've met all of our mutually agreed upon obligations to retain the license. Over the last year, there's been increasing pressure to use the wood to create jobs in the area. Unfortunately, the government decided that they would not wait for LP to restart the mill and informed us last quarter that they had canceled our wood license. They will be setting up a project office to review alternative proposals for the wood. We'll be a part of this process and believe that the LP mill is still the best alternative to use the wood in the area. We do have other options for these assets we will also be exploring. As to the write-off, the accounting rules dictated that we take a noncash charge for the carrying value of the wood license. 
On the positive side, as Sallie mentioned, our Siding business had a record quarter, SmartSide shipments, revenue and EBITDA. We did enjoy lower resin costs in Q1 and the lower Canadian dollar made our operations north of the border more competitive. Efforts to fully convert our Swan Valley mill to SmartSide production are underway, with initial production expected in Q4 of this year. 
Next, let me just share some views on the housing market. As you know, there are mountains of data on the future of the housing market that are confusing, sometimes conflicting and definitely frustrating. My bottom line is that housing is improving, but not at the pace forecast by most economists. Here are some numbers on expected housing starts. The consensus forecast for this year is 1.153 million, which would represent a 15% increase over 2014. Consensus forecast for 2016 stands at 1.36 million, which is a further 18% increase on the forecast for this year. At LP, as I mentioned last quarter, we forecast 1.1 million housing starts for 2015 and I believe that still looks like a reasonable number. In 2016, we expect a 10% to 15% improvement in starts. 
Other positive housing-related news, household formations accelerated in Q4 to 1.7 million and all that up was about 1.5 million in Q1 of this year. This is much better than the anemic 400,000 to 500,000 pace of the last several years. And when a household is formed, this usually means that a home is occupied, which is good news for our industry. A Deutsche Bank economist just published the following tidbit, which might be of interest. The number of people per household returns to the 2000 to 2003 level, this would lead to 4 million new households, a very positive for housing looking forward. 
Mortgage rates remain below 4%, the inventory of new and existing homes for sale is shrinking and most of the big builders who have reported first quarter results have mentioned a strong spring selling season. Repair/remodel expenditures are expected to be strong and the rental vacancy rate is at the lowest level in 20 years. 
So what does this all mean for LP in the next several quarters? With spring finally happening in most of the country and positive momentum in the housing sector, we should see increased demand in North America. Obviously, we would like to see improvement in OSB pricing as well. With high channel inventories and ready wood in the market, we didn't see an increase in pricing or demand in April. We have taken steps to adjust our production levels to take this into consideration as we focus on meeting our customer commitments while limiting the sale of unprofitable open market wood. 
Before I turn back to Sallie, let me make a few comments on South America. We continue to see high demand in Chile due to increased spending by the government on housing. And with the terrible floods in Northern Chile, 24,000 homes were destroyed and we are helping with emergency shelters. We are supplying this demand currently from Brazil. And as you know, we are working on a project to add a third mill into Chile to eliminate the costly freight coming from Brazil. With that, let me turn it back over to Sallie for questions.

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Gail Glazerman with UBS.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you give maybe a little bit more color on the strength in Siding, particularly looking at close to 20% volume growth on top of what I think was double-digit growth last year? Is -- was there some sort of catch-up from prior quarters, or what you shipp
componenttext: Can you give maybe a little bit more color on the strength in Siding, particularly looking at close to 20% volume growth on top of what I think was double-digit growth last year? Is -- was there some sort of catch-up from prior quarters, or what you shipped in the quarter is a sustainable level moving forward?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Gail, I'll take that. We did enjoy a very good quarter in Q1. A couple of things there. One, Siding is not solely tied to single-family new construction. We have a big repair/remodel portion of that. And we also have at least 2 SKUs in every Home Depot, L
componenttext: Gail, I'll take that. We did enjoy a very good quarter in Q1. A couple of things there. One, Siding is not solely tied to single-family new construction. We have a big repair/remodel portion of that. And we also have at least 2 SKUs in every Home Depot, Lowe's and yard [ph] store in North America. So we've been exploring those other markets and satisfying the needs there. In the first quarter, and a little bit of an anomaly, is in the repair/remodel business. They need to pre-finish, we have a series of pre-finishers that are our customers that then sell directly into the market. Those pre-finishers don't have the capability of finishing enough product to meet the annual demand unless they do it in the first quarter. So there is a little bit of a channel fill for the repair/remodel part of that, and we enjoyed those volumes that went into that market. As far as the sustainability going forward, for the next 2 quarters -- actually, the next 3 quarters will be constrained until Swan Valley comes online. As Sallie said, we didn't produce any OSB in our siding mills. We ran them basically at capacity, but we also pulled down our inventories in the first quarter. And we won't have the opportunity to do that for the next couple of quarters.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd add one other thing, Gail, just to remind you that we did have a Tomahawk expansion last year, so we increased the capacity in our Siding business last year with that project.
componenttext: I'd add one other thing, Gail, just to remind you that we did have a Tomahawk expansion last year, so we increased the capacity in our Siding business last year with that project.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Curt, can you expand a little bit on the comments about inventory channels being pretty full and ready availability? Is your -- I mean, just how full do you think they are? I mean, are they full like ahead of a normal seasonal spring building se
componenttext: Okay. And Curt, can you expand a little bit on the comments about inventory channels being pretty full and ready availability? Is your -- I mean, just how full do you think they are? I mean, are they full like ahead of a normal seasonal spring building season or a little bit chunkier than that?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's all anecdotal because there's no firm data out there. But I was actually with a big customer yesterday, and what they said is they expect the takeaways to be better than they were in April because of the return of the cold weather in th
componenttext: Well, I think it's all anecdotal because there's no firm data out there. But I was actually with a big customer yesterday, and what they said is they expect the takeaways to be better than they were in April because of the return of the cold weather in the Northwest and the rain in the South -- or the Northeast rather and the rain in the South. They've said the last couple of weeks, however, with the warmer weather they are seeing those inventories come down. So I think it's a 3- to 4-week kind of issue that probably started to dissipate a little bit in the middle of last month.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And can you talk a little bit about the wood situational late state? I guess, you're able to get wood, it’s just a question at what cost? And is there any line of sight for those costs normalizing?
componenttext: Okay. And can you talk a little bit about the wood situational late state? I guess, you're able to get wood, it’s just a question at what cost? And is there any line of sight for those costs normalizing?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the late states, we're in a little bit of -- I mean, if you look at the wood supply in that area overall, we're in a little bit of a dip. But we should come out of that in the next couple of years, where the growth should significantly exceed the dr
componenttext: Well, the late states, we're in a little bit of -- I mean, if you look at the wood supply in that area overall, we're in a little bit of a dip. But we should come out of that in the next couple of years, where the growth should significantly exceed the drain. It's kind of the age classification of the wood there. What we did is we reached further out principally into Canada. And again, we were aided by the Canadian exchange rate, so that helped us a little bit. So we are going to pull in wood from Canada to support those mills, probably for the next couple of years. But then at that point in time, it also depends on what happens with the pulp mills in the area. We would expect to see wood cost come down a little bit.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And on Chambord, when you're talking about other options, is that other options do to secure wood for the facility should you choose to restart it, or is that just other options for the facility other than keeping it as something that could restart?
componenttext: Okay. And on Chambord, when you're talking about other options, is that other options do to secure wood for the facility should you choose to restart it, or is that just other options for the facility other than keeping it as something that could restart?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think there's 3 things we're looking at. One is to get the wood license back, so we can run that at full capacity when it's needed in the market. Second is, there is enough nongovernmental wood in the area to run that 50% to 60%. So we look at how we co
componenttext: I think there's 3 things we're looking at. One is to get the wood license back, so we can run that at full capacity when it's needed in the market. Second is, there is enough nongovernmental wood in the area to run that 50% to 60%. So we look at how we could monitor -- how we could modify the facility to run at 50% to 60% on OSB and use the other capacity for some other use, and I don't know what that might be. And the third is, we have shown an ability to relocate the physical assets in other parts of the world. We would look at Chambord as another opportunity to do that. So that would be the third option.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just quickly, last quarter, I think, you had indicated that oil prices to be, I think, a $40 million to $50 million benefit this year. Is that still your view? And if not, can you give an updated estimate?
componenttext: Okay. And then just quickly, last quarter, I think, you had indicated that oil prices to be, I think, a $40 million to $50 million benefit this year. Is that still your view? And if not, can you give an updated estimate?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: That is our current view, is a $50 million number.
componenttext: That is our current view, is a $50 million number.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon with Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon with Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Congratulations on the way you’ve really managed and grown the Siding business. A question about that is, as we go -- if we look at the last 3 years, there does seem to be a seasonal element there. And I know that could've been influenced by the fact yo
componenttext: Congratulations on the way you’ve really managed and grown the Siding business. A question about that is, as we go -- if we look at the last 3 years, there does seem to be a seasonal element there. And I know that could've been influenced by the fact you used to make more commodity OSB in that segment. But at any rate, it looks like the seasonal rise in revenue has been roughly $20 million from the first to the second quarter. And I just didn't know if there's any reason not to assume something roughly similar, not asking for specific forecast, but are there factors that might have made the first quarter either unusually strong or -- and therefore, not in the normal pattern?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as we just said Chip, we had Tomahawk was down a part of the first quarter of last year as we increased the capacity there. So we had significantly more available capacity in Tomahawk this first quarter than we did last year. In addition to that, we
componenttext: Well, as we just said Chip, we had Tomahawk was down a part of the first quarter of last year as we increased the capacity there. So we had significantly more available capacity in Tomahawk this first quarter than we did last year. In addition to that, we've manufactured probably 40 million square feet of OSB in Hayward last year and we didn't manufacture any this year. So we utilized the increased capacity at Tomahawk plus the conversion of the OSB we're running to Siding. So that allowed us to sell more product. And we are gaining traction in the market, there's no question about that. We are seeing single-family new construction is coming back a little bit, we do have presence in the multifamily with that product. And then repair/remodel and the nonresidential structures have really been the bulk of the growth over the last year.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I see. So what you're sort of suggesting is not quite the same bump seasonally. But is there also -- as you think about cost going from first to second quarter, obviously, you're dealing with less winter weather and -- but we do hear about wood costs, esp
componenttext: I see. So what you're sort of suggesting is not quite the same bump seasonally. But is there also -- as you think about cost going from first to second quarter, obviously, you're dealing with less winter weather and -- but we do hear about wood costs, especially in the Upper Midwest being still elevated. Any thoughts on what you see profitability in that particular segment doing from first to the second?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, from first to second, as I say, we're probably going to have less volume actually shipped because we ship that inventory in addition to what we produce. So we're going to be constrained on the volume side until Swan Valley comes up in the fourth qua
componenttext: Well, from first to second, as I say, we're probably going to have less volume actually shipped because we ship that inventory in addition to what we produce. So we're going to be constrained on the volume side until Swan Valley comes up in the fourth quarter. On the woods cost, our guys are saying, we're going to be probably about flat of wood costs. We don't see any big change in Q2. We've planned for the breakup, so we're in pretty good shape from that perspective. So I would -- volumes modified a little bit, not a lot. I can assure you, if we can produce it, we'll sell it.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And could you just update us quickly on what you're doing in South America at this point? I know, I believe you're building something down there as well or moving a plant down there as well.
componenttext: And could you just update us quickly on what you're doing in South America at this point? I know, I believe you're building something down there as well or moving a plant down there as well.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're doing couple of things. One, we are making a very small investment in an I-Joist line, that probably will operational towards the end of the year. When I say small, less than $5 million because we have been shipping product from our Engineered
componenttext: Yes. We're doing couple of things. One, we are making a very small investment in an I-Joist line, that probably will operational towards the end of the year. When I say small, less than $5 million because we have been shipping product from our Engineered Wood business up here, down there. And they do think they've got enough demand to begin to run their own. On the OSB side, we applied for the environmental permits last October. We've got the comments from the government in the first quarter along January, February. We have now responded to all of those comments, so we'll be entering into, I think it's the end of this week, we'll enter into a 30-day wait period for the government to hear back on that environmental permit. So we've been doing base engineering, we have acquired used equipment in the market for a portion of that facility. Actually, probably 75% of it we've acquired to date. So the plan is soon to get the environmental permitting, we'll complete the engineering and we hope to get Board approval with that, for that project in October. And we'll immediately start construction in the summer period in South America.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And maybe you what, start up like second quarter of next year, would that be a good guess or maybe later?
componenttext: And maybe you what, start up like second quarter of next year, would that be a good guess or maybe later?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Probably later than that. It's probably a 9- to 12-month construction period, so it’d probably be towards the end of 2016.
componenttext: Probably later than that. It's probably a 9- to 12-month construction period, so it’d probably be towards the end of 2016.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Ketan Mamtora with BMO Capital.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Ketan Mamtora with BMO Capital.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one quick question. Just coming back to Chambord again, so should we assume that converting the Chambord machine to Siding is completely ruled out or is that option on the table?
componenttext: Just one quick question. Just coming back to Chambord again, so should we assume that converting the Chambord machine to Siding is completely ruled out or is that option on the table?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's -- we did look at it. Chambord doesn't have rail, which makes it a little bit hard from a logistic standpoint. What's nice about Swan is, it does have rail service directly there. The other is that the wood species mix at Swan is better for -- we con
componenttext: It's -- we did look at it. Chambord doesn't have rail, which makes it a little bit hard from a logistic standpoint. What's nice about Swan is, it does have rail service directly there. The other is that the wood species mix at Swan is better for -- we consider better for our Siding product than the mix in Chambord. Chambord needs to be an OSB mill.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. That's helpful. And then coming back to Siding, obviously, it was a very good quarter. You talked about how volumes could be down a little bit. But just looking out a little bit on a medium-term basis, do you think margins in the 20% range are ac
componenttext: Got you. That's helpful. And then coming back to Siding, obviously, it was a very good quarter. You talked about how volumes could be down a little bit. But just looking out a little bit on a medium-term basis, do you think margins in the 20% range are achievable, if you go back on the housing starts at 1.4, 1.5?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I certainly think they're achievable, yes.
componenttext: I certainly think they're achievable, yes.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Bill Hoffmann with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Bill Hoffmann with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Curt, can you just talk a little bit more about what's going on down in Latin America? You went through a weakness in Brazil. Are you guys able to elaborate there? You're pushing product out of market, what's the strategy?
componenttext: Curt, can you just talk a little bit more about what's going on down in Latin America? You went through a weakness in Brazil. Are you guys able to elaborate there? You're pushing product out of market, what's the strategy?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, what's hurting us in Brazil right now is, when we've acquired that mill, most of the product going into Brazil was going into these industrial markets. So was for hoarding material on construction site, it was on packaging, it was being used for con
componenttext: Well, what's hurting us in Brazil right now is, when we've acquired that mill, most of the product going into Brazil was going into these industrial markets. So was for hoarding material on construction site, it was on packaging, it was being used for concrete forming. And we went in there with the expectation that we could change building practices like we did in Chile and we are, but we're doing that at a much slower rate. With the decline in the Brazilian economy, that core business that we've acquired, that's the business declining. We're actually selling more into new home construction, and we're selling more from an export standpoint, but we are selling less for that basic courting material and concrete form because there's less activity going on. So the -- what's been good for us is, we've been able to take that excess capacity we have, manufacture the product and ship it to Chile to meet this demand that we have in Chile until we have the new mill operating. But similar to providing product from North America, you give all your profits to the shipper, so shipping from Brazil to Chile actually is not any less expensive than shipping it out of Southern U.S.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. That at least it allows you to run those plants, right?
componenttext: Great. That at least it allows you to run those plants, right?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we're running the plant and we're making a contribution from an absorption standpoint, but we're not in the profitability in that we need to be.
componenttext: So we're running the plant and we're making a contribution from an absorption standpoint, but we're not in the profitability in that we need to be.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. Okay. And then just on the OSB side, one of the things we talked about before is it diversifying your OSB. I mean, obviously, Siding has been a great end market, but could you just talk a little bit more about what other end markets you feel like
componenttext: Got you. Okay. And then just on the OSB side, one of the things we talked about before is it diversifying your OSB. I mean, obviously, Siding has been a great end market, but could you just talk a little bit more about what other end markets you feel like you've been able to move product into and what percent of sales you are at this point and what the target might be?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I can't give you the sales breakdown because I don't have it in front of me. But we've been successful probably right after the great recession started, we've started focusing on the furniture market and we've been successful with several manufacturers th
componenttext: I can't give you the sales breakdown because I don't have it in front of me. But we've been successful probably right after the great recession started, we've started focusing on the furniture market and we've been successful with several manufacturers there. Because OSB actually provides a better product for the frame of couches and chairs than plywood does. As we've had some success there, we've had success in the transportation market. That's pretty broad, that's -- can be inside of trailers, inside of trucks, the inside of containers, as we've had some success there. I think those are the principal areas. We are as I said continuing to look at other industrial applications that may have another opportunity. You can provide -- you can put a surface on the OSB that will actually increase its usefulness.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Any sense of how much of your product can go into those other markets or is going to those other markets? I mean the last quarter of sales.
componenttext: Okay. Any sense of how much of your product can go into those other markets or is going to those other markets? I mean the last quarter of sales.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's not that big right now. It's probably 10%, 5% to 10% right now. But we do think that there's the opportunity to grow that. The export market hasn't been that attractive to us with the strong dollar. But that sort of export business, so it's down a li
componenttext: It's not that big right now. It's probably 10%, 5% to 10% right now. But we do think that there's the opportunity to grow that. The export market hasn't been that attractive to us with the strong dollar. But that sort of export business, so it's down a little bit.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just in Engineered Wood Products, the decline I-Joist in Q1, what's your outlook for that? Is that market balanced here in Q2 or...
componenttext: Okay. And then just in Engineered Wood Products, the decline I-Joist in Q1, what's your outlook for that? Is that market balanced here in Q2 or...

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: It was almost all in Western Canada, it was all pricing. Because we produce that in California, and ship it to Canada at an $0.80 -- or $0.82, dollar. The local producers have a huge advantage and we just didn't want to take a loss.
componenttext: It was almost all in Western Canada, it was all pricing. Because we produce that in California, and ship it to Canada at an $0.80 -- or $0.82, dollar. The local producers have a huge advantage and we just didn't want to take a loss.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Are those markets getting any better, I mean, obviously, not Canada, but can you move it to another market?
componenttext: Okay. Are those markets getting any better, I mean, obviously, not Canada, but can you move it to another market?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, Canada, we did put a price increase, but we're frankly focused at domestic markets in the U.S. and then out of our Eastern Canadian, the joint venture we have with Resolute, they benefit from the costs. And so our I-Joist sales into Eastern half
componenttext: I think, Canada, we did put a price increase, but we're frankly focused at domestic markets in the U.S. and then out of our Eastern Canadian, the joint venture we have with Resolute, they benefit from the costs. And so our I-Joist sales into Eastern half of the U.S. are pretty good from a profitability standpoint.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And so is it reasonable to expect -- I think you've talked in the past about some market growing at about a 15% clip. Is it conceivable that you can get that 15% and some catch-up from any constraint that might have developed this year? Is that a reasonable way to think about it for next year?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first let me just clarify what, if I ever said anything about 15%, that would have been our own growth. As the growth of Siding is dependent on level of housing activity and repair/remodel activity and rest of that. We think we can grow faster than
componenttext: Well, first let me just clarify what, if I ever said anything about 15%, that would have been our own growth. As the growth of Siding is dependent on level of housing activity and repair/remodel activity and rest of that. We think we can grow faster than that if we have the capacity. But we think we should be in the high-double digits. I'm sorry, high teens. Not double-digit.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

componenttext: Okay, great. And then shifting real quickly, if I could to the OSB. You've indicated that you thought it was about a 3- to 4-week issue in terms of the high channel, the high inventories in the channel and I think you said that you thought it started to reverse in the middle of last month so...

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Paul Quinn with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Guys, you outlined the expansion at Tomahawk and if you could just give us the numbers on that expansion. And then the results of expansion at Two Harbors, was there not -- I'm just trying to understand how you've grown that Siding segment in terms of cap
componenttext: Guys, you outlined the expansion at Tomahawk and if you could just give us the numbers on that expansion. And then the results of expansion at Two Harbors, was there not -- I'm just trying to understand how you've grown that Siding segment in terms of capability over the last couple of years.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We did the expansion at Two Harbors in 2013, we added about 25% capacity. That was a smaller mill, it was like 120, so I think we added 25 million, 30 million square feet there. And that is -- we're producing all of that. In the Tomahawk, it was about a 5
componenttext: We did the expansion at Two Harbors in 2013, we added about 25% capacity. That was a smaller mill, it was like 120, so I think we added 25 million, 30 million square feet there. And that is -- we're producing all of that. In the Tomahawk, it was about a 50% expansion, so we probably went from 130 million to about 190 million square feet.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just on Chambord, have you got any kind of legal or financial recourse on that for taking away the license? And then, in terms of that wood supply for competing uses, I mean, is there other mills in that area that would automatically grab
componenttext: Okay, great. And just on Chambord, have you got any kind of legal or financial recourse on that for taking away the license? And then, in terms of that wood supply for competing uses, I mean, is there other mills in that area that would automatically grab that wood or is that -- do you expect to get that back?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We expect to get it back. I think the premier is from the lake Sanguine [ph] area, so he’s very sensitive to the jobs in the area. I think we had a local mayor say, “If that wood was available, by god, there would be a saw mill in here.” So I think
componenttext: We expect to get it back. I think the premier is from the lake Sanguine [ph] area, so he’s very sensitive to the jobs in the area. I think we had a local mayor say, “If that wood was available, by god, there would be a saw mill in here.” So I think it's a little bit of French-Canadian bravado. We are the logical user of that. Resolute is the other big user in the area and they're our partner in the JV and they think it would be the right thing to do to restart Chambord because we provide the web stock by truck to those operations. So it's very convenient from a JV standpoint.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. The French-Canadians are known for that. And just lastly, on North America, flat sales profit down. Is that all on FX or is there a cost increase in Brazil?
componenttext: That makes sense. The French-Canadians are known for that. And just lastly, on North America, flat sales profit down. Is that all on FX or is there a cost increase in Brazil?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. It's mainly FX. There's a little bit of pressure because there is -- there is a small amount of imported product that goes into Chile and puts a cap on pricing. So we have had pricing down in real dollars, but the FX is the biggest part of that.
componenttext: No. It's mainly FX. There's a little bit of pressure because there is -- there is a small amount of imported product that goes into Chile and puts a cap on pricing. So we have had pricing down in real dollars, but the FX is the biggest part of that.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corp. Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded and we now like to turn the conference over to Sallie Bailey, Execu
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corp. Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded and we now like to turn the conference over to Sallie Bailey, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Please begin.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Lotraya, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the second quarter of 2015. I'm Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer, and with me today are Curt Stevens, LPs Chief Executi
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Lotraya, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the second quarter of 2015. I'm Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer, and with me today are Curt Stevens, LPs Chief Executive Officer; as well as Mike Kinney; and Becky Barckley, our primary Investor Relations contact. I will begin the discussion with a review the financial results for the second quarter of 2015 and this will be followed by some comments on the performance of the individual segments and selected balance sheet items. 
After I finish my comments, Curt will discuss the general market environment, in which LP has been operating, provide his perspective on our results and give some thoughts on the outlook. As we have done in the past, we have opened up this call to the public in the doing a webcast. The webcast can be accessed at www.lpcorp.com. And additionally to help with the discussion, we have provided a presentation with supplemental information that should be reviewed in conjunction with the earnings release. I will be referencing these slides in my comments this morning. We have filed an 8-K this morning with some supplemental information as well as our Form 10-Q. I want to remind all the participants about the forward-looking statements comment on Slide 2 of the presentation. Please also be aware of the discussion of our new use of non-GAAP financial information included on Slide 3 of the presentation. The appendix attached to the presentation have some of the necessary reconciliations that has been supplemented by the Form 8-K filing we made this morning. And rather than reading these 2 statements, I incorporate them with this with respect. 
For the second quarter of 2015 as compared to the second quarter of 2014, OSB prices were lower by 15%, which have negative impact on LP's financial results of $39 million. For the first 6 months period, OSB prices were 40% lower, which had negative impact on LP's financial results of $68 million. Now obviously our second quarter and as well as year-to-date performance to be lower than the same period in 2014. This decrease is in OSB prices occurred in a market where actual housing starts were 15% higher quarter-over-quarter and 10% higher for the first half of this year as compared to the first 6 months of 2014. However, the negative impact of the lower 2015 OSB price environment was offset in our results by another strong quarter and 6 months from the Siding segment. And with that, let me go into the detail. 
Moving to Slide 4 of the presentation for a discussion of the second quarter 2015 and first half consolidated results. We are reporting net sales of $493 million for the first quarter of 2015, a 5% decrease from the net sales of $590 million reported in the second quarter of 2014. In the second quarter, we recorded a net loss of $20 million, a loss of $0.14 per diluted share compared to net income for the second quarter of 2014 of $2 million or penny per diluted share. Adjusted loss for the quarter was $12 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.08 based upon a normalized tax rate of 35% compared to a loss of $4 million or loss per diluted share of $0.03 for the second quarter of 2014. 
Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $16 million in the quarter compared to $26 million in the second quarter of 2014. In the first 6 months of 2015, we recorded a net loss of $54 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.38 compared to a net loss for the second quarter of 2014 of $12 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.09. The adjusted loss for the 6 months period was $31 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.22 based upon the normalized tax rate of 35% compared to a loss of $11 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.08 for the first 6 months of 2014.  Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $22 million in the first 6 months of 2015 compared to $49 million in the 2014 comparable period. 
Moving now on to Slide 5 and a review of our business segment results. Starting with OSB. OSB recorded an operating loss of $18 million on sales of $211 million compared to a loss of $6 million on $224 million of sales in the second quarter of 2014. For the quarter, we reported negative adjusted EBITDA of $4 million compared to positive EBITDA of $8 million in the second quarter of 2014. We have an 11% increase in sales volume and a 2% increase in production. We reduced our finished goods inventory in the second quarter and we checked 110 basis down time or the equivalent of 179 million square feet. 
Pricing for OSB was lower by 15% over the second quarter of 2014. And the decrease in pricing resulted in lower operating results by $38 million. For the first 6 months of 2015, OSB recorded an operating loss of $47 million on sales of $401 million compared to a loss of $7 million on $419 million of sales in the first 6 months of 2014. For the first 6 months, we reported negative adjusted EBITDA of $17 million compared to positive adjusted EBITDA of $20 million in the first 6 months of 2014. Sales were higher by 12% and production was 3% higher. Year-to-date, we have taken 237 days of downtime or the equivalent of 375 million square feet. Sales prices were lower by 40% and the impact of the lower sales price on OSB operations was $67 million for the first 6 months of 2015 compared to the prior year. 
Offsetting the reduction sales price for both the quarter and the 6 months period with a reduction of material costs related to petroleum-based raw material as well as a positive impact of the Canadian currency exchange rate on the cost and Canadian operations as compared to the same periods in the prior year. 
Moving to Slide 6, which reports the results of our Sliding business. The segment includes our SmartSide and CanExel Siding products. The Siding segment reported sales of $164 million in the second quarter of 2015. Operating income of $29 million and adjusted EBITDA of $35 million as compared to $170 million of sales, operating income of $26 million and adjusted EBITDA of $30 million reported in the second quarter of 2014. 
For the quarter, SmartSide average sales prices were 4% and volumes decreased 6%. Volumes decreased on our SmartSide volume relative to the second quarter of 2014 as well as the first quarter of 2015 as our customers were rebalancing their inventories as sales into Texas and Oklahoma in particular were impacted by the very wet weather. 
The conversion on the Swan Valley OSB mill into mill is well underway again. The beginning in the third quarter, the results associated with the Swan mill won't be included in the Siding segment rather than as part of the OSB segment. 
Curt will provide more details on the status of the conversion in his comments. Our CanExcel product line recorded price decreases of 7% in US dollars and price increases of 11% in Canadian dollars. Volumes were up 14% in the quarter, due to increases in Canadian demand, Canada is CanExel's primary market. 
The Siding segment reported $337 million for the first 6 months of 2015, an increase of 8% from $313 million reported in the first 6 months of 2014. The Siding segment reported operating income of $62 million compared to $45 million and adjusted EBITDA of $73 million with compared to $54 million in the same period of 2014. 
SmartSide sales prices and volumes were both up 6% for the first 6 months of 2015 compared to the same period in 2014. The increase in our volume was due to continued penetration and several key focus markets, including retail, repair and remodel and markets and outsource building products, including shuts. CanExcel prices were down 3% in US dollars, however, they were up 16% in Canadian dollars. Sales volumes decreased 5% due to decreased in demand primarily from Europe due to discontinuation of certain prefinished colored siding products. 
Please turn to Slide 7 of the presentation, which shows the results for our Engineered Wood Products segment. This segment includes I-Joist, Laminated Strand Lumber, Laminated Veneer Lumber, OSB produces main facility plus other related products. This segment also includes the sales of I-Joist and LBL products produced by the Abitibi joint venture or under a sales arrangement with Murphy Plywood. The Engineered Wood Products segment record sales of $72 million on the second quarter of 2015, down from $76 million from the second quarter of 2014. The segment operating loss in the second quarter of 2015 was $2 million as compared to $5 million in the second quarter of 2014. For the second quarter of 2015, adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations improved to a positive $600,000 as compared to a negative $1 million in the second quarter of 2014. 
Volumes of I-Joist were down 10%, while volumes of LDL and LSL were down 2% compared to the same quarter last year. Pricing was down 1% in I-Joist and down 3% in LBL and LSL. And during the quarter and the first 6 months of 2015, we changing the mix of OSB products that are holding operations to produce more value-added products. The impact of this change resulted in improved operating results by $800,000 in the quarter and $1.2 million for the first 6 months. 
For the first 6 months, sales were $137 million, essentially flat with the first 6 months of 2014. The segment operating loss in the first 6 months was $6 million as compared to $8 million in the first half of 2014. Adjusted EBITDA for the first 6 months of 2015 was also essentially flat with the first 6 months of 2014. 
Moving on to Slide 8 of the presentation. For the quarter, our South America segment recorded sales of $39 million as compared to sales of $42 million in the second quarter of 2014. Operating income was $2 million in the second quarter of 2015 compared to $4 million in the second quarter of 2014. South America's adjusted EBITDA was $4 million for the second quarter of 2015 as compared to $7 million in the second quarter of 2014. 
Sales volumes in Chile were up 16% and lower by 21% in Brazil compared to the same quarter last year. The sales volume increased in Chile was primarily due to improved housing demand. In Brazil, reported sales volumes were lower due to economic recession as well as lower exports to China, but this decrease in demand was offset by higher exports to Chile. 
Sales of Brazilian products, which are sold in Chile are reflected in the Chilean sales volume. On a stand-alone basis, Brazil sales volumes were equal to the second quarter of 2014. 
Pricing was down 7% in Chile and down 24% in Brazil in US dollars. In local currency, Chile's prices was 4% higher than the same quarter in 2014 and Brazil's pricing was about flat with the prior year. For the first 6 months, our South America segment reported sales of $75 million as compared to $79 million in the first quarter of 2014. 
Operating income was $4 million compared to $8 million in the first 6 months of 2014, and adjusted EBITDA declined to $9 million from $13 million from the same period in 2014. 
Total selling, general and administrative expenses were $38 million in the second quarter of 2015 compared to $36 million in the same quarter in 2014. For the quarter, the increase in selling, general and administrative expenses primarily related to the higher information technology costs and increased sales and marketing related expenses. 
For the 6 months period, our selling, general and administrative expenses were flat at $77 million. The lower legal cost associated with the 2014 Ainsworth acquisition were offset by the increase in information and technology comps and the higher sales and marketing expenses. 
Turning now to Slide 9 of the presentation. As of June 30, 2015, we had cash, cash equivalents, investments and restricted cash of $501 million. Working capital of $717 million, net cash of $132 million. And in addition to the $497 million of cash on our balance sheet, we have $200 million of availability on our credit facility. Capital expenditures through June 30, 2015, were $34 million. 
We generated $42 million of cash from operating activities in the quarter and LP's cash balance increased $13 million in the quarter. Decreases in the inventory and receivables were key drivers of the cash flow generation and operating activity. 
Capital expenditures for 2015 are expected to be between $120 million and $130 million with about 2/3 related to growth projects. And we did not repurchase any stock in the quarter under our authorized stock repurchase plan. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Curt for his comments

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks for that review, Salley. Good morning to all of you and thanks for joining us on the call. Let me start with LP safety performance. For the quarter, we slipped a bit in our rolling 12-month total incident rate at the end June, it was at 0.41. Our p
componenttext:
Thanks for that review, Salley. Good morning to all of you and thanks for joining us on the call. Let me start with LP safety performance. For the quarter, we slipped a bit in our rolling 12-month total incident rate at the end June, it was at 0.41. Our performance of the first half of this year as a reminder that we can never let of our attention waver as the importance of safety. As an example, we had 2 injuries at the plant that went 7 years with no recordables and 3 injuries at another plant that hadn't had an injury in over 800,000 hours. Rest assure that we remain focused on the safety of our employees and contractors. As I typically do on these calls, I'll provide a few comments on the results of the second quarter, discuss the housing market and give you my views on the next several quarters and the midterm. After that, I'll turn the call back to Sally to take your questions. 
LSP pricing in continues to be below the industry forecasters projections, FBA, analysts and others. Random Lengths north-central was 14%, below an already low Q2 2014 pricing level. This was coupled with the wettest May on record for much of the middle of the country, including Texas. As we did in Q1, we took significant downtime in our OSB and EWP businesses in the quarter and also reduced our inventories. 
Our Siding business had another very strong quarter with $35 million in adjusted EBITDA. We did see a slight sleep in shipments compared to last year, as we believe the wet weather delayed the pace of reorders. Conversion of our Swan Valley OSB mill to SmartSide production is going well. We reported most of the foundations began, making the building modifications and are expecting equipment at the mill on a daily basis. We are on track to have initial Siding production in the Swan Valley in Q4 of this year. 
At our board meeting last week, we did present and the board approved our project to add FlameBlock coding capacity of one of our own OSB mills in Alabama. This will allow us to expand the production in sale of fire-resistant OSB panels for using multifamily and single-family construction. It's about $15 million project and should be complete around the middle of next year. This is very consistent with our strategy to increase the percentage of value-added OSB and our sales mix. 
Next let me share my views of the housing market. Based on the most recent numbers, demand for our products should be much better than we are seeing. This is quite frustrating. Let me give you some facts and figures. For June, housing starts came in at $1.174 million, a 10% higher than May. This puts the second quarter run rate at $1.14 million, 17% higher than Q1. Permits were even stronger at $1.343 million. Multifamily continues to be a big part of the growth in both starts and permits. Coupled with existing home sales at the highest rate in over 8 years, this certainly points to an accelerating market. The forecast for future activity are just slightly lower than last quarter as e-commerce appears to be exercising some caution as the strong June housing report numbers are not fully reflected. 
Here are the numbers, the consensus forecast for 2016 is now 1.122 million, which is a 12% increase over 2014. And the consensus forecast for 2016 stands at 1.315 million, a 17% increase over the 2015 forecast. As I reported in the last 2 quarters, our forecast going into this year was 1.1 million housing starts and that looks to be achievable. We are just putting together budget assumptions for next year and we haven't yet landed on number for starts, but I think it's fair to say, we'll be somewhere between the current 2015 and 2016 consensus forecast. 
Other positive housing-related news, household formations continue to exceed, make 400,000 to 500,000 pace last several years. And it does appear that the Millennials are moving out. ENAHB homebuilder confidence index reached the highest level over 8 years, which bodes well for our future activity. Thirty-year fixed mortgage rates are right about the 4% level. The inventory of new and existing homes for sale is shrinking. Most of the rig builders have reported second quarter results were optimistic for demand and cautious as to available labor. 
With higher sales of existing homes, there is good news for repair modeling expenditures as well. Well rates are increasing and vacancy rates are declining making homeownership a more attractive alternative in many markets. In the first half this year, we did see increasing demand for our products, but the very cold weather in the first quarter and the wet weather in the second quarter dampened the demand based on increase in housing starts. 
As I look at the second quarter with hindsight -- second half of the year with hindsight of the June housing numbers, certainly my believe that actual housing activity will accelerate in the second half of the year. Based on our discussions with with our customers, it is also my belief that Channel inventories on a relative balance, which means higher housing related demand should convert to orders, which should benefit all of our product lines. However, if I'm wrong, we'll have no choice but to take steps to adjust production levels as we have been in the past to focus on meeting our customer commitments while limiting the sale of unprofitable open-market wood. 
As I look at the next few years, I'm very confident we'll contain to see growth in housing starts as the U.S. has the fundamental shortage of housing units simply based on demographics. The recovery has not been at a pace was anticipated and there are still some headwinds. However, I believe if the labor issues faced by the builders will easy, banks will get back into the business of making loans and millennials will start getting married and having kids. All this is good news for our shareholders as LP is well positioned to capitalize on the continued recovery in housing, repair and remodeling activities. With that, let me turn it back to Sally for Q&A.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Mark Connelly of CLSA.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Mark Connelly of CLSA.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two things. We've started to hear from some other players in building materials about opportunities to improve logistics and plant flexibility. And I'm curious given the growth that you're having in Siding whether the opportunities for you to managing the
componenttext: Two things. We've started to hear from some other players in building materials about opportunities to improve logistics and plant flexibility. And I'm curious given the growth that you're having in Siding whether the opportunities for you to managing the supply chain differently might be expanding? And the second question you didn't mention sales to Asia from Latin America. Can you remind us how you think about that opportunity in the medium term?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, let me take the logistics question. We were disadvantaged in logistics for last couple of years, primarily with the service we were getting from Canadian railroads, at which caused us to put reloads and locations that worked very cost effective for
componenttext: Well, let me take the logistics question. We were disadvantaged in logistics for last couple of years, primarily with the service we were getting from Canadian railroads, at which caused us to put reloads and locations that worked very cost effective for us. In the last 6 months, both our Siding business and our OSB businesses spend a lot more time looking at that. The railroad performance improved this year and we're also seeing more availability of trucks in the U.S. So I do think it's an opportunity to bring down logistics cost. And as Sally mentioned, we did bring our inventories down pretty significant to the second quarter across all the businesses, and a big piece of that was taken them out the reloads to make it more efficient for us. As far as sales to Asia, from the U.S., we look at that very opportunistically. Most of what we ship from the U.S. or from Canada, into Asia has been going into Korea. There is some activity in China, but that's really kind of its infancy for us. The big exports side of the North America we're going into Russia and since the sanctions were put in place, that business has basically been eliminated. We don't do much business there at all. On South America, we did have a decorative OSB product that was going into China and that demand has been sporadic. In the last couple of quarters, we haven't shipped much of the product at all.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from George Staphos of Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question is from George Staphos of Bank of America.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, Curt, first question I had is, you said, your inventories are more or less in balance. So just to be -- maybe a little bit of fine or point on it. So would you said, that your inventories are where you would expect from it be at this time of the
componenttext: I guess, Curt, first question I had is, you said, your inventories are more or less in balance. So just to be -- maybe a little bit of fine or point on it. So would you said, that your inventories are where you would expect from it be at this time of the year,  I know it's very difficult to call this. But from what you can see in terms of your customers and distributors, where do you think their inventories are above normal, normal, below normal as we head into the back half of the year?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, our sales guys talk to our customers and so I'll put them in buckets for you. In general, the home centers don't have any excess inventories. They are pulling out of our reloads and BMIs. So from the home center business, I don't think it's an issue
componenttext: Well, our sales guys talk to our customers and so I'll put them in buckets for you. In general, the home centers don't have any excess inventories. They are pulling out of our reloads and BMIs. So from the home center business, I don't think it's an issue. Although I do think the wet weather in May reduce takeaways from the centers. So we did see reduced demand. In the prodealer channel, I think they did have more inventory going into Q2, and I think they came out of Q2 with a little more inventory than they expected. With the July, it's usually July slowdown from a building standpoint. We are seeing increased activity the end of July and going into August. So I think we're in a pretty good shape and I don't think there's a lot of inventory in the channel that's excess at this point.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Curt, I appreciate the later comments there. Next question I had, you talked about holding trying to move up the curve into the value-added products and if I wasn't mistaken, I thought the price has been down and recognizing 1 mill is going to drive the w
componenttext: Curt, I appreciate the later comments there. Next question I had, you talked about holding trying to move up the curve into the value-added products and if I wasn't mistaken, I thought the price has been down and recognizing 1 mill is going to drive the whole mix. Can you reconcile those 2 things for us? And then you mentioned that you didn't do any repurchase in the quarter and that's fine, you have other growth projects ahead of you. But can you comment in terms of why repurchases didn't seem to be as an attractive as an opportunity in relation to your investment projects in the quarter?

componenttext: I will handle the Horton question and let Sally handle the another one. In Horton, we saw an opportunity to do a value-added flooring product in the Horton mill.
