componenttext: First question is, I noticed that the Swan Valley mill capacity had always been listed about 410 million square foot then it jumped to 520 last year or at least that came out earlier this year. I know that's the 1 that's being converted, what caused the capacity to jump like that? Was it in capital that you spend there? Or was that a change in the mix ahead of the conversion?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We were limited on what we can produce from an environmental perspective. And we had a negotiation with the government, where we put a stack in that allowed us to run it at its full capacity. So we made that capital addition, I think in the first part of
componenttext: We were limited on what we can produce from an environmental perspective. And we had a negotiation with the government, where we put a stack in that allowed us to run it at its full capacity. So we made that capital addition, I think in the first part of last year, so it's really adding stack for environmental.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then the next one is, I know in the last call, you talked about the Chambord tree license, I guess, up in Canada, and how I guess, that's been lost -- I guess, 2 questions. One, is there any chance you might get it back. In other words, is the
componenttext: Got it. And then the next one is, I know in the last call, you talked about the Chambord tree license, I guess, up in Canada, and how I guess, that's been lost -- I guess, 2 questions. One, is there any chance you might get it back. In other words, is there another buyer for those trees? And maybe in regardless to the answer to that question, have you thought about where those assets might be deployed assuming they aren't deployed in Canada, they don't stay in the current location?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, what we looked at, Chip, is we looked at 3 scenarios. One scenario is we get the license back, province has set up a project office in the region. And I think we need to respond sometime the end of this quarter or early next quarter with a proposal
componenttext: Well, what we looked at, Chip, is we looked at 3 scenarios. One scenario is we get the license back, province has set up a project office in the region. And I think we need to respond sometime the end of this quarter or early next quarter with a proposal to them on using that wood. So one option would be get the license back and run it. Second option would be to run it with other available wood, which means we wouldn't running at full capacity, we can run it probably about 2/3. And then the third option was to relocate that equipment to another region that had more favorable wood pricing, and we're looking at all 3 of those. We really have an update on that until we decide what we're going to do with the project office again, towards the end of this quarter or early next quarter.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then on the CapEx, and I could go back a little bit. Is the 120 to 130 range, is that it -- I had 130 in my model, I don't know that's what you said last time or whether you lowered it slightly to a range. And then if you could g
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then on the CapEx, and I could go back a little bit. Is the 120 to 130 range, is that it -- I had 130 in my model, I don't know that's what you said last time or whether you lowered it slightly to a range. And then if you could give us at least from point of August what next year looks like assuming no major changes in what you're thinking in terms of projects?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the 130 is what we've talked about before. I think the lowering the range as we've had a delay in the environmental permitting in South America. So the mill in Chile, we haven't actually started construction yet, so much of that will move into next
componenttext: Well, the 130 is what we've talked about before. I think the lowering the range as we've had a delay in the environmental permitting in South America. So the mill in Chile, we haven't actually started construction yet, so much of that will move into next year as we get through the permitting process. As far as the capital budget for next year, we are leading as a group on, I think at the 18th of this month to go through our capital summit for next year. I don't really have a number at this point in time. It does look like it will be about a $40 million to $50 million carryover from projects that will start this year that will go into next year, but I don't know beyond that.

componenttext: Yes. I think we've -- I talked about this in the past. The plan is when we convert Swan to Siding is that we only will run Siding at that mill. And what we'll do is, we move production capacity out of our Hayward mill and potentially some of the smaller mills in that region, and we'll use Hayward as the You recall that's a 2 line -- 2 full lines there, so we can run 1 on Siding and 1 on OSB. So that will be the swing on that Swan. As far as the ramp up, we're hoping it's going to go relatively quickly, but this is an $85 million project. It's pretty big deal. What we are planning on is that we probably at least in our numbers, we're planning on supplying the market of existing mills until the first quarter. So we'll use the fourth quarter as our ramp up.

So if your European producers and add $100 freight to it, I don't think it makes a whole lot of sense.

So do you have any thoughts around what the mix will look like for housing starts over the next 12 months and sort of implications for your business is more of the mix is multi verses single?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We spend a lot of time. We actually had study here in last week talk to them for housing studies. This view is that multifamily has basically recovered, so it's back added to historic rate for starts. And a single-family has been profited by always o
componenttext: Yes. We spend a lot of time. We actually had study here in last week talk to them for housing studies. This view is that multifamily has basically recovered, so it's back added to historic rate for starts. And a single-family has been profited by always other issues, but that the growth in the next couple of years is going to come from single-family, not from the Multifamily. Multifamily will probably stay at the level with that, but probably won't be as big shared going forward, and that's consistent with what Harvard believe, metro study believes, FBA also believes that.

componenttext: On SmartSide, we are running in the mid-to high 90s on our current production. We did see some improvement in our Tomahawk operations. So we're off allocation, which is good for our customers and good for us. So I think the timing of the new mill is okay. If you can SmartSide or the CanExel pricing, that's all Canadian dollar exchange rate.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corp. Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Sallie Bailey, E
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corp. Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Sallie Bailey, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Please begin.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, LaToya, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the second quarter of 2015. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer; and with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's Chief Execut
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, LaToya, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the second quarter of 2015. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer; and with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's Chief Executive Officer; as well as Mike Kinney and Becky Barckley, our primary Investor Relations contact. 
I will begin the discussion with a review of the financial results for the second quarter of 2015, and this will be followed by some comments on the performance of individual segments and selected balance sheet items. 
After I finish my comments, Curt will discuss the general market environment in which LP has been operating, provide his perspective on our results and give some thoughts on the outlook. 
As we have done in the past, we have opened up this call to the public and are doing a webcast. The webcast can be accessed at www.lpcorp.com. And additionally, to help with the discussion, we've provided a presentation with supplemental information that should be reviewed in conjunction with the earnings release. I will be referencing these slides in my comments this morning. We have filed an 8-K this morning with some supplemental information as well as our Form 10-Q. 
I want to remind all the participants about the forward-looking statements comment on Slide 2 of the presentation. Please also be aware of the discussion of our new use of non-GAAP financial information included on Slide 3 of the presentation. The appendix attached to the presentation has some of the necessary reconciliations that has been supplemented by the Form 8-K filing we made this morning. And rather than reading these 2 statements, I incorporate them with this reference. 
For the second quarter of 2015 as compared to the second quarter of 2014, OSB prices were lower by 15%, which had negative impact on LP's financial results of $39 million. For the first 6-month period, OSB prices were 14% lower, which had negative impact on LP's financial results of $68 million. Now obviously, this caused our second quarter as well as our year-to-date performance to be lower than the same periods in 2014. This decreases in OSB prices occurred in a market where actual housing starts were 50% -- 15% higher quarter-over-quarter and 10% higher for the first half of this year as compared to the first 6 months of 2014. However, the negative impact of the lower 2015 OSB price environment was offset in our results by another strong quarter and 6 months from the Siding segment. 
And with that, let me go into the details. Moving to Slide 4 of the presentation for a discussion of the second quarter 2015 and first half consolidated results. We are reporting net sales of $493 million for the first quarter of 2015, a 5% decrease from the net sales of $519 million reported in the second quarter of 2014. In the second quarter, we recorded a net loss of $20 million, a loss of $0.14 per diluted share compared to net income for the second quarter of 2014 of $2 million or $0.01 per diluted share. The adjusted loss for the quarter was $12 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.08 based upon a normalized tax rate of 35% compared to a loss of $4 million or loss per diluted share of $0.03 for the second quarter of 2014. 
Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $16 million in the quarter compared to $26 million in the second quarter of 2014. In the first 6 months of 2015, we recorded a net loss of $54 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.38 compared to a net loss for the second quarter of 2014 of $12 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.09. The adjusted loss for the 6-month period was $31 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.22 based upon the normalized tax rate of 35% compared to a loss of $11 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.08 for the first 6 months of 2014. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $22 million in the first 6 months of 2015 compared to $49 million in the 2014 comparable period. 
Moving now on to Slide 5 and a review of our business segment results. Starting with OSB. OSB recorded an operating loss of $18 million on sales of $211 million compared to a loss of $6 million on $224 million of sales in the second quarter of 2014. For the quarter, we reported negative adjusted EBITDA of $4 million compared to positive adjusted EBITDA of $8 million in the second quarter of 2014. We have an 11% increase in sales volume and a 2% increase in production. We reduced our finished goods inventory in the second quarter, and we checked 110 days of downtime or the equivalent of 179 million square feet. Pricing for OSB was lower by 15% over the second quarter of 2014, and the decrease in pricing resulted in lower operating results by $38 million. 
For the first 6 months of 2015, OSB recorded an operating loss of $47 million on sales of $401 million compared to a loss of $7 million on $419 million of sales in the first 6 months of 2014. For the first 6 months, we reported negative adjusted EBITDA of $17 million compared to positive adjusted EBITDA of $20 million in the first 6 months of 2014. Sales were higher by 12%, and production was 3% higher. Year-to-date, we have taken 237 days of downtime or the equivalent of 375 million square feet. Sales prices were lower by 14%, and the impact of the lower sales price on OSB operations was $67 million for the first 6 months of 2015 compared to the prior year.  
Offsetting the reduction in sales price for both the quarter and the 6-month period was a reduction of raw material costs related to petroleum-based raw material as well as a positive impact of the Canadian currency exchange rate on the costs incurred in our Canadian operations as compared to the same periods in the prior year. 
Moving to Slide 6, which reports the results of our Siding business. This segment includes our SmartSide and CanExel siding products. The Siding segment reported sales of $164 million in the second quarter of 2015, operating income of $29 million and adjusted EBITDA of $35 million as compared to $170 million of sales, operating income of $26 million and adjusted EBITDA of $30 million reported in the second quarter of 2014. 
For the quarter, SmartSide average sales prices were up 4% and volumes decreased 6%. Volumes decreased in our SmartSide siding line relative to the second quarter of 2014 as well as the first quarter of 2015 as our customers were rebalancing their inventories as sales into Texas and Oklahoma, in particular, were impacted by the very wet weather. 
The conversion of the Swan Valley OSB mill into a siding mill is well underway. Beginning in the third quarter, the results associated with the Swan mill will be included in the Siding segment rather than as part of OSB segment. Curt will provide more details on the status of the conversion in his comments. Our CanExel product line recorded price decreases of 7% in U.S. dollars and price increases of 11% in Canadian dollars. Volumes were up 14% in the quarter due to increases in Canadian demand. Canada is CanExel's primary market. 
The Siding segment reported $337 million for the first 6 months of 2015, an increase of 8% from $313 million reported in the first 6 months of 2014. The Siding segment reported operating income of $62 million compared to $45 million and adjusted EBITDA of $73 million as compared to $54 million in the same period of 2014. SmartSide sales prices and volumes were both up 6% for the first 6 months of 2015 compared to the same period in 2014. The increase in our volume was due to continued penetration in several key focus markets, including retail, repair and remodel markets and outdoor building products, including shuts. CanExel prices were down 3% in U.S. dollars. However, they were up 16% in Canadian dollars. Sales volumes decreased 5% due to decreased demand primarily from Europe due to discontinuation of certain pre-finished colored siding products. 
Please turn to Slide 7 of the presentation, which shows the results from our Engineered Wood Products segment. This segment includes I-Joist, Laminated Strand Lumber, Laminated Veneer Lumber, OSB produced at our Houlton, Maine facility plus other related products. This segment also includes the sales of I-Joist and LVL products produced by the Abitibi joint venture or under a sales arrangement with Murphy Plywood. The Engineered Wood Products segment recorded sales of $72 million in the second quarter of 2015, down from $76 million in the second quarter of 2014. The segment operating loss in the second quarter of 2015 was $2 million as compared to $5 million in the second quarter of 2014. For the second quarter of 2015, adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations improved to a positive $600,000 as compared to a negative $1 million in the second quarter of 2014. 
Volumes of I-Joist were down 10% while volumes of LVL and LSL were down 2% compared to the same quarter last year. Pricing was down 1% in I-Joist and down 3% in LVL and LSL. And during the quarter and the first 6 months of 2015, we changed the mix of OSB products at our Houlton operations to produce more value-added products. The impact of this change resulted in improved operating results by $800,000 in the quarter and $1.2 million for the first 6 months. 
For the first 6 months, sales were $137 million, essentially flat with the first 6 months of 2014. The segment operating loss in the first 6 months was $6 million as compared to $8 million in the first half of 2014. Adjusted EBITDA for the first 6 months of 2015 was also essentially flat with the first 6 months of 2014. 
Moving on to Slide 8 of the presentation. For the quarter, our South America segment recorded sales of $39 million as compared to sales of $42 million in the second quarter of 2014. Operating income was $2 million in the second quarter of 2015 compared to $4 million in the second quarter of 2014. South America's adjusted EBITDA was $4 million for the second quarter of 2015 as compared to $7 million in the second quarter of 2014. 
Sales volumes in Chile were up 16% and lower by 21% in Brazil compared to the same quarter last year. The sales volume increase in Chile was primarily due to improved housing demand. In Brazil, reported sales volumes were lower due to the economic recession as well as lower exports to China, but this decrease in demand was offset by higher exports to Chile. Sales of Brazilian products which are sold in Chile are reflected in the Chilean sales volume. On a stand-alone basis, Brazil sales volumes were equal to the second quarter of 2014. Pricing was down 7% in Chile and down 24% in Brazil in U.S. dollars. In local currency, Chile's prices was 4% higher than the same quarter in 2014, and Brazil's pricing was about flat with the prior year. 
For the first 6 months, our South America segment reported sales of $75 million as compared to $79 million in the first quarter of 2014. 
Operating income was $4 million compared to $8 million in the first 6 months of 2014, and adjusted EBITDA declined to $9 million from $13 million from the same period in 2014. 
Total selling, general and administrative expenses were $38 million in the second quarter of 2015 compared to $36 million in the same quarter in 2014. For the quarter, the increase in selling, general and administrative expenses primarily relate to the higher information technology costs and increased sales and marketing-related expenses. For the 6-month period, our selling, general and administrative expenses are flat at $77 million. The lower legal costs associated with the 2014 Ainsworth acquisition were offset by the increase in information technology costs and the higher sales and marketing expenses. 
Turning now to Slide 9 of the presentation. As of June 30, 2015, we had cash, cash equivalents, investments and restricted cash of $501 million, working capital of $717 million, net cash of $132 million. And in addition to the $497 million of cash on our balance sheet, we have $200 million of availability on our credit facility. Capital expenditures through June 30, 2015, were $34 million. We generated $42 million of cash from operating activities in the quarter, and LP's cash balance increased $13 million in the quarter. Decreases in inventory and receivables were key drivers of the cash flow generation and operating activity. Capital expenditures for 2015 are expected to be between $120 million and $130 million, with about 2/3 related to growth projects. And we did not repurchase any stock in the quarter under our authorized stock repurchase plan. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Curt for his comments

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks for that review, Sallie. Good morning to all of you, and thanks for joining us on the call. Let me start with LP's safety performance. For the quarter, we slipped a bit in our rolling 12-month total incident rate at the end June. It was at 0.41. Ou
componenttext:
Thanks for that review, Sallie. Good morning to all of you, and thanks for joining us on the call. Let me start with LP's safety performance. For the quarter, we slipped a bit in our rolling 12-month total incident rate at the end June. It was at 0.41. Our performance for the first half of this year is a reminder that we can never let our attention waver as to the importance of safety. As an example, we had 2 injuries at a plant that went 7 years with no recordables and 3 injuries at another plant that hadn't had an injury in over 800,000 hours. Rest assured that we remain focused on the safety of our employees and contractors. 
As I typically do on these calls, I'll provide a few comments on our results for the second quarter, discuss the housing market and give you my views on the next several quarters and the midterm. After that, I'll turn the call back over to Sallie to take your questions. 
OSB pricing continues to be below the industry forecasters' projections. I'm talking about FEA, RISI, analysts and others. Random Lengths North Central was 14% below an already low Q2 2014 pricing level. This was coupled with the wettest May on record for much of the middle of the country, including Texas. As we did in Q1, we took significant downtime in our OSB and EWP businesses in the quarter and also reduced our inventories. 
Our Siding business had another very strong quarter with $35 million in adjusted EBITDA. We did see a slight slip in shipments compared to last year as we believe the wet weather delayed the pace of reorders. Conversion of our Swan Valley OSB mill to SmartSide production is going well. We have floored most of the foundations, began making the building modifications and are expecting equipment at the mill on a daily basis. We are on track to have initial siding production in Swan Valley in Q4 of this year. 
At our board meeting last week, we did present and the board approved our project to add FlameBlock coating capacity at one of our OSB mills in Alabama. This will allow us to expand the production and sale of fire-resistant OSB panels for use in multifamily and single-family construction. It's about a $15 million project and should be complete around the middle of next year. This is very consistent with our strategy to increase the percentage of value-added OSB in our sales mix. 
Next, let me share my views of the housing market. Based on the most recent numbers, demand for our products should be much better than we are seeing. This is quite frustrating. Let me give you some facts and figures. For June, housing starts came in at 1.174 million, almost 10% higher than May. This puts the second quarter run rate at 1.14 million, 17% higher than Q1. Permits were even stronger at 1.343 million. Multifamily continues to be a big part of the growth in both starts and permits. Coupled with existing home sales at the highest rate in over 8 years, this certainly points to an accelerating market. The forecast for future activity are just slightly lower than last quarter as the economists appear to be exercising some caution as the strong June housing report numbers are not fully reflected. 
But here are the numbers. The consensus forecast for 2015 is now 1.122 million, which is a 12% increase over 2014, and the consensus forecast for 2016 stands at 1.315 million, a 17% increase over the 2015 forecast. As I've reported the last 2 quarters, our forecast going into this year was 1.1 million housing starts, and that looks to be achievable. We're just putting together budget assumptions for next year, and we haven't yet landed on a number for starts, but I think it's fair to say we'll be somewhere between the current 2015 and 2016 consensus forecast. 
Other positive housing-related news. Household formations continue to exceed the anemic 400,000 to 500,000 pace the last several years, and it does appear the millennials are moving out. The NAHB homebuilder confidence index reached the highest level over 8 years, which bodes well for future activity. 30-year fixed mortgage rates are right about the 4% level. The inventory of new and existing homes for sale is shrinking. Most of the big builders who've reported second quarter results were optimistic for demand and cautious as to available labor. With higher sales of existing homes, this is good news for repair/remodeling expenditures as well. Rental rates are increasing, and vacancy rates are declining, making homeownership a more attractive alternative in many markets. 
In the first half of this year, we did see increasing demand for our products, but the very cold weather in the first quarter and the wet weather in the second quarter dampened the demand based on increase in housing starts. As I look at the second quarter with hindsight -- second half of the year with hindsight of the June housing numbers, it's certainly my belief that actual housing activity will accelerate in the second half of the year. Based on our discussions with our customers, it is also my belief that channel inventories are on relative balance, which means higher housing-related demand should convert to orders, which should benefit all of our product lines. However, if I'm wrong, we'll have no choice but to take steps to adjust our production levels, as we have done in the past, to focus on meeting our customer commitments while limiting the sale of unprofitable open-market wood. 
As I look at the next few years, I'm very confident we'll continue to see growth in housing starts as the U.S. has the fundamental shortage of housing units simply based on demographics. The recovery has not been at a pace any of us anticipated, and there are still some headwinds. However, I believe that the labor issues faced by the builders will ease, banks will get back into the business of making loans and millennials will start getting married and having kids. All of this is good news for our shareholders as LP is well positioned to capitalize on the continued recovery in housing, repair and remodeling activities. 
With that, let me turn it back to Sallie for Q&A.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Mark Connelly of CLSA.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Mark Connelly of CLSA.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two things. We've started to hear from some other players in building materials about opportunities to improve logistics and plant flexibility. And I'm curious, given the growth that you're having in Siding, whether the opportunities for you to manage you
componenttext: Two things. We've started to hear from some other players in building materials about opportunities to improve logistics and plant flexibility. And I'm curious, given the growth that you're having in Siding, whether the opportunities for you to manage your supply chain differently might be expanding. And the second question, you didn't mention sales to Asia from Latin America. Can you remind us how you think about that opportunity in the medium term?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, let me take the logistics question. We were disadvantaged in logistics for the last couple of years, primarily with the service we were getting from the Canadian railroads, which caused us to put reloads in locations that weren't very cost-effective
componenttext: Well, let me take the logistics question. We were disadvantaged in logistics for the last couple of years, primarily with the service we were getting from the Canadian railroads, which caused us to put reloads in locations that weren't very cost-effective for us. In the last 6 months, both our Siding business and our OSB business has spent a lot more time looking at that. The railroad performance improved this year, and we're also seeing more availability of trucks in the U.S. So I do think there's an opportunity to bring down our logistics cost. And as Sallie mentioned, we did bring our inventories down pretty significant in the second quarter across all the businesses, and a big piece of that was taking them out of the reloads to make it more efficient for us. As far as sales to Asia, from the U.S., we look at that very opportunistically. Most of what we ship from the U.S. or from Canada into Asia has been going into Korea. There is some activity in China, but that's really kind of in its infancy for us. The big exports out of North America were going into Russia. And since the sanctions were put in place, that business has basically been eliminated. We don't do much business there at all. On South America, we did have a decorative OSB product that was going into China, and that demand has been sporadic. In the last couple of quarters, we haven't shipped much of that product at all.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from George Staphos of Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question is from George Staphos of Bank of America.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, Curt, first question I had is, you said that inventories are more or less in balance. So just to be maybe a little bit finer point on it, so would you say that your inventories are where you'd expect them to be at this time of the year? And I rea
componenttext: I guess, Curt, first question I had is, you said that inventories are more or less in balance. So just to be maybe a little bit finer point on it, so would you say that your inventories are where you'd expect them to be at this time of the year? And I realize it's very difficult to call this. But from what you can see in terms of your customers and distributors, where do you think their inventories are, above normal, normal, below normal, as we head into the back half of the year?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, our sales guys talk to our customers, and so I'll put them in buckets for you. In general, the home centers don't have any excess inventories because they're pulling out of our reloads and BMI's. So from the home center business, I don't think it's
componenttext: Well, our sales guys talk to our customers, and so I'll put them in buckets for you. In general, the home centers don't have any excess inventories because they're pulling out of our reloads and BMI's. So from the home center business, I don't think it's an issue, although I do think the wet weather in May reduced takeaways from the centers. So we did see reduced demand. In the pro dealer channel, I think they did have more inventory going into Q2, and I think they came out of Q2 with a little more inventory than they expected. With July -- there's usually a July slowdown from a building standpoint. We are seeing increased activity at the end of July and going into August. So I think that -- I think we're in pretty good shape, and I don't think there's a lot of inventory in the channel that's excess at this point.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. That's helpful, Curt. Appreciate the latter comments there. Next question I had, you talked about Houlton trying to move up the curve into the value-added products. And yet, if I wasn't mistaken, I thought the price has been down. And recognizi
componenttext: All right. That's helpful, Curt. Appreciate the latter comments there. Next question I had, you talked about Houlton trying to move up the curve into the value-added products. And yet, if I wasn't mistaken, I thought the price has been down. And recognizing one mill isn't going to drive the whole mix, can you reconcile those 2 things for us? And then you mentioned that you didn't do any repurchase in the quarter, and that's fine, you have other growth projects ahead of you. But can you comment in terms of why repurchases didn't seem to be as attractive an opportunity in relation to your investment projects in the quarter?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I will handle the Houlton question and let Sallie handle the other one. In Houlton, we saw an opportunity to do a value-added flooring product in the Houlton mill, and that's really what we've focused on. We were looking at it more from a geographic
componenttext: Okay. I will handle the Houlton question and let Sallie handle the other one. In Houlton, we saw an opportunity to do a value-added flooring product in the Houlton mill, and that's really what we've focused on. We were looking at it more from a geographic standpoint in the past, where we had demand in the local geography, back to the earlier question of logistics, and we focused on that. In the second quarter, it was really more of the high-performance flooring.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And as it relates to capital allocation, George, we've looked at the investments that we're making in Swan, and there will be some heavy uptick in our capital expenditures in the second half of the year as we finish out this line conversion. And thos
componenttext: Yes. And as it relates to capital allocation, George, we've looked at the investments that we're making in Swan, and there will be some heavy uptick in our capital expenditures in the second half of the year as we finish out this line conversion. And those have returns on them that are well in excess of our cost of capital. And likewise, with the FlameBlock capital expenditure and investment that Curt was talking about, those also are good uses of our cash and provide good returns for our shareholders.

componenttext: First question is, I noticed that the Swan Valley mill capacity had always been listed at about 410 million square feet and then it jumped to 520 last year -- or at least in the K that came out earlier this year. And I know that's the one that is being converted. What caused the capacity to jump like that? Was it -- was there any capital that you spent there? Or was that a change in the mix ahead of the conversion?

componenttext: We were limited on what we can produce from an environmental perspective, and we had a negotiation with the Manitoba government where we put a stack in that allowed us to run it at its full capacity. So we made that capital addition, I think, in the first part of last year, so it's really adding a stack for environmental.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then the next one is, I know in the last call, you talked about the Chambord tree license, I guess, up in Canada and how, I guess, that's been lost. I guess, 2 questions. One, is there any chance you might get it back? In other words, is there another
componenttext: And then the next one is, I know in the last call, you talked about the Chambord tree license, I guess, up in Canada and how, I guess, that's been lost. I guess, 2 questions. One, is there any chance you might get it back? In other words, is there another buyer for those trees? And maybe regardless of the answer to that question, have you thought about where those assets might be deployed, assuming they aren't deployed in Canada -- or they don't stay in their current location?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, what we looked at, Chip, is we looked at 3 scenarios. One scenario is we get the license back. The province has set up a project office in the region, and I think we need to respond some time the end of this quarter or early the next quarter with a
componenttext: Well, what we looked at, Chip, is we looked at 3 scenarios. One scenario is we get the license back. The province has set up a project office in the region, and I think we need to respond some time the end of this quarter or early the next quarter with a proposal to them on using that wood. So one option would be get the license back and run it. Second option would be to run it with other available wood, which means we wouldn't run it at full capacity. We can run it probably about 2/3. And then the third option was to relocate that equipment to another region that had more favorable wood pricing. And we're looking at all 3 of those. I don't really have an update on that until we decide what we're going to do with the project office, again, towards the end of this quarter or early next quarter.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then on the CapEx, and I could go back a little bit, is the $120 million to $130 million range, is that -- I had $130 million in my model. I don't know if that's what you said last time or whether you've lowered it slightly to a range. And then if you could give us, at least from the vantage point of August, what next year looks like, assuming no major changes in what you're thinking in terms of projects.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the $130 million is what we've talked about before. I think the lowering of the range is we have had a delay in the environmental permitting in South America. So the mill in Chile, we haven't actually started construction yet, so much of that will m
componenttext: Well, the $130 million is what we've talked about before. I think the lowering of the range is we have had a delay in the environmental permitting in South America. So the mill in Chile, we haven't actually started construction yet, so much of that will move into next year as we get through that permitting process. As far as the capital budget for next year, we are meeting as a group on -- I think at the 18th of this month to go through our capital summit for next year. So I don't really have a number at this point in time. It does look like there'll be about a $40 million to $50 million carryover from projects that will start this year that will go into next year, but I don't know beyond that.

componenttext: Got you, okay. So maybe one way to think about that is, it sounds like your base was around $40 million or $50 million and so then if you add the carryover, you're maybe in the high double digits and then whatever else you add to that would be what the ultimate number is. Is that roughly correct?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we've -- I've talked about this in the past. The plan is when we convert Swan to Siding is that we only will run Siding at that mill. And what we'll do is we'll move production capacity out of our Hayward mill and potentially some of the smal
componenttext: Yes. I think we've -- I've talked about this in the past. The plan is when we convert Swan to Siding is that we only will run Siding at that mill. And what we'll do is we'll move production capacity out of our Hayward mill and potentially some of the smaller mills in that region, and we'll use Hayward as the swing mill. Because, if you recall, that's a 2-line so we have 2 full lines there, so we can run one on Siding and one on OSB. So that will be the swing on that Swan. As far as the ramp-up, we're hoping it's going to go relatively quickly. But this is an $85 million project, so it's a pretty big deal. What we are planning on is that we probably -- at least in our numbers, we're planning on supplying the market out of the existing mills until the first quarter. So we'll use the fourth quarter as our ramp-up.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I do think the takeaways were hurt. I mean, the strongest housing market in the country is Texas, and Texas had over 16 inches of rain in May. So there weren't any starts going on there, so did takeaways certainly in Texas and Oklahoma that Sallie t
componenttext: Well, I do think the takeaways were hurt. I mean, the strongest housing market in the country is Texas, and Texas had over 16 inches of rain in May. So there weren't any starts going on there, so did takeaways certainly in Texas and Oklahoma that Sallie talked about, I heard that. But we ought to be seeing accelerating activity. Now the other side of that is all the builders have talked about labor issues or it's taking them longer to finish a home. But again, as I said, I think they're going to start solving that issue as we go forward.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't want to get too much into the weeds, but when you say with all the rain, et cetera, that there wouldn't have been the starts, would there possibly have been starts but then they actually slowed it out so that the wood doesn't flow? And I think you
componenttext: I don't want to get too much into the weeds, but when you say with all the rain, et cetera, that there wouldn't have been the starts, would there possibly have been starts but then they actually slowed it out so that the wood doesn't flow? And I think you talked about business getting a little bit better more recently and maybe they're catching up. Or is that not how it works from a reporting perspective?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't know how much surge capacity they have, again, because of the labor issues. So I think they could build at a pace. And if they lose a whole month, if you got to lose that, move those starts forward. But I don't think they have the ability to
componenttext: Well, I don't know how much surge capacity they have, again, because of the labor issues. So I think they could build at a pace. And if they lose a whole month, if you got to lose that, move those starts forward. But I don't think they have the ability to accelerate. And the water issue in Texas and Oklahoma is most of this is slab-on-grade and [indiscernible].

componenttextpreview: So you can't really start a house.
componenttext: So you can't really start a house.

componenttext: Right. And then lastly, I guess, one that you definitely do have is where your inventories are at your mills and where are they -- I think you said they came down from the end of the first quarter. Where would they be versus where they were a year ago?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: In our OSB mills, we're down pretty significantly. In the Siding business, we actually had too low of inventory at this time last year. We've raised that a little bit this year. So our Siding, we're pretty good where we think we need to be. Engineered woo
componenttext: In our OSB mills, we're down pretty significantly. In the Siding business, we actually had too low of inventory at this time last year. We've raised that a little bit this year. So our Siding, we're pretty good where we think we need to be. Engineered wood, we brought them down. I think we're in pretty good shape there. So OSB, lower; Engineered wood, about the same; Siding, just a little bit higher right now.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015

componenttext: The next question is from Alex Ovshey of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of ones for you. With the correction to structural lumber prices, I'm curious if you're seeing customers switch back from engineered wood into lumber as lumber prices have corrected.
componenttext: A couple of ones for you. With the correction to structural lumber prices, I'm curious if you're seeing customers switch back from engineered wood into lumber as lumber prices have corrected.

componenttext: Well, it's interesting, we just talked about that this morning. We're seeing a little bit of it, but it's not significant. Actually, it's more related to some of the fire codes than it is the pricing.

componenttext: Okay, got it. So you don't think that, that potentially accelerates if lumber prices stay low?

componenttext: Historically, it hasn't. I mean, if you look over the last 8 to 10 years, it really hasn't gone back.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful, Curt. And then just on import of panels, it sounds like we're seeing that flow on the plywood side. Obviously, you don't have exposure there, but I'm curious if you have any thoughts around whether or not the plywood imports could
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful, Curt. And then just on import of panels, it sounds like we're seeing that flow on the plywood side. Obviously, you don't have exposure there, but I'm curious if you have any thoughts around whether or not the plywood imports could have an impact on your business and whether or not you see potential for maybe all those B2B [ph] coming in from other places in the U.S. -- I'm sorry, into the U.S. from other places given how strong the dollar is.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that plywood, I don't -- I saw the import numbers went up, but I don't think it's going to have a big impact on us. We are seeing imported wood from Europe going into South America, and that has had some downward pressure on our pricing, par
componenttext: Well, I think that plywood, I don't -- I saw the import numbers went up, but I don't think it's going to have a big impact on us. We are seeing imported wood from Europe going into South America, and that has had some downward pressure on our pricing, particularly in Chile. We have not seen much coming into the U.S. even with the stronger dollar. Pricing really is about cash breakeven for most U.S. producers. So if you're a European producer and add $100 freight to it, I don't think it makes a whole lot of sense.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. That makes sense, Curt. And just last one just on starts. So the headline number certainly look very encouraging, but looking at the details, especially on the permit side, almost half of the starts are multifamily. And so do you have any thoughts ar
componenttext: Yes. That makes sense, Curt. And just last one just on starts. So the headline number certainly look very encouraging, but looking at the details, especially on the permit side, almost half of the starts are multifamily. And so do you have any thoughts around what the mix will look like for housing starts over the next 12 months and sort of implications for your business if more of the mix is multi versus single?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We spend a lot of time -- we actually had Metrostudy in here last week, talked to them, and I talked to Harvard's Joint Center for Housing Studies. The view is that multifamily has basically recovered, so it's back at its historic rate for starts, an
componenttext: Yes. We spend a lot of time -- we actually had Metrostudy in here last week, talked to them, and I talked to Harvard's Joint Center for Housing Studies. The view is that multifamily has basically recovered, so it's back at its historic rate for starts, and the single-family has been benefited by all these other issues. But the growth in the next couple of years is going to come from single family, not from the multifamily. Multifamily will probably stay at the level it's at, but it probably won't be as big a share going forward. And that's consistent with what Harvard believes, Metrostudy believes. FEA also believes that.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the last question is from George Staphos of Bank of America.
componenttext: And the last question is from George Staphos of Bank of America.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two quickies to conclude here. So I remember you saying on SmartSide that you wanted to be, and correct me if I'm wrong, ahead of the market over time because you have great demand for the product, it's a new product, you're gaining market share. If you c
componenttext: Two quickies to conclude here. So I remember you saying on SmartSide that you wanted to be, and correct me if I'm wrong, ahead of the market over time because you have great demand for the product, it's a new product, you're gaining market share. If you could, where would you sort of index your production relative to market demand at this juncture? And then switching gears, just on pricing. Both for the Siding and EWP, prices ticked down a little bit sequentially. I'm assuming that's just seasonality. But was there anything else going on that we should be mindful of?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: On SmartSide, we are running in the mid- to high 90s on our current production. That's why Swan -- the timing of the Swan Valley project is so important because that will allow us a couple more years of growth to come out of that mill. And then we have to
componenttext: On SmartSide, we are running in the mid- to high 90s on our current production. That's why Swan -- the timing of the Swan Valley project is so important because that will allow us a couple more years of growth to come out of that mill. And then we have to start thinking about what the next mill is for Siding. So you're right, we want to be ahead. I think we're probably a quarter behind where I'd like to be. I'd rather have that mill coming up next month than in the fourth quarter. But I think we're in pretty good shape. We're actually -- we were on allocation most of last year. We did see some improvements in our Tomahawk operations. So we are off allocation, which is good for our customers and good for us. So I think the timing of the new mill is okay. It should have been a little bit earlier, but I'm happy with that. As far as pricing, a lot of the pricing is related to the Canadian dollar. If you look at SmartSide or the CanExel pricing, that's all Canadian dollar exchange rate.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: But on SmartSide and also on EWP, was that also largely the impact of currency? Or is that something else?
componenttext: But on SmartSide and also on EWP, was that also largely the impact of currency? Or is that something else?

componenttextpreview: Well, in the case of EWP, currency does play a role because we have some export sales in Australia. There's also mix in EWP and likewise with SmartSide. I mean, it was down 1% on the mix.
componenttext: Well, in the case of EWP, currency does play a role because we have some export sales in Australia. There's also mix in EWP and likewise with SmartSide. I mean, it was down 1% on the mix.

I just got on a bit late. But I had a, I guess, corollary to George's question. If SmartSide will be sold out hopefully in another 2, 3 years after Swan is done, would the subsequent growth also come from a conversion or something greenfield? And hopefully it's a conversion. Do you have any mothballed facilities? Can you hear me? Curt? Sallie?
[Technical Difficulty]
