headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: One question, for Curt, I mean, to the extent that you have a view on this or your customers were commenting on the growth in millennials, what's been catalyzed in millennials start buying homes form your point out. There is living in the basement of thei
componenttext: One question, for Curt, I mean, to the extent that you have a view on this or your customers were commenting on the growth in millennials, what's been catalyzed in millennials start buying homes form your point out. There is living in the basement of their penthouses, is there anything else going on in terms of fundamental standpoint. That's driving that? And then, quick one on OSB and I'll turn it over. From looking at some of our data, panels year-to-date are relatively flat. I don't have the breakdown of OSB versus plywood in that number, but I noticed your volumes were up, is that, do you think OSB gaining market share year-to-date or do you think you've gained market share within OSB year-to-date?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, on the millennials, I think it is the household formations. Again, what I said is $1.1 million in the first quarter, $2.1 million household formation, and a lot of those, I think are the millennial's living their parent's home and actually forming r
componenttext: Well, on the millennials, I think it is the household formations. Again, what I said is $1.1 million in the first quarter, $2.1 million household formation, and a lot of those, I think are the millennial's living their parent's home and actually forming relationships and beginning to have children because the birth rates are coming back up. So I think that's what's driving their participation in the market. A long delay when we didn't have jobs for them and now the household formation creation. On OSB, our sales in Q2 from a volume standpoint out of the OSB segment were a little bit lower than last year. So I'm not sure, I understand your question.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Year-to-date, I saw your volumes in OSB were up, if I'm mistaken, so year-to-date versus '14 or up 4%, which is better than my industry indicators, so just if you had a specific deal on those, I was curious why you think you've gone a little bit stronger

componenttext: And the next question comes from Mark Connelly with CLSA.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Curt, it looks to me like your Siding segment could have been a lot worse given the year-over-year volume declines. So I looked at that performance, is actually pretty good. Can you give me a sense maybe, of why we didn't see a bigger hit from that 14% de
componenttext: Curt, it looks to me like your Siding segment could have been a lot worse given the year-over-year volume declines. So I looked at that performance, is actually pretty good. Can you give me a sense maybe, of why we didn't see a bigger hit from that 14% decline. You got some price, but I'm just wondering if it was mix that saved you?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it was a mix, it was a price increase. but it was also a little bit of mix, we didn't run any OSB in the third quarter last year. We did run a little bit of OSB this year. So that was an offset. And then the costs in our facilities have actually got
componenttext: Well, it was a mix, it was a price increase. but it was also a little bit of mix, we didn't run any OSB in the third quarter last year. We did run a little bit of OSB this year. So that was an offset. And then the costs in our facilities have actually gotten quite a bit better. We just have the benefit of raw materials, so we have lower raw materials in MDI resident, and that we had a little bit of increase, since I, but overall our manufacturing costs were lower. So it's combination of the price and better manufacturing cost.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. One last thing is we've been hearing a lot of chatter about hurricane impact. Is that going to be meaningful at all to you?
componenttext: That's very helpful. One last thing is we've been hearing a lot of chatter about hurricane impact. Is that going to be meaningful at all to you?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. We don't have that in our forecast as an upside.
componenttext: I don't think so. We don't have that in our forecast as an upside.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Curt, can you give a little bit more perspective on the recent OSB priced rally and what you think drove it. To what extent it might have been on the production side versus just kind of catch up from the weather issues in the first half.
componenttext: Curt, can you give a little bit more perspective on the recent OSB priced rally and what you think drove it. To what extent it might have been on the production side versus just kind of catch up from the weather issues in the first half.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I do think the weather issues had some impact on that. We did take, I'm just talking about LP. We did take some downtime and we also were very careful to sell into real demand and not fill the channel. We do think the channel got filled in Q1 and Q2
componenttext: Well, I do think the weather issues had some impact on that. We did take, I'm just talking about LP. We did take some downtime and we also were very careful to sell into real demand and not fill the channel. We do think the channel got filled in Q1 and Q2 and that affected pricing.

componenttext: Well, Sawn and 2, 3 of last year produced about $90 million fee. So the reduction that you saw for the Q3, the Q3 is almost entirely Swan. Because we moved that into the Siding segment.

componenttext: Sure. Overall, we have been saying that raw materials would benefit at year-over-year $50 million and we certainly see that occurring maybe even a little bit better. Basis of the third quarter '15 relative to the third quarter of '14, logs were probably about the same, although we would've seen some improvement in OSB from logs and that would've been offset. We would a negative impact on that on our Siding business. But we saw very positive probably, on the price basis around $10 million quarter-over-quarter for MDIs and waxes and other based input.

componenttext: We -- as I've said, we made our first last Friday. So what we'll be doing is, running that mill this week. We'll be identifying the areas that we need to go in and fix. So sellable product, I wouldn't anticipate, wouldn't come off to a second half of December and they were right into the holiday. So I wouldn't say it's going to be meaningful production out of Swan, until January.

componenttext: In South America, your profit in EBITDA were up $2 million even though the sales were down $10 million. So was that cost improvement and is it sustainable?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we're running our mills in Chile at 100%. Hardly improvement, if you recall in Q3 of last year, we lost a month of production in one of our mills because we had a Flickr blown down. So part of that improvement is that extra month of production in La
componenttext: Well, we're running our mills in Chile at 100%. Hardly improvement, if you recall in Q3 of last year, we lost a month of production in one of our mills because we had a Flickr blown down. So part of that improvement is that extra month of production in Lautaro. And our cost, we've good cost position in Chile. Brazil, our costs are getting better although, we've had a reduction in volume because of the horrible economy there.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. Mid '17, correct. That's right. So let me just be a little more specific. What Chile did is, they adopted the UMP standard on average of people. So essentially, what we have in Chile now is they have a situation somewhere to Canada with First Nation.
componenttext: No. Mid '17, correct. That's right. So let me just be a little more specific. What Chile did is, they adopted the UMP standard on average of people. So essentially, what we have in Chile now is they have a situation somewhere to Canada with First Nation. Whether it's a consultative process, they need to bring, they had to bridge it off the average of people into that. And it is -- it's new for Chile and it's very disjointed.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015

componenttext: With the duplicating claims? And then on Swan, you gave us some indication of how long it will take to be ramped up. Is there a risk that it undermines pricing for Siding as a whole or you think the demand is there.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I don't think there is risk at all. We're the only producer of that product and we compete against fibers and some application side. I think we have a lot for market opportunity. Overall, our Siding business is somewhere in the 6% of the available mar
componenttext: No. I don't think there is risk at all. We're the only producer of that product and we compete against fibers and some application side. I think we have a lot for market opportunity. Overall, our Siding business is somewhere in the 6% of the available market. So we've got a lot of ramp up in front of us.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good. Final question. I agree with you on your 2016 housing forecast. Point two, 1.25. So if the consensus of 1.3 and change is correct and your peers kind of plan production in line with you, will OSB be very tight or is a industry nimble enough to incre
componenttext: Good. Final question. I agree with you on your 2016 housing forecast. Point two, 1.25. So if the consensus of 1.3 and change is correct and your peers kind of plan production in line with you, will OSB be very tight or is a industry nimble enough to increase production rapidly?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think there has been -- let me answer it in a differently. I would say at the Harvard joint center of our housing studies and we did a roundtable to look at what housing starts might be in the consensus in that room was about where we're, 1.2 to 1.25, w
componenttext: I think there has been -- let me answer it in a differently. I would say at the Harvard joint center of our housing studies and we did a roundtable to look at what housing starts might be in the consensus in that room was about where we're, 1.2 to 1.25, with labor being the big issue. So I don't think I can answer your questions directly. What we have is we do have a fair amount of capacity in front of us, with taking Swan Valley up, our Canadian mills are not running at 100%, so we'll have the ability to respond to the increase and demand from about 1.1 million square feet of demand for every 100,000 housing starts. So we had 150,000 housing starts, we need another 1.6 billion. The industry, according to APA, was running at about 86% last quarter. We ran about that same number. So you can use your calculator to figure that out. But I think it's going to be more time.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, I think the sense had been that the Siding business was going at about 15% type rate, volume wise. And obviously, this year, we've had a pause and some of the destocking being a big factor. How are you thinking about the growth rate
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, I think the sense had been that the Siding business was going at about 15% type rate, volume wise. And obviously, this year, we've had a pause and some of the destocking being a big factor. How are you thinking about the growth rate in the Siding business and obviously, tying it to housing starts, kind of as we looked at 2016 and even 2017, any of thumb you could give us?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we need -- I want to be in the low double digits. I'd like to be in the 12% to 14% of growth on the volume year-over-year. You can't really take the increase in housing starts because it's only 14% of the product. Is going into new construction, the
componenttext: Well, we need -- I want to be in the low double digits. I'd like to be in the 12% to 14% of growth on the volume year-over-year. You can't really take the increase in housing starts because it's only 14% of the product. Is going into new construction, the rest is going to repair model and this outdoor billing solution to shut and then the retail piece of it. I think 12% to 14% should be achievable.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And there had been thought process that maybe, you've been capacity constrained at one point. Are you backing away from that perspective and it looks like there was inventory building going on and that was...
componenttext: And there had been thought process that maybe, you've been capacity constrained at one point. Are you backing away from that perspective and it looks like there was inventory building going on and that was...

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think there was a destocking. But also, I think when you go on allocation, to be honest, so your sales force isn't aggressive as they need to be. Now that we have Swan operational, our sales force is going to be a lot more aggressive.
componenttext: I think there was a destocking. But also, I think when you go on allocation, to be honest, so your sales force isn't aggressive as they need to be. Now that we have Swan operational, our sales force is going to be a lot more aggressive.

componenttext: Well, the $4.5 million is the expenses of the people the facility. Didn't have anything to do with the captain, but that was an effect for about half of the quarter. So my guess is the conversion expenses will be in the $6 million to $7 million range in the fourth quarter.

componenttextpreview: Well, a lot of that, we can't really tell where it comes from. A lot of it does come from retail. And if you look at our comparables forward-looking statements and Home Depot year-over-year, I think they were up 2% to 3% to 4%. So not significant. And the
componenttext: Well, a lot of that, we can't really tell where it comes from. A lot of it does come from retail. And if you look at our comparables forward-looking statements and Home Depot year-over-year, I think they were up 2% to 3% to 4%. So not significant. And then the prodealers, we have gone through some consolidations, as you know, BMC and stock. So their numbers are up kind of consistent with housing kind of 10%, kind of increases.

Historically, we found that wage drove and unemployments been the driver, but I can't really point to that as being a driver here, so what do you think household formation. headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the millennials, we spent a lot of time talking about that particularly, at the Harvard meeting. If you look at the Harvard joint center, they just came out of there, state of the nation's housing and there was a section on the millennials. And they do
componenttext: On the millennials, we spent a lot of time talking about that particularly, at the Harvard meeting. If you look at the Harvard joint center, they just came out of there, state of the nation's housing and there was a section on the millennials. And they do think it's getting a job. You're right, that's been necessarily a high-paying job, but they aren't getting employed. I think there is a lot of help coming from the baby-boom generation and helping them make down payments to leave a household. And that's a bigger trend. We also spend a lot of time at student debt. As it turns out that according to Hayward, most of the students debt, it is at risk of being not paid back from a portion of the population that would buy homes anyway. So they don't think that's a big impact on the buying trend for millennials.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation Q3 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation Q3 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms. Sallie Bailey, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Louisiana-Pacific Corp. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Chanel. Good morning, and thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the third quarter of 2015. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer; and with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's Chief Exec
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Chanel. Good morning, and thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the third quarter of 2015. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer; and with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's Chief Executive Officer; as well as Mike Kinney and Becky Barckley, our primary Investor Relations contact.
I'll begin the discussion with a review of the financial results for the third quarter and first 9 months of 2015. It will be followed by some comments on the performance of the individual segments and selected balance sheet items. And after I finish my remarks, Curt will discuss the general market environment in which LP has been operating, provide his perspective on our operative results and give some thoughts on the outlook. As we have done in the past, we have opened up this call to the public and are doing a webcast. And that webcast can be accessed at www.lpcorp.com. 
Additionally, to help with the discussions, we have provided a presentation with supplemental information that should be reviewed in conjunction with the earnings release. I will be referencing these slides in my comments this morning. We filed an 8-K this morning with some supplemental information as well as our Form 10-Q. I want to remind all the participants about the forward-looking statements comment on Slide 2 of the presentation. Please also be aware of the discussion of our use of non-GAAP financial information included on Slide 3 of the presentation. The appendix attached to the presentation has some of the necessary reconciliations that have been supplemented by the Form 8-K filing we made this morning. Rather than reading these 2 statements, I incorporate them with this reference. 
LP's OSB price in the third quarter was 7% below the third quarter of 2014. This level of OSB pricing continued to negatively impact our financial results. However, even in this environment, all 4 business segments reported positive adjusted EBITDA in the third quarter, and we're reporting a comparable level of adjusted EBITDA and $53 million less in sales for the third quarter of 2015 as compared to the third quarter of 2014, while also absorbing $4.5 million of estimated expense associated with the Swan conversion to a Siding mill and $4 million of foreign exchange loss. And with that, let me go into the details. 
Moving to Slide 4 of the presentation for a discussion of the third quarter 2015 and first 9 months of 2015 consolidated results. We are reporting net sales of $465 million for the third quarter of 2015, a 10% decrease from the net sales of $518 million reported in the third quarter of 2014. In the third quarter, we recorded a net loss of $27 million compared to a net loss for the third quarter of 2014 of $20 million. The adjusted loss from continuing operations for the same quarter was $16 million based upon a normalized tax rate of 35%, which is comparable to the same period in 2014. 
Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations of $11 million in the quarter was $1 million less than the third quarter of 2014. In the first 9 months of 2015, we recorded a net loss of $81 million compared to a net loss for the third quarter of 2014 of $33 million. The adjusted loss for the 9-month period was $47 million based upon normalized tax rate of 35% compared to $28 million for the first 9 months of 2014. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $33 million for the first 9 months of 2015 compared to $61 million in the same period of 2014. 
Moving on to Slide 5 of the -- and a review of our segment results, beginning with OSB. OSB recorded an operating loss of $11 million on sales of $200 million compared to a loss of $16 million on $233 million of sales in the third quarter of 2014. For the quarter, we reported adjusted EBITDA of $4 million compared to negative adjusted EBITDA of $1 million for the third quarter of 2014. We had a 9% decrease in sales volume, primarily due to the transfer of our Swan Valley facility to the Siding segment. Overall, the company's OSB shipments, including shipments from our Swan, Hayward and Houlton facilities in the third quarter, were 4% below the third quarter of 2014. 
Pricing for OSB was lower by 7% compared to the third quarter of 2014. This decrease in pricing resulted in lower operating results by $16 million. For the first 9 months of 2015, OSB recorded an operating loss of $58 million and net sales of $601 million compared to a loss of $24 million on $652 million of sales in the first 9 months of 2014. For the first 9 months, we reported negative adjusted EBITDA of $13 million compared to adjusted EBITDA of $19 million in the first 9 months of 2014. 
Sales volumes were higher by 4%, and sales prices were lower by 12%. The impact of the lower sales price on OSB operations was $81 million for the first 9 months of 2015 compared to the prior year. Offsetting the reduction in sales prices for both the quarter and the 9-month period was the reduction in the raw material costs related to petroleum, base raw materials as well as the positive impact of the Canadian currency exchange rate. 
Slide 6 reports the results of our Siding business. This segment includes our SmartSide and CanExel siding products as well as small amounts of OSB. The Siding segment reported net sales of $158 million in the third quarter of 2015, a decrease of 3% from $163 million reported in third quarter of 2014. The Siding segment reported operating income of $17 million compared to $21 million in the third quarter of 2014 and adjusted EBITDA of $22 million as compared to $26 million in the same quarter of 2014. 
For the quarter, SmartSide average sales prices were up 6% and volumes decreased 14%. We believe that the volume decrease in our SmartSide siding line with our customers, especially refinishers, rebalanced our inventories as we came off allocation as well as due to the continued impact of the wet weather in the second quarter of 2015. 
During the third quarter of 2015, we started the conversion of our Swan Valley OSB mill to a SmartSide mill. During the majority of the quarter, this mill was not operational. We estimated that the expenses incurred at the Swan Valley facility during the third quarter related to the conversion were approximately $4.5 million. We produced and sold 57 million square feet of OSB in this segment during the third quarter of 2015. CanExel prices were down 12% U.S. dollars, but up 11% in Canadian dollars. Canada is CanExel's primary market. Volumes were down 14% in the quarter due to decreased demand, primarily in Europe, due to discontinuation of certain pre-finished color Siding products. 
The Siding segment reported sales of $495 million for the first 9 months of 2015, an increase of 4% from $476 million reported in the first 9 months of 2014. Siding segment reported operating income of $79 million and adjusted EBITDA of $95 million for the first 9 months of 2015 as compared to $66 million of operating income and $79 million of adjusted EBITDA in the same period of 2014. 
SmartSide sales prices were up 6% and volumes were down 1% for the 9 months of 2015 compared to the same period in 2014. CanExel sales prices were down 6% in U.S. dollars, however, up 12% in Canadian dollar. Sales volume decreased 8%. 
Please turn to Slide 7 of the presentation, which shows the results of our Engineered Wood Products segment. This segment includes I-Joist, the Laminated Strand Lumber, Laminated Veneer Lumber, OSB produced at our Houlton, Maine facility plus other related products. This segment also includes the sale of I-Joist and LVL products produced by the Abitibi joint venture under a sales arrangement with Murphy Plywood. 
The Engineered Wood Products segment recorded sales of $74 million in the third quarter of 2015, down from $77 million in the third quarter of 2014. The segment's operating loss in the third quarter of 2015 was $1 million as compared to breakeven in the third quarter of 2014. For the third quarter of 2015, adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations declined by $1 million from the third quarter of 2014 to $3 million. Volumes of I-Joist were up 5%, while volumes of LVL and LSL were down 3% to the same quarter of last year. Pricing was down 1% in both I-Joist, LVL and LSL.
During the quarter and the first 9 months of 2015, we changed the mix of OSB products at our Houlton operations to manufacture primarily value-added foreign products. The impact of this change improved operating results by $500,000 in the quarter and $2.1 million for the first 9 months of 2015. 
For the first 9 months, sales were $211 million, down slightly from the same period in 2014. The segment's operating loss in the first 9 months was $7 million as compared to $9 million in the same period of 2014. Adjusted EBITDA declined by $1 million for the first 9 months of 2015 compared to the same period in 2014. 
Turning to Slide 8 of the presentation. For the quarter, our South American segment recorded $27 million -- recorded sales of $27 million as compared to $36 million in the third quarter of 2014. Operating income was $2 million in the third quarter of 2015 compared to breakeven in the third quarter of 2014. South America's adjusted EBITDA of $4 million for the third quarter of 2015 was $2 million higher than the same period in 2014. Volumes in Chile were up 13% and lower by 4% in Brazil compared to the same quarter last year. The sales volume increase in Chile was primarily due to improved housing demand. In Brazil, the reduction in sales volume was due to reduced industrial demand associated with the economic recession. Pricing was down 15% in Chile and down 23% in Brazil. In local currency, Chile's pricing was flat with the same quarter in 2014, and Brazil's pricing showed an increase of 21%, primarily due to increased exports. For the first 9 months, our South American segment recorded sales of $101 million as compared to $115 million in the first 9 months of 2014. 
Operating income was $7 million compared to $9 million in the first 9 months of 2014. And adjusted EBITDA declined to $13 million from $15 million from the same period in 2014. Total selling, general and administrative expenses were $38 million in the quarter of 2015 compared to $32 million in the same quarter of 2014, and $115 million for the first 9 months as compared to $109 million for the same period in 2014. 
For the quarter and the 9-month period, the increase in selling, general and administrative expenses was primarily related to higher sales and marketing expenses associated with our corporate initiatives and compensation expense. 
We recorded a $4 million foreign exchange loss in the quarter compared to a $1 million loss in the same quarter last year. For the first 9 months, we recorded a loss of $6 million compared to a $2 million loss in 2014. This loss was primarily driven by the devaluation of the Brazilian real and the devaluation's impact on the dollar-denominated loan. These foreign exchange losses are deductions to our adjusted EBITDA. Interest expense net was flat between the quarters. 
Please refer to Slide 9 of the presentation. As of September 30, 2015, we had cash, cash equivalents, investments and restricted cash of $468 million; working capital of $674 million; net cash of $101 million. In addition to the $468 million of cash on our balance sheet, we have $200 million of availability on our credit facility. Capital expenditures through September 30, 2015, were $67 million. Capital spending for 2015 is expected to be in the range of $120 million to $130 million. We are still completing our 2016 budget, but we expect capital spending for 2016 to be around $100 million for our North American business. We continue to invest in our Siding business. We also plan to invest in our South American business with our third Chilean mill, and we anticipated that the third Chilean mill will be funded by cash on hand in Chile as well as local borrowing.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Curt for his comments.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sallie. Good morning, and thanks for joining us on the call. Let me first start with LP's safety performance. Year-to-date, our total incident rate for recordable injuries was 0.49 and the rolling 12-month PIR at the end of September was at 0.4
componenttext:
Thank you, Sallie. Good morning, and thanks for joining us on the call. Let me first start with LP's safety performance. Year-to-date, our total incident rate for recordable injuries was 0.49 and the rolling 12-month PIR at the end of September was at 0.43. Significant milestones in the quarter included 3 years recordable-free at our Panguipulli mill in Chile, 2 years injury-free in Park County Alabama and 3 mills have celebrated 1 year without a recordable injury. 
As I typically do on these calls, I will provide a few comments on our results and the accomplishments in the quarter, discuss the housing market and give you my views on the rest of 2015 and into next year. After that, we'll turn it over to Chanel to take questions. OSB pricing continues to be below the projections from industry experts like FEA, RISI, analysts and others. Random Lengths North Central was 7% below and already low Q3 2014 pricing level. The good news is that we have seen the OSB prices as recorded by Random Lengths' move from about $184 per MSF 3/8 North Central at the end of July to $253 last Friday, 13 straight weeks of increases that accumulated to 38% better pricing. Our Siding business had a reasonable quarter with $22 million in adjusted EBITDA, despite the negative impact of the inventory drawdowns, particularly at our pre-finishing customers and the costs associated with the Swan Valley conversion. 
Speaking about the conversion in the Swan Valley OSB mill to SmartSide production, I'm pleased to report that we produced our first Siding board last Friday and the project is on-time and on budget. As you know, this will be critical to the ongoing growth of this important business segment. One other note is we completed that project injury-free both for our employees as well as the many contractors that we had on-site. 
EWP was once again a positive EBITDA in the quarter with volumes that were consistent -- volume changes that were consistent with the industry as reported by the APA. In South America, our results were nearly doubled the same quarter last year, despite ongoing political and economic turmoil in Brazil and much weaker currencies in both Brazil and in Chile. 
In early October, a vote was taken among the various governmental agencies to approve the environmental permit for our third mill in Chile and the result was positive. We are in the mandatory waiting period provided by statute for any further concerns to be raised. This period will end in late November, and assuming nothing is filed, we will be in a position to begin this work in earnest. 
With a changing government and additional regulations, this process has taken longer and been more complicated than we've experienced in the past. On the housing market, there was mostly good news in the U.S. Census Bureau released on housing on October 20. For September, housing starts came in at a little over 1.2 million, while permits were a bit lower at 1.1 million. This is the sixth month in a row with housing starts over 1 million with the average over this period of time being 1.161. Another positive housing news, household formations continue to significantly exceed the anemic pace of the last several years. In Q1 of this year, household formations were 1.5 million. In Q2, that pace increased to 2.1 million, according to Census Bureau data. Over the last few years, there's been a lot of concern about the participation of the millennial generation in the housing recovery. So here's a piece of good news. The 2015 National Association of Realtors, Home Buyers and Seller Generational Trend Report, that's a mouthful, says millennials now comprise the largest category of home buyers, 32%, with 68% of those being first-time homebuyers. The NAHB homebuilder confidence index in September reached the highest level in over 10 years, which also bodes well for more activity. On the financing side, the average 30-year fixed mortgage rate for the weakening October 16 was at 3.82%, which, interesting, is below the rate it was a year ago. With higher sales of existing homes, this is also good news for repair and remodeling expenditures. So the forecast for future housing activity now stand at the consensus for 2015 is 1.125 million, a 12% increase over last year. And the consensus forecast for 2016 is 1.307 million or 16% increase over the forecast for 2015. 
For LP, we are using a budget assumption of 1.2 million to 1.25 million for 2016 housing starts. In the first half this year, we did see somewhat weaker demand for our products, probably driven by very cold weather in the first quarter and wet weather in the second quarter. This led to a drawdown of inventories early in the third quarter with a pickup in activity in August and September. This increased demand was reflected in the increasing OSB pricing during the last 2 months of the quarter and into October. With a more mild fall so far, we are continuing to see demand at higher levels, which should carry over into 2016. Based on discussions with customers, there was a strong belief that 2016 will have a higher level of activity than this year in all areas: new home construction, repair/remodel, light commercial and industrial. This is good for LP as we focus on these broader segments with value propositions to each. 
As I look out beyond next year, I believe that we'll have several more years of housing growth in front of us based on demographics and the slow rate of recovery so far. The major constraining factors to a more immediate, robust housing recovery remain labor at all levels, available lots and access to credit for the first-time homebuyer. I believe that the labor issues faced by the builders will ease either through increased employment or changing construction practices that will reduce the need for labor. The lot shortage is a result of a multitude of factors that may take longer to address. Regulation, shortage of manpower and planning departments, funding for infrastructure and higher land pricing. On the financing side, we now know there will be no significant changes for Fannie and Freddie until after the 2016 elections. It looks like the Fed is going to delay action until December on raising rates, and banks should get into the practice of making loans again. This is good for our stakeholders as LP is well positioned to capitalize on the continued growth and housing, repair and remodeling activities with our product portfolio and focus on growth and innovation to meet our customers' needs.
With that, let me turn it over to Chanel for questions.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Paul Quinn of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Paul Quinn of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015

componenttext: Sure, Paul. In the third quarter, we check about 50 days of downtime, which is about 74 million square feet, and we don't give indications of the fourth quarter.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just turning onto Siding. Year-to-date volume is down 1%. You had a very, very strong Q1 and Q2. Sort of where you missed versus my bullish forecast was really on the Siding said. Just wondering why you saw a drop in Q3.
componenttext: Okay. And then just turning onto Siding. Year-to-date volume is down 1%. You had a very, very strong Q1 and Q2. Sort of where you missed versus my bullish forecast was really on the Siding said. Just wondering why you saw a drop in Q3.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we -- Sallie mentioned it in her comments and I said it as well. We look at our customers to find out when we're losing that business. And principally, where we lost business in Q3 was to the pre-finishers. So our pre-finished customers took a lot o
componenttext: Well, we -- Sallie mentioned it in her comments and I said it as well. We look at our customers to find out when we're losing that business. And principally, where we lost business in Q3 was to the pre-finishers. So our pre-finished customers took a lot of product in the first quarter and into the second quarter because they don't have the ability to finish it all within the quarter, so they have to put inventory in place. And then with the wet weather we had in Q2, they didn't have the offtakes in Q2, so they didn't reorder in Q3. But it really is tied to those pre-finishers now. Our salespeople have talked to them. There's no reduction in their business, but there was a delay due to the wet weather. So really I think focused at that, as we look at October, we're having a pretty good October.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, another way for you to think about it is that as we went on allocation, we did see some inventory going into the channel. And as we've come off the allocation, we think that inventory will come back sort of on LP versus our customer's book. So there
componenttext: Well, another way for you to think about it is that as we went on allocation, we did see some inventory going into the channel. And as we've come off the allocation, we think that inventory will come back sort of on LP versus our customer's book. So there's that dynamic going on as well.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And last question I had, just on CapEx. You guided $100 million in '16 on North America. What is it in South America for the new mill?
componenttext: Okay. And last question I had, just on CapEx. You guided $100 million in '16 on North America. What is it in South America for the new mill?

componenttext: Well, we don't really know. What we said depends on the timing, as Curt talked about. But overall, we think that mill could cost as much as $50 to $60. But I think...

componenttextpreview: Million dollars.
componenttext: Million dollars.

componenttext: Million dollars, thank you. Depends on how the currency goes. But I think the most important takeaway is that Chile does have cash on their balance sheet as well as the ability to fund that locally. So we will not be paying for that out of our North American cash balances.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from George Staphos of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And our next question comes from George Staphos of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, first question I had, Sallie, was did the pickup in the inventory that we see on the cash flow statement in the quarter, was that in any way related to the destocking that you had in Siding, i.e. you had more production sitting on your balance sh
componenttext: I guess, first question I had, Sallie, was did the pickup in the inventory that we see on the cash flow statement in the quarter, was that in any way related to the destocking that you had in Siding, i.e. you had more production sitting on your balance sheet than was ultimately taken away by the customers? Or were they unrelated there?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's mostly logs, the pickups and the inventories related to logs.
componenttext: It's mostly logs, the pickups and the inventories related to logs.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I mean, I think you've already covered this, but I just wanted to maybe get one last affirmation. So from your vantage point, the slowdown that you saw in Siding, you don't think you're losing any ability to penetrate the market. You're not seei
componenttext: Okay. And I mean, I think you've already covered this, but I just wanted to maybe get one last affirmation. So from your vantage point, the slowdown that you saw in Siding, you don't think you're losing any ability to penetrate the market. You're not seeing any sort of competitive response that is slowing your progressions here. It's purely just timing of customer's inventory relative to your production and things are looking better as we get into the fourth quarter.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's my conclusion, George. If you look at it by segment, our retail business is pretty good all the way through. Repair/remodeling business is largely where the finished product goes, so repair/remodeling has been off. And then with new home constructi
componenttext: That's my conclusion, George. If you look at it by segment, our retail business is pretty good all the way through. Repair/remodeling business is largely where the finished product goes, so repair/remodeling has been off. And then with new home construction, we've seen a tremendous change in the cycle time for building a house, going from 90 to 100 days to 170 to 180 days. And the Siding is the last thing that goes on in the structure. So we think a little bit of that impact has hit us as well.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: But we also want to call your attention to -- that we did have a 6% price increase quarter-over-quarter and year-to-date price in SmartSide is up 6%.
componenttext: But we also want to call your attention to -- that we did have a 6% price increase quarter-over-quarter and year-to-date price in SmartSide is up 6%.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. So you think maybe there's a little bit of pull forward as well ahead of whatever pricing you might have had in play?
componenttext: Okay. All right. So you think maybe there's a little bit of pull forward as well ahead of whatever pricing you might have had in play?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the point is that we've been able to maintain price through and actually increase it year-over-year.
componenttext: I think the point is that we've been able to maintain price through and actually increase it year-over-year.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. One question for Curt. Curt, I mean, to the extent that you have a view on this or your customers were commenting on the growth in millennials, what's been catalyzed in millennials to finally start buying homes from your viewpoint other t
componenttext: Okay. All right. One question for Curt. Curt, I mean, to the extent that you have a view on this or your customers were commenting on the growth in millennials, what's been catalyzed in millennials to finally start buying homes from your viewpoint other than they're sick and tired of living in the basement of their parent's houses? Is there anything else going on in terms of -- from a fundamental standpoint, that's driving that? And then quick one on OSB and I'll turn it over. From looking at some of our industry data, panels year-to-date are relatively flat. I don't have the breakdown of OSB versus plywood in that number, but I noticed your volumes were up. Is that, do you think, OSB gaining market share year-to-date? Or do you think you've gained market share within OSB year-to-date?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, on the millennials, I think it is the household formations. Again, what I said is 1.1 million in the first quarter to 2.1 million household formations, and a lot of those, I think, are the millennials living their parent's home and actually forming
componenttext: Well, on the millennials, I think it is the household formations. Again, what I said is 1.1 million in the first quarter to 2.1 million household formations, and a lot of those, I think, are the millennials living their parent's home and actually forming relationships and beginning to have children because the birth rates are coming back up. So I think that's what's driving their participation of the market. A long delay when we didn't have jobs for them and now the household formation creation. On OSB, our -- actually, our sales in Q2 from a volume standpoint out of the OSB segment were a little bit lower than last year. So I'm not sure I understand your question.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, year-to-date, I thought your volumes in OSB were up, unless I was mistaken. So year-to-date versus '14, you're up 4%, which is better than my industry indicator. So I was just -- if you had a specific view on that, I was curious why you think you've
componenttext: Well, year-to-date, I thought your volumes in OSB were up, unless I was mistaken. So year-to-date versus '14, you're up 4%, which is better than my industry indicator. So I was just -- if you had a specific view on that, I was curious why you think you've grown a little bit stronger than the panel market overall, whether it's OSB gaining share versus plywood or do you think you've gained share within OSB? That was all that was in the question.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the APA industry stats would say it's up about 4% as well. So I think we're pretty consistent.
componenttext: I think the APA industry stats would say it's up about 4% as well. So I think we're pretty consistent.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Mark Connelly of CLSA.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Mark Connelly of CLSA.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Curt, it looks to me like your Siding segment could have been a lot worse given the year-over-year volume declines. So I looked at that performance, it's actually pretty good. Can you give me a sense maybe of why we didn't see a bigger hit from that 14% d
componenttext: Curt, it looks to me like your Siding segment could have been a lot worse given the year-over-year volume declines. So I looked at that performance, it's actually pretty good. Can you give me a sense maybe of why we didn't see a bigger hit from that 14% decline? You got some price, but I'm just wondering if it was mix that saved you?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it was a mix, it was a price increase, but it was also a little bit of mix. We didn't run any OSB in the third quarter last year. We did run a little bit of OSB this year, so that was an offset. And then the costs in our facilities have actually got
componenttext: Well, it was a mix, it was a price increase, but it was also a little bit of mix. We didn't run any OSB in the third quarter last year. We did run a little bit of OSB this year, so that was an offset. And then the costs in our facilities have actually gotten quite a bit better. We did have the benefit of raw materials, so we had lower raw materials in MDI resin, and that we had a little bit of an increase in zinc borate. But overall, our manufacturing costs were lower. So it's a combination of the price and better manufacturing cost.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. And one last thing is we've been hearing a lot of chatter about hurricane impact. Is that going to be meaningful at all to you?
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. And one last thing is we've been hearing a lot of chatter about hurricane impact. Is that going to be meaningful at all to you?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. We don't have that in our forecast as an upside.
componenttext: I don't think so. We don't have that in our forecast as an upside.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gail Glazerman of UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gail Glazerman of UBS.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Curt, can you give a little bit more perspective on the recent OSB price rally and what you think drove it? To what extent it might have been on the production side versus just kind of catch-up from the weather issues in the first half?
componenttext: Curt, can you give a little bit more perspective on the recent OSB price rally and what you think drove it? To what extent it might have been on the production side versus just kind of catch-up from the weather issues in the first half?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I do think the weather issues had some impact on that. We did take, I'm just talking about LP, we did take some downtime and we also were very careful to sell into real demand and not fill the channel. We do think the channel got filled in Q1 and Q2
componenttext: Well, I do think the weather issues had some impact on that. We did take, I'm just talking about LP, we did take some downtime and we also were very careful to sell into real demand and not fill the channel. We do think the channel got filled in Q1 and Q2 and that affected pricing.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And slightly related to that. The 50 million down days, is that kind of apples-to-apples to what you're taking earlier in the year? Or would the outage at Swan maybe have impacted that, if we take a little more company look?
componenttext: Okay. And slightly related to that. The 50 million down days, is that kind of apples-to-apples to what you're taking earlier in the year? Or would the outage at Swan maybe have impacted that, if we take a little more company look?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Sawn in Q3 of last year produced about 90 million feet. So the reduction that you saw for the Q3-to-Q3 is almost off entirely Swan because we moved that into the Siding segment.
componenttext: Well, Sawn in Q3 of last year produced about 90 million feet. So the reduction that you saw for the Q3-to-Q3 is almost off entirely Swan because we moved that into the Siding segment.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. And then, Sallie, can you just give more details on kind of the raw material cost relief you've seen maybe year-over-year in the third quarter as well as year-to-date?
componenttext: All right. And then, Sallie, can you just give more details on kind of the raw material cost relief you've seen maybe year-over-year in the third quarter as well as year-to-date?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I -- overall, we have been saying that raw materials would benefit year-over-year around $50 million, and we certainly see that occurring maybe even a little bit better. Basis of the third quarter '15 relative to the third quarter of '14, logs
componenttext: Yes, sure. I -- overall, we have been saying that raw materials would benefit year-over-year around $50 million, and we certainly see that occurring maybe even a little bit better. Basis of the third quarter '15 relative to the third quarter of '14, logs were probably about the same, although we would've seen some improvement in OSB from logs and that would've been offset. We would have a negative impact to that on our Siding business. But we saw very positive, probably on the price basis, around $10 million quarter-over-quarter for MDIs and waxes and other resin-based input.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, almost all the -- Gail, almost all the savings is coming from the resins or waxes that are tied into benchmarks that are oil derivatives.
componenttext: Yes, almost all the -- Gail, almost all the savings is coming from the resins or waxes that are tied into benchmarks that are oil derivatives.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one last one question on kind of global trade flows. Not much, but your Chilean prices were down a teeny bit sequentially. Did you see any sort of uptick in North American flows down to Chile? Or has the currency situation been enough to ki
componenttext: Okay. And just one last one question on kind of global trade flows. Not much, but your Chilean prices were down a teeny bit sequentially. Did you see any sort of uptick in North American flows down to Chile? Or has the currency situation been enough to kind of keep that in check?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We actually saw pressure coming from Europe and imports into Chile. We didn't see much coming down from the U.S., mainly from Europe.
componenttext: We actually saw pressure coming from Europe and imports into Chile. We didn't see much coming down from the U.S., mainly from Europe.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ketan Mamtora of BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ketan Mamtora of BMO Capital Markets.

componenttext: From the flooding?

componenttextpreview: Yes. Just generally, is there any uptick in...
componenttext: Yes. Just generally, is there any uptick in...

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. Actually, where we operate in Texas wasn't affected that much. That would have been the primary area. And then, as you know, we don't operate in South Carolina, but South Carolina did have a disruption of logs for a number of our competitors.
componenttext: No. Actually, where we operate in Texas wasn't affected that much. That would have been the primary area. And then, as you know, we don't operate in South Carolina, but South Carolina did have a disruption of logs for a number of our competitors.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you, okay. And then switching to Swan Valley, can you just help us provide some sort of guideline on the ramp-up? Because I know this quarter, there was a lot of noise between OSB and production and Siding. But if you can just help us provide some gui
componenttext: Got you, okay. And then switching to Swan Valley, can you just help us provide some sort of guideline on the ramp-up? Because I know this quarter, there was a lot of noise between OSB and production and Siding. But if you can just help us provide some guideline in terms of the ramp-up.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we, as I said, we made our first board last Friday. So what we'll be doing is running that mill this week. We'll be identifying the areas that we need to go in and fix. And then we'll spend most of the November and the first part of December making
componenttext: Well, we, as I said, we made our first board last Friday. So what we'll be doing is running that mill this week. We'll be identifying the areas that we need to go in and fix. And then we'll spend most of the November and the first part of December making those fixes. So sellable product, I would anticipate, wouldn't come off until the second half of December and they were right into the holiday. So I wouldn't say there's going to be meaningful production out of Swan until January.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. And so there would, obviously, not be any OSB production during that time at the mill?
componenttext: Got you. And so there would, obviously, not be any OSB production during that time at the mill?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not at Swan. If you recall, Ketan, what we said is we would move -- if we had excess capacity inside, we'll move the OSB production to Hayward.
componenttext: Not at Swan. If you recall, Ketan, what we said is we would move -- if we had excess capacity inside, we'll move the OSB production to Hayward.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Steve Chercover of D.A. Davidson.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Steve Chercover of D.A. Davidson.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: In South America, your profit in EBITDA were up $2 million, even though the sales were down $10 million. So was that cost improvement and is it sustainable?
componenttext: In South America, your profit in EBITDA were up $2 million, even though the sales were down $10 million. So was that cost improvement and is it sustainable?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we're running our mills in Chile at 100%. Hardly improvement. If you recall in Q3 of last year, we lost a month of production in one of our mills because we had a flaker go down. So part of that improvement is that extra month of production in Lauta
componenttext: Well, we're running our mills in Chile at 100%. Hardly improvement. If you recall in Q3 of last year, we lost a month of production in one of our mills because we had a flaker go down. So part of that improvement is that extra month of production in Lautaro. And our costs, we have a good cost position in Chile. Brazil, our costs are getting better, although we've had a reduction in volume because of the horrible economy there.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I mean, you're saying that it's actually getting more onerous to get the permitting for your new mill down in South America. I mean, well, it's everything went perfect, would it be online maybe for mid-'17 or something?
componenttext: And I mean, you're saying that it's actually getting more onerous to get the permitting for your new mill down in South America. I mean, well, it's everything went perfect, would it be online maybe for mid-'17 or something?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. Well, mid-'17, correct. That's about right. So let me just be a little more specific. What Chile did is they adopted the U.N. standard on aboriginal people. So essentially, what we have in Chile now is we have a situation similar to Canada with First
componenttext: No. Well, mid-'17, correct. That's about right. So let me just be a little more specific. What Chile did is they adopted the U.N. standard on aboriginal people. So essentially, what we have in Chile now is we have a situation similar to Canada with First Nations. Whether it's a consultative process, you need to bring the aboriginal people into that. And it is -- it's new for Chile and it's very disjointed.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that -- I guess, that impacts logging or it implies that they have to participate in the logging the way the natives in Canada get some of the tree farming.
componenttext: And that -- I guess, that impacts logging or it implies that they have to participate in the logging the way the natives in Canada get some of the tree farming.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, that actually isn't the issue because we actually employ within the region where we operate that we do have the tribes called Mapuche. We actually employ about 30% of our workforce. So that's not the issue. It's that they are contending they own the n
componenttext: No, that actually isn't the issue because we actually employ within the region where we operate that we do have the tribes called Mapuche. We actually employ about 30% of our workforce. So that's not the issue. It's that they are contending they own the natural resources similar to Canada. And so you can't do -- get your fiber out of the woods without some kind of agreement with the natives.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: In Canada, they own 150% of the natural resource.
componenttext: In Canada, they own 150% of the natural resource.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's right.
componenttext: Yes, I think that's right.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, with the duplicating claims, okay. And then, on Swan, you gave us some indication of how long it will take to be ramped up. Is there a risk that it undermines pricing for Siding as a whole or you think that the demand is there?
componenttext: Well, with the duplicating claims, okay. And then, on Swan, you gave us some indication of how long it will take to be ramped up. Is there a risk that it undermines pricing for Siding as a whole or you think that the demand is there?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think there's any risk at all because we're the only producer of that product and we compete against inter-James Hardie in fiber cement and vinyl and some applications. So I think we have lots of market opportunity. Overall, our Siding busines
componenttext: No, I don't think there's any risk at all because we're the only producer of that product and we compete against inter-James Hardie in fiber cement and vinyl and some applications. So I think we have lots of market opportunity. Overall, our Siding business is somewhere in the 6% of the available market, so we've got a lot of ramp-up in front of us.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good. Okay. Final question. I agree with you on your 2016 housing forecast at 1.2 million to 1.25 million. So if the consensus of 1.3 million and change is correct and your peers kind of plan production in line with you, will OSB be very tight or is a ind
componenttext: Good. Okay. Final question. I agree with you on your 2016 housing forecast at 1.2 million to 1.25 million. So if the consensus of 1.3 million and change is correct and your peers kind of plan production in line with you, will OSB be very tight or is a industry nimble enough to increase production rapidly?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think there's been -- let me answer it in a different way. I would say at the Harvard joint center for housing studies and we did a roundtable to look at what housing starts might be and the consensus in that room was right about where we are, 1.2 milli
componenttext: I think there's been -- let me answer it in a different way. I would say at the Harvard joint center for housing studies and we did a roundtable to look at what housing starts might be and the consensus in that room was right about where we are, 1.2 million to 1.25 million, with labor being the big issue. So I don't think I can answer your question directly. What we have is we do have a fair amount of capacity in front of us. Even with taking Swan Valley out, our Canadian mills are not running at 100%, so we'll have the ability to respond to the increase in demand from housing starts to be -- remember the rule of thumb, it's about 1.1 billion square feet of demand for every 100,000 housing starts. So if we had 150,000 housing starts, that means we need another 1.6 billion. The industry, according to APA, was running at about 86% last quarter. We ran about that same number. So you can use your calculator to figure that out, but I think it's going to be more tight.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015

componenttext: And our next question comes from Mark Weintraub of Buckingham Research.

componenttextpreview: And then you'd mentioned that October was pretty good. Are you starting to see favorable year-over-year comparison volume-wise yet? Or maybe asking the question a little bit differently, are we done with the destocking, do you think?
componenttext: And then you'd mentioned that October was pretty good. Are you starting to see favorable year-over-year comparison volume-wise yet? Or maybe asking the question a little bit differently, are we done with the destocking, do you think?

componenttextpreview: I think so. I think we should have normal takeaways.
componenttext: I think so. I think we should have normal takeaways.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And so would it be fair to say we're positive in October for SmartSide volume-wise?
componenttext: And so would it be fair to say we're positive in October for SmartSide volume-wise?

componenttextpreview: I haven't looked at the numbers. I can't answer that.
componenttext: I haven't looked at the numbers. I can't answer that.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, I think the sense had been that the Siding business was growing at about a 15% type rate volume-wise. And obviously, this year, we've had a pause and some of the destocking being a big factor. How are you thinking about the growth r
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, I think the sense had been that the Siding business was growing at about a 15% type rate volume-wise. And obviously, this year, we've had a pause and some of the destocking being a big factor. How are you thinking about the growth rate in the Siding business, and obviously, tying it to housing starts, kind of as we look to 2016 and even 2017? Any rules of thumb you could give us?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we need -- I want to be in the low double digits. I would like to be in the 12% to 14% kind of growth on volume year-over-year. You can't really take the increase in housing starts because only 40% of the product is going into new construction, the
componenttext: Well, we need -- I want to be in the low double digits. I would like to be in the 12% to 14% kind of growth on volume year-over-year. You can't really take the increase in housing starts because only 40% of the product is going into new construction, the rest is going to repair/remodel and these outdoor building solutions, the sheds and then the retail piece of it. I think 12% to 14% should be achievable.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And there had been a thought process that maybe you've been capacity constrained at one point. I mean, have you -- are you backing away from that perspective? And it looks like there was inventory building going on and that was...
componenttext: And there had been a thought process that maybe you've been capacity constrained at one point. I mean, have you -- are you backing away from that perspective? And it looks like there was inventory building going on and that was...

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think there was a destocking. But also, I think when you go on allocation, to be honest, your sales force isn't as aggressive as they need to be. Now that we have Swan operational, the sales force is going to be a lot more aggressive.
componenttext: I think there was a destocking. But also, I think when you go on allocation, to be honest, your sales force isn't as aggressive as they need to be. Now that we have Swan operational, the sales force is going to be a lot more aggressive.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. So lastly and then I'll stop beating a dead horse here. But -- and so do you think this is kind of a 1 quarter blip and we should be back on track starting fourth quarter and beyond in Siding?
componenttext: Okay, great. So lastly and then I'll stop beating a dead horse here. But -- and so do you think this is kind of a 1 quarter blip and we should be back on track starting fourth quarter and beyond in Siding?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's probably not going to pick up the pace until Q1 where we have the Swan contributing, Swan Valley mill contributing.
componenttext: I think it's probably not going to pick up the pace until Q1 where we have the Swan contributing, Swan Valley mill contributing.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Sean Steuart of TD Securities.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Sean Steuart of TD Securities.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: For the conversion expenses at Swan Valley, how much more should we expect to carry into the fourth quarter, if anything?
componenttext: For the conversion expenses at Swan Valley, how much more should we expect to carry into the fourth quarter, if anything?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the $4.5 million is the expenses of the people in running the facility. Didn't have anything to do with the capital, but that was an effect for about half the quarter. So my guess is the conversion expenses will be in the $6 million to $7.5 million
componenttext: Well, the $4.5 million is the expenses of the people in running the facility. Didn't have anything to do with the capital, but that was an effect for about half the quarter. So my guess is the conversion expenses will be in the $6 million to $7.5 million range in the fourth quarter.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Curt, as you showed with OSB, because it is driven by U.S. housing activity, you talked about that driver, but can you speak to some of the other end markets in OSB: the renovation, commercial, industrial end markets? What are you seeing t
componenttext: Okay. componenttext: Just some housekeeping at the end. First for all, Curt, I didn't want to quadruple it, but on millennials and there are sort of recovery in terms of housing demand, I know household formation drives ultimately construction, but what's driving household formation, if again you have a specific view on this from your sources? Historically, we found that wage growth and employment has been the driver, but I can't really point to that as being a driver here. So what do you think is going on with household formation? And then my other 2 questions. Sallie, I think you mentioned there were some corporate initiatives in SG&A. Were those large? What was behind that? And just I think you said the operating rate in OSB this year-to-date was 86%. Did I hear that correctly for you guys?

componenttext: On the millennials, we spend a lot of time talking about that, particularly at the Harvard meeting. If you look at the Harvard joint center for housing studies, they just came out with their state of the nation's housing and there was a section on the millennials. And they do think it's getting a job. You're right, it hasn't been necessarily a high-paying job, but they are getting employed. And I think there's a lot of help coming from the baby-boom generation and helping them make down payments to leave a household. And that's a bigger trend. We also spend a lot of time talking about student debt. As it turns out that according to Harvard, most of the student debt, it is at risk of being not paid back is from a portion of the population that wouldn't buy homes anyway. So they don't think that's a big impact on the buying trend for millennials.
